Step 1: Use Python or PowerShell to read System Up Time and event log entries for Event ID 6005.Step 2: Count how many reboots have occurred in the past 24 hours.Step 3: If more than 3–5 reboots are detected, assume sandbox activity.Step 4: If normal uptime and fewer reboots, proceed.Step 5: Simulate repeated reboots in a test VM and see impact.Step 6: Compare logs with a fresh installation.

Step 1: Use Python time.time() to record start time.Step 2: Perform a trivial task (e.g., sum a large array).Step 3: Record end time and calculate duration.Step 4: If time taken is significantly longer than expected, assume overhead from analysis.Step 5: Exit quietly.Step 6: On fast hardware, continue execution normally.

Step 1: Use Python to enumerate all loaded modules/DLLs of the current process.Step 2: Search for DLLs like sbiedll.dll (Sandboxie), dbghelp.dll (debugger), or api_log.dll (CWSandbox).Step 3: If found, terminate or delay the malware.Step 4: If not found, execute the payload.Step 5: Use tools like Process Hacker to simulate loading/unloading DLLs and compare behavior.Step 6: Observe real-time changes in loaded modules during simulation.

Step 1: Use Python to randomize SMTP commands timing and spacing.Step 2: Strip STARTTLS in randomized form (e.g., modify individual chars in real-time).Step 3: Evade AI-based detection systems that rely on standard patterns.Step 4: Send email and capture traffic.Step 5: Demonstrate how traffic looks benign due to entropy.Step 6: Replay for validation.Step 7: Highlight challenges of AI/ML defense in protocol downgrades.

Step 1: Use Python to retrieve the list of running processes (via tasklist).Step 2: Search for sandbox-related processes like vboxservice.exe, vmtoolsd.exe, wireshark.exe, Procmon.exe.Step 3: Additionally, use libraries like pygetwindow to check if window titles contain keywords like "Sandbox", "Debugger", etc.Step 4: If detected, the malware quits.Step 5: If not, proceed with dummy payload or message.Step 6: Simulate running malware with and without these tools active.

Step 1: Use Python to search for paths like C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox Guest Additions, C:\cuckoo, etc.Step 2: If these exist, malware exits.Step 3: Otherwise, continue with mock payload.Step 4: Test behavior on real vs. sandboxed system with those folders.Step 5: Simulate folder removal and analyze response.Step 6: Log file access in sandbox for detection.

Step 1: Use Python’s pyperclip to copy a string to clipboard.Step 2: Immediately read it back.Step 3: If value is different or inaccessible, assume sandbox interference.Step 4: Exit quietly.Step 5: If clipboard acts normally, malware proceeds.Step 6: Run on real and sandboxed systems and compare results.

Step 1: Use RTL-SDR to capture the signal when the homeowner uses their RF remote to toggle the light.Step 2: Save the waveform and label it as "light ON".Step 3: Record another signal labeled "light OFF".Step 4: Replay these at different times using HackRF or compatible transmitter.Step 5: Lights respond to the replayed command without authentication.Step 6: Used to cause annoyance or simulate ghost activity.

Step 1: Use Rufus to create bootable USB with Windows PE.Step 2: Add auto-start keylogger EXE in startup folder.Step 3: Plug USB, reboot system into USB OS.Step 4: Keylogger installs silently on internal hard drive.Step 5: Remove USB and restart normally – keylogger stays active.

Step 1: Use SDR to capture light toggle signal (usually 315 or 433 MHz).Step 2: Label "light ON" and "light OFF" waveforms.Step 3: Replay "ON" multiple times during the night.Step 4: Light turns on, potentially alerting or annoying residents.Step 5: Demonstrate how replay can mimic human behavior.Step 6: Discuss use cases in red teaming and physical penetration tests.

Step 1: Use SDR to scan Zigbee frequency (2.4 GHz).Step 2: Capture ON command for the Zigbee-connected TV.Step 3: Save and isolate the Zigbee frame.Step 4: Replay during nighttime using HackRF One.Step 5: TV turns ON without user input.Step 6: Victim confused or annoyed.

Step 1: Use SDR to tune into the WiMAX downlink channel.Step 2: Configure GNU Radio to decode OFDMA symbols and extract data frames.Step 3: Use Wireshark with custom dissectors to analyze downlink traffic.Step 4: Reconstruct payloads like HTTP or DNS requests to understand user activity.Step 5: Log and document all unencrypted sessions for study.

Step 1: Use SET to craft a fake configuration file (autodiscover.xml or .mobileconfig for iOS).Step 2: Email the configuration file with a message like “Update your mail settings for improved security.”Step 3: On victim system, open the file and allow changes to email settings.Step 4: Email client is reconfigured to use attacker-controlled IMAP server.Step 5: Victim tries to log in, credentials are sent to attacker's server.Step 6: On attacker server (e.g., MailCatcher), credentials are logged.Step 7: Use them to access actual mail server or simulate compromise.

Step 1: Use SOIC8 clip and flashrom to dump original firmware. Step 2: Analyze firmware structure with binwalk. Step 3: Use Ghidra to identify key logic controlling Bluetooth data. Step 4: Modify data transmission routine to leak data to attacker-controlled app. Step 5: Save modified firmware and re-flash via flashrom -w firmware_mod.bin. Step 6: Power on device and verify altered behavior in controlled setup.

Step 1: Use Scapy or custom Python script to construct malformed SAE packets.Step 2: Inject crafted packets at the time of SAE key exchange using monitor mode.Step 3: Observe client or AP behavior — often results in software crash or authentication failure.Step 4: Repeatedly send malformed packets to disrupt service.Step 5: Use logs to confirm denial-of-service due to malformed SAE elements.

Step 1: Use Scapy to craft a beacon frame for a fake access point, advertising WPA3-SAE security.Step 2: Broadcast this frame using your wireless adapter in injection mode.Step 3: Set up a rogue AP using airbase-ng that only supports WPA2, but has the same SSID as advertised.Step 4: Deauthenticate clients from the real WPA3 AP using aireplay-ng.Step 5: Victim connects to your AP, thinking it is WPA3.Step 6: Capture the handshake and redirect DNS using dnsmasq for further exploitation.Step 7: Show how beacon manipulation tricks devices into insecure associations.

Step 1: Use Scapy to craft a packet with outer VLAN tag of attacker VLAN and inner tag of ICS VLAN.Step 2: Send it to the switch and see if forwarded.Step 3: Use Wireshark to monitor response.Step 4: If reply is seen, ICS VLAN is reachable.Step 5: Use follow-up tools (Nmap) to scan for services.

Step 1: Use Shodan to find exposed AQ sensor dashboards.Step 2: Login using default admin/admin credentials.Step 3: Modify sensor thresholds or inject false PM2.5 data.Step 4: Simulate pollution spike in report export.Step 5: Show how this affects ventilation decisions or health responses.Step 6: Logout and reset changes.

Step 1: Use Shodan to find printers with open SMTP ports. Step 2: Access internal web UI without login. Step 3: Configure outbound email settings with spoofed alerts@company.com. Step 4: Compose alert email about “Paper jam auto-refill billing”. Step 5: Send to finance or admin department. Step 6: Include PDF with embedded malicious script.

Step 1: Use Shodan to identify HMI panel with exposed remote monitoring API (e.g., port:443 product:"HMI Panel").Step 2: Send a GET request to retrieve API version (curl https://target-ip/api/version).Step 3: Use Postman to issue unauthenticated control commands (e.g., POST /api/control with body {"temp":100}).Step 4: Monitor if command executes remotely.Step 5: Repeat with various endpoints (e.g., /api/alarm_ack).Step 6: Document lack of token/session validation.Step 7: Evaluate severity of unauthenticated remote control.

Step 1: Use Shodan to locate exposed doorbells by vendor name.Step 2: Launch app or open IP in browser.Step 3: Use vendor’s default login (e.g., guest/guest).Step 4: Access real-time video feed or stored clips.Step 5: Highlight privacy implications and record steps for audit log.Step 6: Simulate breach report and logout.

Step 1: Use Shodan to locate smart meter with open HTTP interface.Step 2: Log in using default credentials (admin/energy123).Step 3: Modify meter readings or reset logs.Step 4: Export falsified usage report as PDF.Step 5: Explain potential for fraud or billing manipulation.Step 6: Demonstrate how attackers can mask real energy theft.

Step 1: Use Shodan to search for HMIs with open VNC ports (port:5900).Step 2: Identify IPs with manufacturer banners such as Siemens or Allen-Bradley.Step 3: Launch a VNC Viewer (like RealVNC or TightVNC) and try connecting to the target IP.Step 4: If prompted, try default credentials or empty password.Step 5: Upon successful connection, interact with the HMI interface—observe SCADA processes, try issuing test commands (e.g., toggle pump on/off).Step 6: Record any anomalies or safety risks resulting from control abuse.

Step 1: Use Shodan to search for exposed alarm system cloud interfaces.Step 2: Open one of the URLs in browser.Step 3: Use vendor’s default credentials (admin/alarm123).Step 4: Simulate disabling the motion sensor or arming/disarming remotely.Step 5: Log unauthorized access and explain potential burglary risks.Step 6: Show how many IoT alarms lack enforced password rotation.

Step 1: Use Shodan to search for exposed smart tank interfaces (e.g., search “Aquarium Controller port:80”).Step 2: Open one exposed IP in browser.Step 3: Try factory credentials (admin/aquarium123).Step 4: Access dashboard and change temperature to extreme values.Step 5: Simulate disabling filters or overfeeding.Step 6: Explain risks to aquatic life due to lack of access control.

Step 1: Use Shodan to search for smart bins (e.g., keyword: “smartbin status”).Step 2: Access the bin dashboard via public IP.Step 3: Try default credentials (admin/bin123).Step 4: Simulate triggering compactor remotely.Step 5: Schedule fake maintenance alerts.Step 6: Discuss disruption to waste management.

Step 1: Use Shodan.io to search for publicly exposed IP cameras.Step 2: Filter by brand (e.g., “Hikvision”, “Dahua”) to identify camera models.Step 3: Pick an IP and open it in a web browser to access its login page.Step 4: Use default credentials from public lists (e.g., admin/admin, root/12345).Step 5: Upon successful login, browse live feed or device settings.Step 6: Take screenshots for documentation and exit without modifying anything (educational ethics).

Step 1: Use Ubiqua to monitor Zigbee smart plug.Step 2: Wait until smart plug is turned ON by user.Step 3: Capture ON command.Step 4: Build a Python script using KillerBee to replay the packet.Step 5: Plug turns on as if user issued the command.Step 6: Repeat at odd hours to disturb user.

Step 1: Use VRFY over Telnet to get valid usernames like jane, itadmin, ceo. Step 2: Append domain to form emails (jane@target.com). Step 3: Visit target’s webmail portal (e.g., mail.target.com). Step 4: Try usernames with passwords like Welcome123, Company2024. Step 5: Log successful attempts and take screenshots. Step 6: Show how poor passwords + exposed users lead to compromise.

Step 1: Use WMI queries or PowerShell to inspect the ACPI DSDT table from Win32_ComputerSystem.Step 2: Search for strings like VBOX__, VMWARE__, or XEN__ inside the ACPI table.Step 3: If such identifiers are found, the malware assumes a virtual machine and exits.Step 4: Otherwise, malware proceeds to execute normally.Step 5: Compare real and virtual environments to note the signature.Step 6: Use hex viewers or ACPI parsers to simulate table differences in training.

Step 1: Use Wi-Fi analyzer to identify the cradle’s hotspot.Step 2: Connect to it using default Wi-Fi password (e.g., baby1234).Step 3: Open app and login with default admin credentials.Step 4: Simulate starting/stopping cradle rocking motion.Step 5: Demonstrate timing attacks (e.g., at odd hours).Step 6: Explain safety and sleep risks for infants.

Step 1: Use WinRAR to create archive secret.zip with confidential docs.Step 2: Use a tool or command to append it to a JPEG: copy /b photo.jpg + secret.zip combined.jpg.Step 3: Attach combined.jpg to Gmail.Step 4: Send it to personal email.Step 5: At home, extract ZIP from image using WinRAR.

Step 1: Use WinSCP to access HMI log folder via SMB or SFTP (if open).Step 2: Download log file (e.g., operation_log.txt).Step 3: Open with Notepad++, edit timestamped entries to fake operator actions.Step 4: Remove records of unauthorized access (e.g., "User guest issued command: pump off").Step 5: Save and upload modified log back to the system.Step 6: Restart logging service using PsExec to avoid detection.Step 7: Test system alarms to ensure logs reflect false state.

Step 1: Use Wireshark or Burp Suite to capture traffic from the IoT mobile app. Step 2: Identify API calls that control the device, such as POST /device/on. Step 3: Save the request with authentication header and payload. Step 4: Replay the same request using Postman after the session has expired. Step 5: Observe that the device still responds due to lack of nonce or session tokens. Step 6: Simulate how this allows an attacker to turn on/off devices repeatedly without credentials.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to analyze HMI interface requests and identify IP/port.Step 2: Clone interface with HTML and JavaScript using HTTrack or manually via browser inspection.Step 3: Serve clone via Flask on attacker's machine (e.g., flask run --host=192.168.1.50).Step 4: Change DNS records via spoofing or social engineering to redirect hmi.company.local to attacker’s clone.Step 5: Operator accesses fake HMI and enters commands.Step 6: Log actions and optionally forward them to real HMI to avoid detection.Step 7: Evaluate success in phishing control actions and training impact.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to capture FT handshake between client and original AP.Step 2: Extract the R0KH-ID field and mobility domain values from FT response.Step 3: Configure rogue AP (hostapd) to broadcast same SSID, R0KH-ID, and Mobility Domain ID.Step 4: Increase signal strength to lure the client to your rogue AP.Step 5: When the client roams, it trusts the fake R0KH ID and completes the FT handshake.Step 6: Capture user traffic or redirect to phishing content.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to capture HTTP traffic between HMI and server.Step 2: Filter for Set-Cookie headers or Authorization tokens.Step 3: Copy captured session token (e.g., JSESSIONID=XYZ).Step 4: Use Burp Suite to manually inject the token into new browser request.Step 5: Access authenticated interface without credentials.Step 6: Test control functionality (e.g., toggling outputs).Step 7: Validate if session expires or remains valid.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to capture Modbus traffic and identify a Unit ID (e.g., 0x05).Step 2: Craft Modbus responses using the same Unit ID.Step 3: Inject spoofed responses to overwrite actual data.Step 4: HMI accepts wrong responses thinking it’s from legit PLC.Step 5: Real PLC gets ignored due to mismatch timing.Step 6: Operator sees wrong process data.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to capture traffic between HMI and PLC to discover tag names (e.g., Tank_Level, Motor_Status).Step 2: Use AdvancedHMI to create a mock interface pointing to the PLC IP and tag names.Step 3: Manipulate tag values (e.g., set Tank_Level = 0) without triggering validation.Step 4: Observe if the HMI reflects tampered values without operator input.Step 5: Confirm if alarm logic is triggered or bypassed.Step 6: Log tag read/write permissions and note if authentication was required.Step 7: Evaluate potential for physical damage from logic abuse.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to gather 802.11r Information Elements (IEs) from the real AP.Step 2: Configure hostapd to mimic the exact FT capabilities.Step 3: Broadcast stronger signal to lure the client device.Step 4: Allow the FT reassociation to complete.Step 5: Intercept and relay all traffic or perform credential phishing.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to monitor and identify the gateway SSID of a QSM chat network.Step 2: Set up a rogue AP using PineAP or hostapd with the same SSID and stronger signal.Step 3: Wait for clients to connect, then assign them an IP from your own DHCP pool.Step 4: Forward traffic through a proxy while logging and analyzing key exchange behavior.Step 5: Redirect packets to a real gateway after key agreement to minimize detection.Step 6: Inject fake traffic or modify messages before relaying back.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to monitor real Modbus TCP traffic between HMI and PLC.Step 2: Identify the target PLC IP and the Function Code used to control machinery (e.g., Write Coil).Step 3: Use Scapy to craft a Modbus TCP packet with Function Code 5 and set output to 0 (OFF).Step 4: Spoof the source IP as the HMI to make the PLC think it is a legitimate shutdown command.Step 5: Send the packet to the PLC and observe the machinery halting operation.Step 6: Validate that operators are unaware of this spoofed event.

Step 1: Use Wireshark to monitor traffic on the network (e.g., in a test LAN).Step 2: Configure a test email client to connect using POP3 (port 110) without encryption.Step 3: Log in with valid credentials on the client.Step 4: In Wireshark, observe that username and password are clearly visible in the traffic.Step 5: Replay the credentials using a script or POP3 client to confirm full inbox access.Step 6: Use this method to demonstrate how attackers on the same network could capture credentials.

Step 1: Use Yard Stick One and KillerBee’s zbdump tool to sniff Zigbee packets near a smart garage door.Step 2: Wait for the homeowner to open the garage using their Zigbee remote/app.Step 3: Capture the "open" command in real time.Step 4: Save the command for replay.Step 5: Use the zbreplay tool to send the captured packet back to the garage door controller.Step 6: The garage door opens again without any user confirmation.Step 7: Demonstrate to learners how wireless home access can be compromised.

Step 1: Use Zigbee2MQTT on a Raspberry Pi to listen to Zigbee network.Step 2: Wait for legitimate user to set thermostat to 30°C.Step 3: Capture that command using Wireshark.Step 4: Export captured command as a binary file.Step 5: Replay the command using HackRF One.Step 6: Thermostat executes the fake request, heating the room unnecessarily.

Step 1: Use a Python script to encode commands in ultrasonic (18kHz–22kHz) range.Step 2: Bot listens via microphone and decodes instructions.Step 3: Audio command can be broadcast via speaker or YouTube video.Step 4: Bot decodes command and executes it.Step 5: Sends result via HTTP or logs locally.

Step 1: Use a Python script with microphone input (e.g., speech_recognition).Step 2: Set trigger phrase like “Start presentation”.Step 3: When phrase is detected, run file encryption function.Step 4: Victim speaks into mic on VM; trigger activates.Step 5: Script renames .docx and .png files.Step 6: Plays a ransom message via TTS speaker.

Step 1: Use a Wi-Fi card in monitor mode to capture SAE handshake packets.Step 2: Extract the captured handshake.Step 3: Use Dragonblood’s sae-partition.py to perform partial key derivation.Step 4: Combine this with hashcat to brute-force only feasible password partitions.Step 5: Log which passwords cause partial matches and narrow down the real key.

Step 1: Use a Wi-Fi sniffer to identify beacon patterns from QKD system’s control AP.Step 2: Launch a deauthentication attack to force reconnects from the QKD client device.Step 3: Use mdk3 or similar to broadcast fake beacon frames that mimic entanglement success triggers.Step 4: Respond to QKD handshake queries with pre-scripted success messages.Step 5: Modify local log files using Python scripts to insert timestamps and entangled bit info.Step 6: Let system proceed to key exchange phase with fabricated data.Step 7: Exfiltrate the forged logs for key recovery.

Step 1: Use a Z-Wave sniffer like UZB stick with Wireshark to monitor traffic between Z-Wave lock and controller.Step 2: Wait for a legitimate unlock command sent using S0.Step 3: Identify the payload and capture the frame.Step 4: Write a simple Python script or use replay tool to resend the same frame to the lock.Step 5: Lock interprets it as a valid unlock command since S0 lacks proper authentication of origin.Step 6: Gain access to physical location or demonstrate in a lab simulation.

Step 1: Use a bootkit builder to create a malicious bootloader. Step 2: Inject polymorphic code that modifies itself on reboot. Step 3: Replace original bootloader using USB/Live CD. Step 4: System boots from infected sector. Step 5: Rootkit hides malware and processes. Step 6: Code changes every boot cycle to evade disk signature scans. Step 7: Attacker maintains full hidden access.

Step 1: Use a compatible Wi-Fi card and Kali Linux.Step 2: Put Wi-Fi card into monitor mode using airmon-ng start wlan0.Step 3: Start hcxdumptool to capture PMKID from nearby routers with hcxdumptool -i wlan0mon -o pmkid.pcapng --enable_status=1.Step 4: Wait for a PMKID to be captured.Step 5: Convert file using hcxpcapngtool pmkid.pcapng -o pmkid_hash.txt.Step 6: Crack hash with hashcat -m 16800 pmkid_hash.txt wordlist.txt.

Step 1: Use a local blockchain environment like Ganache and Remix for testing smart contracts. Step 2: Deploy a vulnerable contract that has a withdraw function sending Ether to the caller before updating their balance. Step 3: Develop an attacker contract with a fallback or receive function. This special function automatically triggers when the contract receives Ether. Step 4: In the fallback/receive function, program the attacker contract to call back into the vulnerable contract’s withdraw function, creating a recursive call loop. Step 5: Fund the vulnerable contract with Ether to simulate real-world conditions. Step 6: From the attacker contract, initiate the attack by calling the vulnerable contract’s withdraw function. Step 7: When Ether is sent from the vulnerable contract to the attacker contract, the fallback/receive function triggers automatically. Step 8: This fallback function immediately calls the vulnerable contract’s withdraw again, before the vulnerable contract has updated the attacker’s balance. Step 9: This recursion continues, draining Ether repeatedly from the vulnerable contract. Step 10: The attacker gains more Ether than their deposited balance, effectively stealing funds. Step 11: To fix, ensure that the vulnerable contract updates the user’s balance before sending Ether. Use OpenZeppelin’s ReentrancyGuard to prevent reentrant calls. Step 12: Detection can be done by analyzing transaction traces for multiple nested calls involving fallback functions or by using smart contract security tools to find fallback-related reentrancy issues.

Step 1: Use a modified Dragonblood script to initiate SAE commit exchanges.Step 2: Introduce large delay intervals between packets using Linux’s tc command to simulate packet delay.Step 3: Send the commit message and hold back the confirm message for an extended period.Step 4: The access point will hold resources in memory waiting for confirmation.Step 5: Repeat this behavior from multiple spoofed MACs.Step 6: Log router behavior to demonstrate increased CPU or memory usage due to resource locks.

Step 1: Use a packet crafting tool like Scapy to forge group key handshake packets.Step 2: Inject them into the air during a key renewal phase.Step 3: The victim accepts the key reinstallation, resulting in a reset state.Step 4: Repeat the attack in intervals to prevent re-authentication.Step 5: Observe that the device cannot maintain a stable connection.

Step 1: Use a script to generate a list of random SSID names. Step 2: Feed the list to mdk3 in beacon flooding mode. Step 3: Beacon frames are broadcast with SSIDs like “FreeWiFi123”, “Public_WiFi_AB”, etc., changing every second. Step 4: Scanning clients show fluctuating SSID lists, making it hard to connect. Step 5: Monitor client-side behavior (battery drain, Wi-Fi failures).

Step 1: Use a script to generate random DevAddrs and payloadsStep 2: Configure 3+ LoRa nodes or SDRs to inject at high intervalStep 3: Monitor gateway CPU and log performance degradationStep 4: Observe packet drop rate and processing delaysStep 5: Correlate with system logs showing increased load

Step 1: Use a side-channel timing script on a local machine or Raspberry Pi.Step 2: Capture WPA3 handshake exchanges with a Wi-Fi adapter in monitor mode.Step 3: Time CPU cache responses during partial key computations.Step 4: Compare response times for multiple attempts to infer bits of the password.Step 5: Reconstruct the key using inferred timing data and offline brute-force techniques.

Step 1: Use a spectrum analyzer to identify the exact frequency band used by QSM devices (often in RF or optical spectrum).Step 2: Set up a narrowband RF jammer to target only the identified QSM channel.Step 3: Gradually increase jamming strength until packet loss occurs during key negotiation.Step 4: Observe behavior of QSM terminals—if improperly configured, they may revert to classical key exchange (e.g., RSA).Step 5: Once fallback is triggered, monitor for classical session keys and attempt MITM (man-in-the-middle) or passive interception.Step 6: Stop jamming intermittently to simulate unpredictable network failure.

Step 1: Use a telescope to align with the ground station receiving quantum signals from the satellite.Step 2: Fly drone to optimal injection height, avoiding LOS obstruction.Step 3: Emit single photons with pre-calculated polarization values aligned with the satellite’s modulation scheme.Step 4: Use GPS jammer to temporarily interfere with satellite sync timing.Step 5: Monitor classical channel to match Bob’s basis choices and inject suitable responses.Step 6: Collect accepted key bit sequences from reconciliation.Step 7: Exit flight path before satellite scan re-aligns.

Step 1: Use a test iPhone and jailbreak it using tools like Checkra1n (for educational use only).Step 2: Install Cydia and Filza file manager.Step 3: Use Cydia to install OpenSSH server on the phone.Step 4: From PC, connect to iPhone via SSH using default root credentials.Step 5: Write a simple bash script that collects SMS database, contact file, and location history.Step 6: Run the script via SSH and transfer data to PC.Step 7: Analyze what files were accessed and whether user detected it.

Step 1: Use a tool like G2Metamorph to write ransomware code that changes every time. Step 2: Obfuscate the ransomware using PyArmor. Step 3: Test it in a safe virtual machine environment. Step 4: Spread via USB, email, or cloud sharing link. Step 5: Once opened, it encrypts user files. Step 6: It rewrites its own code to look different. Step 7: It displays ransom message and hides traces.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng and airbase-ng to set up a rogue WPA2 AP using the same SSID as a WPA3 target.Step 2: Enable DHCP and fake DNS using dnsmasq.Step 3: Deauth real WPA3 AP using aireplay-ng.Step 4: Wait for victim to reconnect to your WPA2 AP thinking it is trusted.Step 5: Sniff traffic, redirect DNS, and perform man-in-the-middle attacks.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng to capture a valid WPA3 handshake.Step 2: Disconnect client using deauth packets.Step 3: Spoof an AP with same SSID and partial valid credentials.Step 4: Observe client reconnect attempts — if “Fast Transition” is enabled, it tries to reuse prior keys.Step 5: Inject known or predictable parts of handshake to compromise connection.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng to enable monitor mode on a Wi-Fi adapter. Step 2: Run mdk3 wlan0 b -f ssid_list.txt -s 100 where ssid_list.txt contains hundreds of fake SSID names. Step 3: Clients scanning for Wi-Fi see hundreds of fake networks, causing confusion. Step 4: APs may struggle to process excess management traffic. Step 5: Client connections may drop or fail due to beacon frame saturation.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng to enable monitor mode on adapter. Step 2: Launch a script (e.g., with scapy) to generate unique beacon frames every few milliseconds. Step 3: Each frame uses a random MAC address and SSID. Step 4: Loop continuously to fill beacon queues on target clients and APs. Step 5: Monitor CPU spikes and interface resets on affected devices.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng to enable monitor mode on multiple Wi-Fi interfaces (wlan0mon, wlan1mon, etc.). Step 2: Assign each interface a unique channel (1, 6, 11, etc.). Step 3: Use mdk4 on each interface to flood beacon frames with random SSIDs on assigned channels. Step 4: Monitor available networks on target device — expect over 100+ fake SSIDs spread across channels. Step 5: Attempt to connect to a legitimate AP; connection delays or failures will be observed due to spectrum congestion.

Step 1: Use airmon-ng to start monitor mode.Step 2: Use mdk4 wlan0mon d -c [channel] to jam the legitimate WPA3 AP.Step 3: Simultaneously, launch a rogue AP using hostapd broadcasting same SSID on WPA2.Step 4: Wait for clients to reconnect to the fake AP.Step 5: Start hcxdumptool to capture PMKID.Step 6: Convert to hash and crack using hashcat.Step 7: Optionally use captured key to try lateral movement.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to capture ongoing PQC-based handshake. Step 2: Identify cipher suite negotiation frame (e.g., RSN or vendor-specific element). Step 3: Use Scapy to craft a forged handshake initiation frame that includes legacy cipher suites (e.g., TKIP/AES). Step 4: Inject the forged frame using aireplay-ng. Step 5: Device interprets as preferred cipher and responds with fallback.Step 6: Record legacy handshake and attempt decryption. Step 7: Access encrypted traffic via cracked session key.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to identify SSID and BSSID of PQC-secured AP.Step 2: Clone SSID using hostapd but configure it with WPA2 only.Step 3: Boost signal strength using physical proximity or Wi-Fi amplifier.Step 4: Targeted clients automatically connect to stronger rogue AP.Step 5: Use Bettercap to intercept or inject traffic.Step 6: Launch phishing page using Fluxion to collect credentials.Step 7: Log all client activity.Step 8: Disconnect client after credential capture to prevent suspicion.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to identify device SSID and BSSID. Step 2: Capture traffic with Wireshark or airodump-ng. Step 3: Filter and extract OTA firmware packets. Step 4: Reassemble the captured data into a firmware image. Step 5: Use binwalk and Ghidra for reverse engineering.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to identify mesh routers with multiple SSIDs (one WPA3, one WPA2).Step 2: Set up hcxdumptool to listen near a child node operating in WPA2.Step 3: Wait for child nodes to reconnect or force re-authentication.Step 4: Capture the handshake and PMKID.Step 5: Convert .pcapng to hash using hcxpcapngtool.Step 6: Crack using hashcat and a common wordlist.Step 7: Use the cracked key to access the mesh’s backhaul traffic.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to passively monitor the airwaves and identify the corporate SSID (e.g., "CorpNet"). Step 2: Check for probe requests by laptops looking for “CorpNet” – this indicates auto-connect configuration. Step 3: Use mdk4 with b mode to broadcast fake beacon frames for “CorpNet” on a different channel. Step 4: Wait for corporate devices to connect to your fake SSID, mistaking it for their home network. Step 5: Record timestamps and device MACs to simulate client misbehavior or failed authentication attempts.

Step 1: Use airodump-ng to scan for dual-mode devices.Step 2: Capture handshake traffic and note MAC, vendor info, capabilities.Step 3: Use macchanger to spoof same MAC address.Step 4: Recreate device fingerprint using Scapy to mimic advertised protocols.Step 5: Connect to network as a legacy-compatible device.Step 6: Trigger fallback on access point side by broadcasting only legacy protocol support.Step 7: Start MITM session by intercepting data.Step 8: Exfiltrate login and config info.

Step 1: Use an Alfa Wi-Fi adapter and Kali Linux.Step 2: Put card into monitor mode.Step 3: Start hcxdumptool to capture handshakes with PMKIDs passively.Step 4: Wait until several devices attempt to connect.Step 5: Convert and crack the captured hashes using hashcat.

Step 1: Use an Android smartphone with NFC snooping app (e.g., NFC Tools or custom sniffing app).Step 2: Enable developer or root access to intercept nearby NFC/RFID scans.Step 3: Stand near passengers tapping cards (typically within 5cm range).Step 4: Record transaction data silently without user interaction.Step 5: Analyze captured information for card ID and system frequency.Step 6: Repeat to gather multiple scans from different cards.

Step 1: Use an IP scanner tool to find the IP address of the lighting hub.Step 2: Visit the IP in your browser.Step 3: Try default credentials like admin/light123.Step 4: If successful, simulate turning off lights in multiple rooms, changing light colors, or flashing them repeatedly.Step 5: Demonstrate how this could cause panic or interfere with routines.Step 6: Log events and show how attackers could use it for harassment.Step 7: Secure the system with a strong, new password.

Step 1: Use an RFID sniffer like Proxmark3 near a toll booth scanner.Step 2: Wait for a vehicle with an RFID tag (e.g., Fastag) to approach and trigger the gate.Step 3: Capture the signal emitted from the tag when it's read by the toll gate reader.Step 4: Save the waveform and note the vehicle ID encoded (if visible).Step 5: Move to a different toll booth or time, and replay the signal using SDR.Step 6: If the system doesn't use real-time validation, the gate opens without payment from the actual user.Step 7: In simulation, show how toll systems without server-side nonce checking are vulnerable.

Step 1: Use an RTL-SDR device to record raw RF signals from a lattice-PQ router or device.Step 2: Record signals during idle, regular, and encrypted transmissions.Step 3: Train an RNN to learn timing "signatures" of lattice crypto, focusing on millisecond-level jitter.Step 4: Compare live traffic against model to identify exact time of crypto usage.Step 5: Plan precise timing-based fault injection or key inference techniques.

Step 1: Use an SDR to monitor the wireless frequency of a PQ device (e.g., 2.4GHz band).Step 2: Record small frequency drifts during idle and heavy crypto operations (such as key exchange).Step 3: Train an AI model to associate specific drift patterns with specific PQ crypto algorithms or workloads.Step 4: Use real-time drift monitoring to infer when a key is being generated or used.Step 5: Trigger active surveillance or RF injection during those identified windows.

Step 1: Use binwalk to extract file system from firmware.bin. Step 2: Mount the extracted file system with chroot or emulate with QEMU. Step 3: Browse /etc/ folder for misconfigurations (e.g., weak SSH keys). Step 4: Use Ghidra to reverse engineer voice processing binaries. Step 5: Test hardcoded cloud connection logic in controlled sandbox.

Step 1: Use binwalk to extract multiple partitions. Step 2: Isolate recovery partition and mount with loop device. Step 3: Check for /etc/init.d or recovery shell scripts. Step 4: Discover root shell opened without authentication. Step 5: Use Ghidra to confirm bootloader interaction logic.

Step 1: Use binwalk to extract root filesystem and kernel. Step 2: Identify CPU architecture (file vmlinux, e.g., ARM). Step 3: Set up QEMU for the matching architecture. Step 4: Boot firmware using emulated serial or network interface. Step 5: Observe services, logs, and network behavior. Step 6: Inject commands via netcat or serial shell to test security posture.

Step 1: Use default or leaked RDP credentials to log into target system.Step 2: Transfer and run keylogger EXE remotely.Step 3: Hide the application from task manager.Step 4: Set it to auto-start with system.Step 5: Receive logs over email or cloud dashboard.

Step 1: Use dig MX domain.com or MXToolbox to find all MX entries.Step 2: Note the backup MX (with higher priority number).Step 3: Connect to the backup MX using Telnet or SMTP testing tool.Step 4: Attempt to deliver email bypassing normal SPF/DKIM checks.Step 5: If backup MX accepts messages without proper filtering, attacker can deliver spam or phishing.Step 6: Confirm delivery via email logs or receiving account.

Step 1: Use dig TXT _dmarc.domain.com to retrieve the DMARC record. Step 2: Confirm the policy is p=none, meaning no enforcement. Step 3: Use spoofemail.io or sendmail to spoof an internal address. Step 4: Send spoofed email to a test recipient. Step 5: Check that spoofed email arrives without warning. Step 6: Demonstrate how attacker can use this for phishing or fraud.

Step 1: Use dig TXT default._domainkey.domain.com to check if DKIM is enabled. Step 2: If no DKIM record, craft email with forged headers using sendmail. Step 3: Send the email with manipulated From, Reply-To, and Subject headers. Step 4: Receive the email and verify it arrived without DKIM failure warning. Step 5: Analyze how forged email appears legitimate in inbox. Step 6: Show how attackers exploit this for BEC or phishing.

Step 1: Use dig TXT domain.com and look for include:unsecure3rdparty.com.Step 2: Check that the included domain has +all or loose IP validation.Step 3: Use spoofing tools to send email from attacker@domain.com using spoofed IP.Step 4: Email gets SPF PASS due to the included record.Step 5: Use this to demonstrate how trusting 3rd-party SPF records can backfire.

Step 1: Use dig TXT domain.com to view the SPF record. Step 2: Look for v=spf1 +all or includes like include:someuntrusted.com. Step 3: Use sendmail or online spoofing tools to craft a spoofed email as admin@domain.com from attacker IP. Step 4: Send spoofed email to a test recipient. Step 5: Use EmailHeaderAnalyzer to confirm SPF passed due to misconfig. Step 6: Demonstrate how an attacker can impersonate internal users.

Step 1: Use dirb or gobuster to brute-force HMI web directories (/backup/, /config/).Step 2: Locate downloadable .bak, .zip, or .conf files.Step 3: Use wget to download files locally.Step 4: Run strings or open in Notepad++ to extract hardcoded passwords or IPs.Step 5: Attempt login with credentials on real HMI interface.Step 6: Modify configuration or alter HMI project using restored data.Step 7: Document if backup includes SSH keys or PLC comms info.

Step 1: Use firmware API or UART to write known data blocks to flash. Step 2: Time the duration for each write using a stopwatch script. Step 3: Compare timing differences between encrypted and plaintext blocks. Step 4: Infer if the block contains secrets or dummy padding. Step 5: Map out memory layout and sensitive zones.

Step 1: Use free online SMS spoofing services to send a message from “Apple”.Step 2: Message content: “Your iCloud access has been disabled. Login here: [short URL]”.Step 3: The link redirects to a cloned Apple login page.Step 4: Set up proxy backend to capture auth token post-login.Step 5: Victim logs in on phone.Step 6: Token is harvested and stored.Step 7: Attacker logs in to iCloud dashboard without password.

Step 1: Use hciconfig to check your Bluetooth adapter. Step 2: Change your Bluetooth MAC to a trusted device's using bdaddr tool. Step 3: Use btmgmt to make your spoofed adapter discoverable. Step 4: Send pairing request to target using the spoofed MAC. Step 5: Observe target behavior and whether it connects automatically.

Step 1: Use hcitool lescan to find BLE bulbs in vicinity. Step 2: Connect to bulb using gatttool. Step 3: Discover services and find RGB control handle. Step 4: Inject new color value by writing to the RGB characteristic (e.g., char-write-cmd 0x0034 ff0000 for red). Step 5: Light changes color or toggles state without owner action. Step 6: Repeat with flashing pattern to cause disruption.

Step 1: Use hostapd multi-BSSID config to spoof multiple known SSIDs.Step 2: Assign different MACs to each (via virtual interface).Step 3: Wait for different clients to auto-connect.Step 4: Run hcxdumptool and collect multiple PMKIDs.Step 5: Convert and crack all collected hashes.Step 6: Document which SSIDs were most vulnerable.Step 7: Rotate fake SSIDs over time for testing.

Step 1: Use hping3 --icmp -c 1 -a 192.168.1.1 -d 120 --spoof 192.168.1.1 192.168.1.255 to broadcast ping.Step 2: Wait for replies from devices.Step 3: Use tcpdump to log responses.Step 4: Identify live ICS systems by source IPs.Step 5: Document for follow-up scans.

Step 1: Use hping3 -S -p 502 --rand-source [target IP] to test Modbus port with spoofed IPs (Tool: hping3).Step 2: Run nmap -p 502,20000,44818 --reason and observe response codes (Tool: Nmap).Step 3: Based on filtered, open

Step 1: Use inline assembly in C++ to execute the RDTSC instruction before and after a known task (e.g., loop over 10,000 iterations).Step 2: Calculate the delta (end - start ticks).Step 3: If the delta is too large for a simple task, it could indicate hypervisor interference.Step 4: If time distortion is detected, the malware exits silently.Step 5: On real hardware, this deviation is absent, and malware continues.Step 6: Analyze multiple iterations to reduce false positives.

Step 1: Use ipconfig or ifconfig to find attacker's IP and subnet.Step 2: Use nmap -sn 192.168.1.0/24 to identify active hosts including HMI and PLC.Step 3: Launch Bettercap with sudo bettercap -iface eth0.Step 4: Use Bettercap commands to spoof ARP for HMI and PLC (set arp.spoof.targets 192.168.1.10,192.168.1.20 → arp.spoof on).Step 5: Enable packet sniffer in Bettercap (net.sniff on).Step 6: Observe captured packets in Wireshark; filter by Modbus/TCP or HTTP.Step 7: Extract credentials, process values, or command messages for further misuse.

Step 1: Use macchanger to spoof the BSSID of the target WPA3 AP.Step 2: Use hostapd to launch a WPA2 AP using same SSID and spoofed BSSID.Step 3: Clients may auto-connect to the stronger/faster signal.Step 4: Capture PMKID using hcxdumptool.Step 5: Crack hash as usual.Step 6: Use key to monitor network, or pivot.Step 7: Document client behavior for study.

Step 1: Use magnifier to read part numbers and manufacturer logos on chips. Step 2: Search datasheets online using part number (e.g., “W25Q64 datasheet”). Step 3: Confirm pinout and voltage ratings. Step 4: Use this info to plan safe probing or dump methods.

Step 1: Use mdk3 to broadcast fake SSIDs with names like “Free_Public_WiFi”. Step 2: Remove encryption flags from beacon frames to make them appear open. Step 3: Optionally use Wifiphisher to redirect users to phishing pages once they connect. Step 4: Wait for victims to auto-connect or manually connect. Step 5: Analyze traffic or perform further phishing exploitation.

Step 1: Use microscope and hot air gun to remove eMMC from board. Step 2: Solder it onto a test breakout board. Step 3: Connect to eMMC reader and dump content. Step 4: Use binwalk to extract bootloader, kernel, and file system. Step 5: Reverse engineer vulnerable binaries using Ghidra.

Step 1: Use mobile phone to discreetly take photo of screen or printed doc.Step 2: Use an OCR app (like Adobe Scan or Google Lens) to convert photo into text.Step 3: Copy the text and paste into Gmail.Step 4: Send to external address.Step 5: Delete photo and email after confirmation.

Step 1: Use multiple sniffers to simultaneously capture Wi-Fi, BLE, and Zigbee traffic in a PQ test environment.Step 2: Log time, source device ID, and packet counts from each protocol into a central CSV.Step 3: Feed this data into a graph AI model that links devices and actions (e.g., “Device A sends Zigbee before Wi-Fi PQ key exchange”).Step 4: From graph relationships, AI finds repeating behavioral sequences (e.g., 8 AM crypto burst, 5 PM logout).Step 5: Attacker uses schedule predictions to time future attacks or network probing.

Step 1: Use nRF Connect or hcitool to discover MAC of nearby tracker.Step 2: Clone MAC using btspoof and set device name to match tracker.Step 3: Use BLEPeripheral (Android) to mimic services (e.g., HeartRate, Steps Count).Step 4: Broadcast spoofed data during app sync window.Step 5: Open target app on another device and allow data sync.Step 6: Confirm injection by checking manipulated step count or vitals.Step 7: Reset all data post simulation.

Step 1: Use nc targetdomain.com 25 or telnet to connect to SMTP port. Step 2: Read the server banner, e.g., 220 mail.domain.com ESMTP Postfix 3.1.2. Step 3: Note hostname, software, and version info. Step 4: Use version info in CVE databases to identify known exploits. Step 5: Document how misconfigured banners help attackers with reconnaissance. Step 6: Simulate scanning multiple email servers to demonstrate scale.

Step 1: Use nmap --script http-title -p 80,443 192.168.0.0/24.Step 2: Look for page titles like FactoryTalk View, WinCC Login.Step 3: Run WhatWeb to fingerprint CMS or technologies used.Step 4: If accessible, screenshot login page and vendor details.Step 5: Use results for social engineering or targeted password spraying.

Step 1: Use nmap -p 21 192.168.0.0/24 --script ftp-anon.Step 2: If anonymous login is allowed, connect via FileZilla or command line FTP.Step 3: List directory contents and look for files like firmware.hex, config.ini, or project.alien.Step 4: Download sample configs and inspect for hardcoded passwords.Step 5: Determine ICS function of the host from directory naming.

Step 1: Use nmap -p 25 targetdomain.com to check SMTP port. Step 2: Connect via telnet targetdomain.com 25. Step 3: Type HELO attacker.com to initiate session. Step 4: Run VRFY command like VRFY admin, VRFY john, VRFY mary. Step 5: If the server responds with “User exists”, note it down. Step 6: Compile a list of valid usernames for later attacks (e.g., brute-force or phishing).

Step 1: Use nmap -p 445 --script smb-enum-services [IP].Step 2: If SMB allows null or weak authentication, collect list of running services.Step 3: Look for ICS software (e.g., Siemens, Rockwell, Wonderware) in service names.Step 4: Identify outdated or insecure services for later exploitation.Step 5: Document host, services, and possible role in ICS topology.

Step 1: Use nmap to scan for port 25 on the target domain to check for SMTP service. Step 2: Use telnet targetdomain.com 25 to connect to the SMTP server. Step 3: Type HELO attacker.com and then MAIL FROM:<attacker@attacker.com>. Step 4: Type RCPT TO:<victim@somewhere.com>. If accepted, it's an open relay. Step 5: Type DATA and enter a phishing message. Step 6: Send the message and exit using . followed by QUIT. Step 7: Observe that the email is delivered from the victim’s server.

Step 1: Use nslookup -type=mx target.com to find the mail server for the domain. Step 2: Use Nmap to confirm port 25 is open: nmap -p 25 mail.target.com. Step 3: Connect to the SMTP server using Telnet: telnet mail.target.com 25. Step 4: Type HELO attacker.test and wait for server response. Step 5: Enter a list of VRFY commands like VRFY john, VRFY finance, VRFY hr, one at a time. Step 6: Observe server responses: if it replies with 250 or User OK, it confirms the user exists. Step 7: Document all positive matches and note down which aliases are valid for further abuse (phishing or brute force).

Step 1: Use physical access or jamming to force a reset of the Z-Wave hub. Step 2: Start Wireshark and monitor all Z-Wave frames. Step 3: Begin spoofed pairing request using PC Controller with S0 mode only. Step 4: When hub accepts, note the exposed key in the pairing logs. Step 5: Use this key to intercept traffic and replay ON/OFF or sensor commands. Step 6: Repeat for all connected devices to slowly compromise the network.

Step 1: Use proxy to intercept firmware update API from mobile app. Step 2: Discover that the URL allows enumeration (e.g., GET /firmware/list). Step 3: Download multiple firmware files. Step 4: Extract them using binwalk. Step 5: Compare versions and identify security changes or vulnerabilities.

Step 1: Use psutil.virtual_memory().total to check total RAM.Step 2: If size < 3GB, assume VM.Step 3: If ≥ 4GB, assume physical machine.Step 4: Log result and adjust behavior accordingly.Step 5: Run in sandbox VM with 2GB and real system with 8GB for testing.Step 6: Show students how changing VM RAM alters execution.

Step 1: Use pyautogui.size() to get screen resolution.Step 2: If screen resolution is ≤ 1024x768, assume VM or sandbox.Step 3: If resolution is ≥ 1920x1080, proceed.Step 4: Use PIL to save screenshot for inspection.Step 5: Run malware in different resolution environments.Step 6: Compare execution behaviors.

Step 1: Use reconnaissance to find HMI login portals over HTTP.Step 2: Clone the interface using tools like SEToolkit’s website cloner.Step 3: Host the fake HMI on a local Apache server (e.g., http://192.168.1.100/hmi).Step 4: Perform ARP spoofing with MITMProxy to redirect internal HMI traffic to attacker’s server.Step 5: Wait for an operator to access the fake portal and enter credentials.Step 6: Capture login details, use them to access real HMI panel, then try issuing process-altering commands.

Step 1: Use scapy to craft beacon frames with varying beacon intervals. Step 2: Randomize MAC addresses and SSID names. Step 3: Send beacon frames every few milliseconds, but with time jitter to bypass simple detection tools. Step 4: Observe Wi-Fi scanners and client logs for instability. Step 5: Record traffic with Wireshark to analyze beacon timing patterns.
Step 1: Use special Write-Once USB or controller chip. Step 2: Copy files onto it – malware or payload. Step 3: On use, USB erases itself or burns NAND. Step 4: Prevents forensic analysis.
Step 1: Use steghide to embed payload (like script) inside an image. Step 2: Store image on USB. Step 3: Victim opens image unaware. Step 4: Script extracts hidden data and executes it.

Step 1: Use the Fing app on your phone to find the IP address of the water heater.Step 2: Open a browser and enter the IP (e.g., http://192.168.1.60) to access the heater’s admin panel.Step 3: Try default credentials like admin/heater123 or admin/admin.Step 4: If successful, navigate to the temperature control section.Step 5: Simulate increasing the temperature to the maximum level (e.g., 75°C), or change scheduled timings.Step 6: Discuss the danger of burns or energy waste caused by unauthorized access.Step 7: Reset all settings and emphasize the importance of strong passwords.

Step 1: Use tool like Steghide or Audacity with plugin.Step 2: Embed confidential.txt into meeting.wav file.Step 3: Attach WAV file to email labeled “Meeting Notes”.Step 4: Send to personal address.Step 5: Extract at home using Steghide command.

Step 1: Use tool to bind ransomware to “song.mp3.exe”.Step 2: Set icon to match Windows Media Player.Step 3: Place it in Downloads and simulate clicking it.Step 4: On click, file runs and encrypts Music folder.Step 5: Displays ransom note as audio file using mplay32.exe.

Step 1: Use tools like MXToolbox to test if the SMTP server allows relaying. Step 2: Connect via Telnet to the SMTP server (port 25). Step 3: Run HELO attackerdomain.com. Step 4: Run VRFY root, VRFY ceo, VRFY webmaster. Step 5: Server responses confirm valid users. Step 6: The attacker saves this list for future phishing attacks. Step 7: Combine enumeration results with spam relay to simulate real-world abuse.

Step 1: User executes malware disguised as a PDF reader installer.Step 2: Malware uses VBScript to open Outlook COM interface.Step 3: Creates a rule in Outlook: “Forward all emails with attachments to attacker@shady.biz”.Step 4: Rule executes silently as Outlook runs.Step 5: Malware ensures rule is recreated on reboot.

Step 1: User installs chat app called “QuickTalk” for private messaging.Step 2: App runs and creates a hidden service.Step 3: Rootkit hides that service and creates a reverse shell.Step 4: Attacker remotely accesses system any time.Step 5: No visible app remains, only hidden processes.

Step 1: Using OSINT, the attacker finds that target.com uses a mail smarthost: smtp.smartrelay.target.com. Step 2: From a VPN, attacker connects via Telnet: telnet smtp.smartrelay.target.com 25. Step 3: Sends HELO fakeorg.com. Step 4: Issues VRFY commands for known or guessed users like VRFY jsmith, VRFY marketing, VRFY hradmin. Step 5: Server returns user existence confirmations (e.g., 250 OK <jsmith@target.com>). Step 6: Attacker collects valid users, then disconnects and rotates to another IP to avoid detection.

Step 1: Using a Linux laptop or Raspberry Pi, run hciconfig to verify the Bluetooth adapter.Step 2: Scan nearby devices using hcitool scan to find the actual car audio system (e.g., “TOYOTA_AUDIO” with MAC).Step 3: Change your adapter’s Bluetooth name and MAC to match the car using tools like btspoof.Step 4: Make the spoofed device discoverable.Step 5: When a phone in the vicinity tries to reconnect (thinking it’s the car), accept the connection request.Step 6: Immediately stream a pre-recorded voice message like “Your car software needs updating. Visit xyz.com.”Step 7: Monitor whether the user responds (e.g., taps the link or reacts).Step 8: Disconnect and reset adapter identity after simulation.

Step 1: Victim clicks link from an Instagram giveaway message.Step 2: Redirected to a site that asks to “verify with a setup tool”.Step 3: Setup installs a Trojan.Step 4: RAT activates, allowing attacker access to photos and credentials.Step 5: Victim unaware as system behaves normally.

Step 1: Victim clicks on a script file or malicious shortcut Step 2: Script decodes Base64-encoded string Step 3: It executes the decoded PowerShell in memory Step 4: Malware starts recording keystrokes or stealing data Step 5: No visible file or alert is shown

Step 1: Victim downloads “Free Antivirus Pro” from an ad.Step 2: Grants permission during install.Step 3: RAT starts running in background.Step 4: Attacker gains access to mic, camera, calls, etc.Step 5: App shows fake “No Virus Found” alerts to avoid suspicion.

Step 1: Victim finds a tool claiming to generate secure BTC wallets.Step 2: Tool shows random keys but installs RAT behind.Step 3: Attacker waits for any crypto activity.Step 4: Wallet data and clipboard content is stolen.Step 5: Funds get drained without user's notice.

Step 1: Victim gets a USB or email with "Resume.lnk" Step 2: Clicks the shortcut, which runs hidden command Step 3: Shortcut launches PowerShell silently Step 4: PowerShell runs code in memory to download malware Step 5: No file is dropped, malware stays in RAM

Step 1: Victim installs a browser extension claiming to block ads Step 2: Extension runs background JS script silently Step 3: Script contacts attacker server for payload Step 4: Payload is loaded directly into browser memory Step 5: Victim's data is stolen in real-time

Step 1: Victim logs into webmail interface vulnerable to XSS.Step 2: Attacker sends a malicious email containing embedded JavaScript.Step 3: Script runs when email is opened and copies message content.Step 4: Auto-triggers client-side SMTP request or uses hidden form to resend the message.Step 5: Message is resent to attacker-controlled address or target recipient.Step 6: Victim is unaware replay occurred as email was sent silently.Step 7: Attacker harvests message history for phishing.

Step 1: Victim looks for “free resume templates”.Step 2: Attacker site offers a DOCX file with macros.Step 3: Victim enables macros to edit template.Step 4: Macro launches background RAT installer.Step 5: Attacker gains remote access silently.

Step 1: Victim opens HTML file claiming to be from bank Step 2: Script runs in browser and loads obfuscated JS Step 3: JS collects browser data and sends to attacker Step 4: No file is saved; everything is memory-based Step 5: Attacker uses credentials for fraud

Step 1: Victim opens PowerPoint from email Step 2: Clicks a slide that contains an action trigger Step 3: The action silently launches PowerShell Step 4: PowerShell loads malware from a remote site into memory Step 5: Attacker controls the system remotely

Step 1: Victim opens a script creating a temporary virtual drive Step 2: Script mounts virtual drive in memory (RAM) Step 3: Malware is loaded and executed from this drive Step 4: No files are written to real disk Step 5: After restart, nothing remains

Step 1: Victim opens an old-looking Excel file Step 2: XLM macro runs hidden PowerShell command Step 3: PowerShell downloads malware and runs it in memory Step 4: File remains clean, no signature found Step 5: Malware exfiltrates system info

Step 1: Victim opens banking app with NFC payment enabled. Step 2: Attacker’s phone scans NFC field from a close distance (e.g., in a crowded metro). Step 3: Relay software sends real-time data to a rooted emulator on a laptop. Step 4: Emulator uses the token to initiate a tap-to-pay transaction. Step 5: Transaction is completed without victim noticing.

Step 1: Victim opens fake “Help.chm” file Step 2: File silently executes VBScript Step 3: VBScript launches PowerShell hidden window Step 4: PowerShell loads and runs malware in memory Step 5: No visible file remains, but system is compromised

Step 1: Victim opens file named “tracking.hta” thinking it’s shipment info Step 2: File runs VBScript with hidden PowerShell Step 3: Script downloads and executes malware in RAM Step 4: Malware keylogs or opens a backdoor Step 5: HTA file deletes itself

Step 1: Victim opens malicious Word file Step 2: Macro downloads DLL as a byte stream Step 3: PowerShell reflectively injects DLL into memory Step 4: DLL runs keylogger or RAT silently Step 5: Malware exits memory after task

Step 1: Victim receives a .vbs attachment in an email titled "Salary Info" Step 2: Victim double-clicks the script Step 3: Script launches WSH and runs PowerShell commands Step 4: Malware code is injected directly into memory Step 5: Malware connects to attacker's server

Step 1: Victim receives a calendar invite for “Project Sync Meeting”.Step 2: Email includes ZIP with “Agenda.exe” pretending to be a document.Step 3: Victim opens the file.Step 4: RAT is installed and connects to C2 server.Step 5: Attacker observes through camera and steals meeting data.

Step 1: Victim receives an email with stylized signature Step 2: Email client auto-renders the signature Step 3: Hidden script triggers a background HTTP call Step 4: Payload loads in memory and opens backdoor Step 5: Victim is unaware while system is monitored

Step 1: Victim receives an image (e.g., “teamphoto.jpg”) Step 2: A script runs and reads hidden code from image pixels Step 3: Extracted code is passed to PowerShell Step 4: Code runs directly in memory Step 5: Malware communicates with command server

Step 1: Victim runs a "Productivity Booster.exe" made with AHK Step 2: Script loads a PowerShell command directly Step 3: Keylogger module loads in RAM Step 4: Logs keystrokes silently Step 5: Sends data over the internet without saving logs

Step 1: Victim runs file disguised as a game Step 2: MSBuild runs embedded malicious code Step 3: PowerShell loads crypto miner into memory Step 4: Miner uses CPU power silently in background Step 5: System becomes slow; no file found on disk

Step 1: Victim searches for free HD movie downloads.Step 2: Attacker-hosted site offers a “movie player setup”.Step 3: Victim downloads and installs the file.Step 4: Trojan installs and connects to attacker.Step 5: Attacker can now access webcam and files.

Step 1: Victim visits a compromised blog or news site Step 2: Hidden iframe loads malicious JavaScript from another server Step 3: JS checks for vulnerable browser version Step 4: Exploit injects malware into browser memory Step 5: Attacker gains control via command server

Step 1: Victim visits a compromised or malicious website Step 2: Hidden exploit kit scans browser and OS for known vulnerabilities Step 3: If vulnerable, JavaScript exploits browser to run shellcode in memory Step 4: Malware code is executed directly without downloading a file Step 5: Attacker gains remote access or data exfiltration

Step 1: Victim visits a compromised website.Step 2: Site shows a popup: “Flash Player Outdated – Update Now”.Step 3: Victim downloads and installs the file.Step 4: Trojan silently installs and gives remote access to attacker.Step 5: Attacker uses system without alerting user.

Step 1: Victim wants to activate Windows for free.Step 2: Downloads “KMSAuto” from cracked software site.Step 3: Activator runs, says "Windows Activated".Step 4: RAT starts silently and sets persistence.Step 5: Attacker gains admin access to the system.

Step 1: Victim wears a fitness band (e.g., Fitbit) with Bluetooth turned on. It’s not paired to any phone. Step 2: Attacker walks nearby and runs blueborne-scanner to detect BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) devices. Step 3: Using hcitool lescan, attacker identifies the MAC address and confirms the device type. Step 4: Launches a crafted BLE exploit script to send malformed Bluetooth packets using gatttool. Step 5: The device responds, giving unauthorized access to sync data, steps count, and allows editing records (e.g., fake calories).

Step 1: Visit a "share with a friend" form on a marketing site. Step 2: In the name or subject input, inject: Hello%0ASubject: Urgent! Reset Your Password Now. Step 3: Intercept and modify request using ZAP Proxy. Step 4: Observe how recipient gets an email with custom subject, mimicking a legitimate service. Step 5: Use it to simulate a phishing link.

Step 1: Visit a gym that uses RFID-based smart lockers for users to secure personal items. Step 2: Observe users who leave their RFID locker bands or cards on the bench while using the equipment. Step 3: Bring a concealed Flipper Zero device or small RFID reader inside a gym bag.Step 4: While pretending to sit nearby or access your own locker, scan the unattended RFID band or card from a few centimeters away.Step 5: The Flipper Zero automatically detects and logs the RFID UID.Step 6: Store the captured UID in a text file or internal memory of the device.Step 7: Later simulate cloning the UID onto a blank RFID key using an emulator for lab simulation of locker access bypass.

Step 1: Visit a website with a "Forgot Password" feature. Step 2: Intercept the request using ZAP Proxy or Burp Suite. Step 3: Replace the email field with: victim@example.com%0ABCC:all-users@example.org%0ASubject:Free%20Crypto. Step 4: Submit and trigger email flood or mass spam. Step 5: Capture the resulting emails using Mailtrap to confirm spam delivery.

Step 1: Visit alarm help page (e.g., http://hmi/help.php?file=alarm1.txt).Step 2: Modify URL to read OS files (file=../../../../etc/passwd).Step 3: Use Burp Suite repeater to automate path traversal attempts.Step 4: If successful, retrieve configuration, password files, or logs.Step 5: Set up local HTTP server with crafted HTML and include script call (<iframe src="...">).Step 6: Use social engineering to trick operator into visiting link.Step 7: Document exploited paths and file exposure level.

Step 1: Visit random blog/website hosting malicious ad.Step 2: Without clicking anything, code runs in background.Step 3: Exploit finds browser weakness and downloads rootkit.Step 4: Rootkit installs with low-level privileges.Step 5: Attacker can control browser and redirect to phishing sites.

Step 1: Visit router support site and download recovery firmware .img. Step 2: Use binwalk to identify compressed filesystems inside the image. Step 3: Extract the filesystem with binwalk -e firmware.img. Step 4: Use Firmware Mod Kit to mount and modify the image. Step 5: Explore /etc/shadow and /etc/passwd for hardcoded credentials. Step 6: Analyze services and binaries in /bin, /sbin using Ghidra. Step 7: Create a simulation of vulnerable firmware in sandboxed VM.

Step 1: Visit suspicious website showing “Browser Outdated” warning.Step 2: Click on “Update Now” button.Step 3: Download and install fake browser update.Step 4: Installer installs a rootkit instead.Step 5: Rootkit disables browser security settings.

Step 1: Visually identify test points marked as TP1, TP2, etc. Step 2: Use multimeter in continuity mode to trace where they connect. Step 3: Probe with logic analyzer to detect signals. Step 4: If signal is UART/SPI/I2C, connect appropriate tools. Step 5: Use decoded data or inject custom signal.

Step 1: Wait for a quiet time when the security room is unattended. Step 2: Enter the room using general staff access. Step 3: Plug in a USB drive into the DVR/NVR device. Step 4: Copy recent security footage. Step 5: Leave without changing anything visibly.

Step 1: Wait for a team to leave after a meeting. Step 2: Check if laptop is still logged in or unlocked. Step 3: Access project folders, emails, or chats. Step 4: Email files to self or copy them to USB. Step 5: Close everything and walk away.

Step 1: Wait for user to lock system but leave session active. Step 2: Plug in HID USB programmed to press Win key, type commands to disable lock screen or reset password. Step 3: Run payload or exfiltrate files.

Step 1: Wait near a user while they unlock a smart RF-based door lock.Step 2: Record the RF burst using HackRF and URH.Step 3: Save and tag the signal for replay.Step 4: Return to the door when user is away.Step 5: Replay the signal and the door unlocks.Step 6: If the lock doesn’t use rolling code, attack succeeds.

Step 1: Wait near loading dock or delivery entry. Step 2: Walk in with real delivery crew carrying a small box. Step 3: Act like you belong, avoid eye contact. Step 4: Enter restricted area like server room or office floor. Step 5: Place a USB device or observe activities.

Step 1: Wait near office printer (pretend to collect your print). Step 2: Look at the tray or internal memory print queue. Step 3: Take confidential papers left behind or uncollected. Step 4: Optionally print again from printer history. Step 5: Photograph or store them for misuse.

Step 1: Wait outside the server room until someone with access opens it. Step 2: Follow behind them (tailgating) without a badge. Step 3: Once inside, unplug a server or switch to cause outage. Step 4: Exit without leaving any visible trace.

Step 1: Wait until no one is nearby (e.g., during break).Step 2: Plug in a personal USB drive into office computer.Step 3: Press Windows + E to open File Explorer.Step 4: Go to important folders like "Documents", "Shared", or "Finance".Step 5: Select and right-click "Copy" on key files (e.g., budget.xlsx).Step 6: Navigate to USB drive and right-click "Paste".Step 7: Wait for files to copy and then click "Safely Remove Hardware" to eject.Step 8: Pocket the USB and leave.

Step 1: Wait until the target leaves their laptop on and unattended (e.g., restroom break). Step 2: Ensure screen is unlocked or asleep. Step 3: Grab the laptop and place in a bag or box. Step 4: Leave the building quickly. Step 5: Use the stolen laptop to access company data from outside.
Step 1: Waits for area to be empty. Step 2: Says voice command: “Send email to…”, “Unlock door” etc. Step 3: Device executes it due to poor config. Step 4: Logs/data are transmitted.

Step 1: Waits for coworker to leave desk with password manager still unlocked.Step 2: Opens password manager extension.Step 3: Navigates to “Settings” or “Export Passwords”.Step 4: Exports entire vault to .csv.Step 5: Saves to USB or sends via email.

Step 1: Waits for coworker to leave workstation with browser still logged in.Step 2: Opens DevTools with F12, navigates to Application tab → LocalStorage.Step 3: Copies session token string.Step 4: On their own machine, uses tools like Postman or curl to replay session.Step 5: Accesses application with the same permissions as the user without password.

Step 1: Walk around during breaks or cleaning time. Step 2: Look for any sticky notes on desks or under keyboards. Step 3: Take a photo using your phone quickly and quietly. Step 4: Use the passwords later to log into systems. Step 5: Clear browser history after use.

Step 1: Walk by a target’s desk during lunch or restroom break. Step 2: Turn on NFC scanning on your phone. Step 3: Tap near the laptop (many have NFC for badges or pairing). Step 4: Capture any device handshake data (device name, ID, etc.). Step 5: Use it for profiling or spoofing attempts.

Step 1: Walk casually through patient-access areas wearing a bag containing RFID scanning module.Step 2: Pass near beds where RFID wristbands are in range (10-30cm).Step 3: Capture transmitted patient tag data silently.Step 4: Store each UID with a timestamp for correlation.Step 5: Analyze data to map room-patient-tag IDs for surveillance simulation.Step 6: Demonstrate how this data could be used to impersonate or relocate patients in simulated attack.

Step 1: Walk or fly with an SDR device collecting RF signal strength and reflection data from walls and objects.Step 2: Use AI model trained to recognize signal "echoes" from PQ crypto activity (typically more intense bursts).Step 3: Generate a heatmap of signal density and likely crypto processing zones inside the building.Step 4: Correlate signal maps with time-of-day crypto operations for targeted attacks later.Step 5: Identify vulnerable PQ key exchange times to deploy secondary attacks.
Step 1: Walks behind employee. Step 2: Pretends to use phone. Step 3: Takes silent photo of screen showing sensitive data. Step 4: Emails photo to outside contact.

Step 1: Wear BLE-enabled smartwatch paired with QKD controller.Step 2: Use custom app to listen to photon timestamp updates.Step 3: Intercept and alter timestamps to match attacker's injected photon timings.Step 4: Match injected photons to expected base using log manipulation.Step 5: Allow key reconciliation to proceed.Step 6: Store full key within smartwatch app.Step 7: Erase app data post-session.

Step 1: Wear OS smartwatch with outdated firmware is kept powered on with Bluetooth active. Step 2: Attacker scans with blueborne-scanner and identifies the smartwatch by MAC and OS fingerprint. Step 3: Using Metasploit’s BlueBorne module, attacker crafts a payload targeting Android Wear Bluetooth stack. Step 4: Exploit triggers a buffer overflow in the Bluetooth service, granting shell access. Step 5: Attacker uses Android shell to access GPS, microphone, and step-count sensors.

Step 1: Wear a smartwatch with camera (e.g., Apple Watch, Galaxy Watch).Step 2: Sit near a screen showing sensitive info.Step 3: Tap watch to take discreet photo.Step 4: Sync watch to personal phone later.Step 5: Extract image and share externally.

Step 1: Wear simple overalls or uniform (no ID badge). Step 2: Carry a clipboard and a small toolbag. Step 3: Walk into HR area confidently saying you’re checking ventilation. Step 4: Ask them to leave you alone “for privacy during test.” Step 5: Take photos or steal files from unlocked cabinets.

Step 1: Word document titled “Annual_KPI_Targets.docm” is created.Step 2: Macro opens OneNote and creates a new note.Step 3: The note includes a hidden .exe payload attached and embedded in a visual element.Step 4: User is told to check the "new shared note" in email.Step 5: Victim opens Word file, macro creates and opens the OneNote silently.Step 6: User double-clicks the embedded file believing it’s part of the note.Step 7: .exe runs and gives attacker control.Step 8: Malware uses persistence to stay even after reboot.Step 9: Attacker controls infected machine.Step 10: OneNote is used as a sneaky vector, bypassing many filters.

Step 1: Word file “Quarterly_Review_Metrics.docm” includes a macro.Step 2: Macro downloads a full-screen fake “Windows Update in progress…” message.Step 3: While this screen is displayed, the macro uses PowerShell to encrypt files.Step 4: Victim opens file and enables content, believing it to be a real update.Step 5: User sees the fake update screen and waits.Step 6: In the background, PowerShell encrypts user documents, spreadsheets, and images.Step 7: Once completed, screen disappears and ransom note appears.Step 8: Attacker demands payment to decrypt files.Step 9: System is non-functional until restored or decrypted.Step 10: Files may be permanently lost if ransom not paid.

Step 1: Word macro includes URL of payload PDF.Step 2: Macro auto-downloads and opens it on file open.Step 3: PDF uses a known exploit to attack PDF reader.Step 4: Shellcode in PDF executes hidden malware.Step 5: Malware runs with local user privileges.

Step 1: Word macro targets Documents folder.Step 2: Deletes .docx, .xlsx, .pdf files using VBA FileSystemObject.Step 3: Sent as resume attachment in fake job email.Step 4: Victim opens and enables macros.Step 5: Macro runs and files are deleted permanently.

Step 1: Write Arduino sketch to send keystrokes (e.g., open terminal, run malware). Step 2: Upload sketch and connect Digispark to target PC. Step 3: It runs pre-programmed keystrokes silently. Step 4: Payload runs with user or admin rights if session is open.

Step 1: Write DuckyScript that opens terminal and downloads a bot script silently.Step 2: Load script into USB Rubber Ducky.Step 3: Insert into target PC — it types commands automatically.Step 4: Installs bot that connects to attacker's server.Step 5: Remote C2 connection is established.

Step 1: Write HTML email saying “We are performing system updates. Log in here to preserve access.” Step 2: Set fake From: it-team@company.com. Step 3: Link to a cloned internal login portal. Step 4: Send via Mailtrap or SMTP test server. Step 5: Employee clicks and logs in. Step 6: Credentials stolen.

Step 1: Write PowerShell script that gets executed on receiving certain emails.Step 2: Set an Outlook Rule to auto-run script when subject is e.g., “#update”.Step 3: Victim opens Outlook; bot triggers.Step 4: Commands can be sent via emails.Step 5: Bot reports back via email or webhook.

Step 1: Write Python script to grab Discord token from local files.Step 2: Add file encryption function afterward.Step 3: Convert to EXE and disguise as “GameBooster2025.exe”.Step 4: Share via Discord or simulate local execution.Step 5: Script runs, logs out victim from Discord, encrypts files.Step 6: Drops ransom note.

Step 1: Write Python script using smtplib. Step 2: Set MAIL FROM to it-support@company.com Step 3: Set RCPT TO to victim’s email. Step 4: Craft email body saying “Reset your password here”. Step 5: Include fake reset link. Step 6: Run the script to send the spoofed email.

Step 1: Write a C++ program that calls the CPUID instruction with function ID 0x40000000.Step 2: This special CPUID call returns a vendor-neutral hypervisor signature.Step 3: Compare the returned string to known hypervisors like Microsoft Hv, VMwareVMware, or KVMKVMKVM.Step 4: If a match is found, the malware exits.Step 5: If no hypervisor is detected, the malware proceeds with a mock payload.Step 6: Simulate this behavior in both VM and physical environments to observe difference.

Step 1: Write a C++ program that raises a dummy exception (e.g., divide by zero).Step 2: In the exception handler, use RtlCaptureStackBackTrace or StackWalk64 to inspect the call stack.Step 3: Analyze if any unexpected hooks (sandbox DLLs, injected modules) are in the trace.Step 4: If abnormal call stacks are found (e.g., fake parent processes), abort execution.Step 5: If the stack is clean, proceed with payload.Step 6: Test this against sandboxes with API hooking frameworks (like Cuckoo).

Step 1: Write a JS bookmarklet to log keystrokes.Step 2: Make it look like a utility (e.g., “Dark Mode”).Step 3: Post on social media or blogs.Step 4: Victim drags it to bookmarks and clicks it.Step 5: Keylogger activates and logs inputs on every page.

Step 1: Write a PowerShell script that checks a Pastebin URL every minute.Step 2: Upload a benign-looking base64 or plain text command to Pastebin.Step 3: Trick the target into running the PowerShell script (via USB, phishing, etc.).Step 4: The infected PC will execute whatever command is stored in the Pastebin content.Step 5: Update Pastebin content to issue new commands remotely.

Step 1: Write a Python malware stub that starts with a time.sleep(600) delay (10 minutes).Step 2: After sleep, it prints a message or executes dummy payload.Step 3: Sandboxes that limit execution time (e.g., 5 mins) terminate before malware does anything.Step 4: On real machines, malware resumes after the delay.Step 5: Modify script to detect patched sleep (i.e., bypassed sleep) to enhance stealth.

Step 1: Write a Python script that records mic input and logs to hidden file. Step 2: Add metamorphic code that rewrites itself at intervals. Step 3: Convert script to .exe and store in USB drive with AutoRun. Step 4: Trick target into plugging in USB (e.g., labeled “Confidential”). Step 5: Malware activates and records audio. Step 6: Code changes on its own periodically. Step 7: Logs are hidden in system folders.

Step 1: Write a Python script using smtplib. Step 2: Script connects to mail.target.com over port 25. Step 3: Sends standard EHLO to mimic real clients. Step 4: Executes VRFY for common names quietly. Step 5: Waits a few seconds between each request to evade rate-limiting. Step 6: Logs valid usernames to a file. Step 7: Optionally uses TLS if available to encrypt probing.

Step 1: Write a Python script with Scapy to send 50 beacon frames in rapid succession with 5-second intervals. Step 2: Use randomized MAC addresses and SSIDs each cycle. Step 3: Schedule script execution using cron to run every 5 seconds. Step 4: Wi-Fi scanners on the client device refresh every few seconds and prioritize strongest SSIDs — these fake APs show up briefly but strongly. Step 5: Observe intermittent Wi-Fi instability due to sudden signal spikes and client confusion.

Step 1: Write a Slack message like [Download Report](https://trusted-domain.com) but mask the actual URL to redirect to https://attacker-site.com.Step 2: Attacker hosts a site that resembles a corporate dashboard login page.Step 3: Include scripts to extract OAuth or cookie-based tokens.Step 4: Send message in a channel with context like “Monthly Metrics Available”.Step 5: Victim clicks link, believing it to be safe due to link text.Step 6: Browser loads malicious site; script captures session tokens silently.Step 7: Attacker accesses protected services (e.g., Slack, email, G-Suite).

Step 1: Write a VBScript to open Outlook and send email with malware attached. Step 2: Store it on USB. Step 3: Use Rubber Ducky to auto-run the script. Step 4: Victim’s system becomes unwitting sender.

Step 1: Write a custom email where a header like “Reply-To” contains script or malicious-looking content (e.g., <script>alert('XSS')</script>).Step 2: Send this email to an invalid recipient at a domain.Step 3: Wait for the bounce-back message.Step 4: Observe that some servers may reflect the custom header in the bounce.Step 5: If received by a human (e.g., support staff), this may result in reflected code execution or confusion.Step 6: Can be used for phishing or XSS reconnaissance.

Step 1: Write a macro in Word that launches a PowerShell script. Step 2: PowerShell connects to a website to download the malware. Step 3: Use a script generator that mutates the PowerShell commands every time. Step 4: Embed macro in a file named “Meeting_Agenda.docm”. Step 5: Email file to employees. Step 6: When opened, payload is downloaded and installed. Step 7: Macro regenerates new script structure for every document.

Step 1: Write a macro-enabled .xlsm file.Step 2: Inside VBA, fetch a remote command from web (e.g., pastebin or raw GitHub).Step 3: Distribute Excel via email.Step 4: When user enables macro, commands are fetched.Step 5: Macro runs downloaded script silently.
